Posted: October 23, 2015
Great game for the age! But for some it does not work. Here is a way to fix the game1. Run the game atleast once2. Go To Library-->Fallout 3-->Press Properties-->Local Files-->Browse Local Files-->fallout 3-->Fallout 3.ini3. Press "Ctrl+F" type (without quotation marks) "bUseThreadedAI"-If the game has been started it should already be a line named "bUseThreadedAI=0", change the 0 to 1.If the line isn't there, add it in the in the .ini folder. Anywhere is fine as long it      has its own line.4. This is maybe not needed, it works without it for me.   -(This next line shouldn't be in your file already but do a quick Ctrl+F to make sure, if it is change    it accordingly)-Directly underneath "bUseThreadedAI=1", write "iNumHWThreads=2". If it's already there, just change whatever value it is to "2".Save & Exit¨For 144hz users.Keep the screen settings at a maximum of 60Hz and you should be fine. This prevents stuttering, and prevents the physics engine to spasm out.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I drank water from toilet to increase health. 10/10 would buy again.EDIT: Wow, I didn't realise that this "review" had got so much attention o_O. Allright, since I've played this game for nearly 600 hours, I'll give you a serious recommendation.If you're a fan of The Elder Scrolls series like me, you'll love it. Fallout 3 is kinda similar to TES IV: Oblivion in many aspects. Don't expect a fast-paced shooting gallery because combat's the weakest spot in the game. Fallout 3 is all abount exploration, moral choices and immersing yourself into the world. Walking lonely with your dog like two little dots in the Capital Wasteland, crawling in the dark while exploring an abandon Vault, punching a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in his face because he annoyed your girl, blowing up a city to become an evil based... are just some small things among thousands of insane♥♥♥♥♥♥you can do in this game.What I love most about Fallout 3 is the dark atmosphere. In this game, you really feel like you're in a dead world. You rarely find a house that's not completely ruined, you will meet many kinds of people, from poor citizen who can't protect themselves from Mutants to cannibals and slave traders. The diversity is undeniable, the world is beautifully crafted in a dark and heavy tone. Fallout 3 sometimes doesn't take itself seriously, it's the result from a script filled with black-comedy, from story, dialogues to the ridiculous amount of gore. Fallout 3 is an over-the-top game, but it still managed to maintain both dark tone and comedic writing.Combat is... well, not so much things to say. You can find bazilion of weapons, from a small pistol, sub-machine gun to things that can blow up a god damn building like a rocket launcher called Fat Man, a holy♥♥♥♥♥♥it's-on-fire machete with a name that I can't spell properly and a gun that can shoot junks you put in called Rock-It-Launcher (I wished it allowed me to put someone's head in it). However, the impressive amount of weapons can't prevent the combat system from being dull. 3rd person camera works better than it does in Oblivion, but I found it a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to use it in combat so I recommend sticking with 1st person camera. This game has a turn-based system called V.A.T.S. In the first Fallout games, this point counts the actions that player can use, from moving to using your weapon. In Fallout 3, this system serves as an aimbot helping you "mark" enemy's parts of their body (it has percentages, so don't expect to get 100% YOLOSWAG420). The problem is, VATS can be abuse, you can shoot an enemy, run back, wait for it to regenerate and bam, get back to the warzone. The mechanic of this system is a little bit weird and I'm not sure if it's a positive or negative point.Shooting people isn't something special, you met a bunch of bandits ? Keep the distance and shoot them. You found a big ♥♥♥♥ing bear ? Keep the distance and shoot him. You met 10 Enclave soldiers ? Keep the distance and shoot them. You met a mother♥♥♥♥ing Deathclaw ? Keep the distance and shoot him. Combat is kinda dull, repetitive and it only feels decent if you manage to find creative ways to punish enemies, like putting a grenade inside a bandit's pants and see him explode or firing a flamethrower while sneaking behind an Enclave soldier.Graphics looks kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ by today's standard, but you can always find some enhancing mods so that's not a big trouble.My conclusion: After 580 hours in this game, I had a very good time immersing myself in a dark, dead wasteland. Combat is dull, karma system doesn't make sense sometimes, but other aspects has hidden those shortcomings perfectly. I'm not a Fallout hardcore fan, but now I want to be. 9/10. AND GOD DAMN IT BETHESDA, RELEASE FALLOUT 4 ALREADY!!!.P/S: It works fine on Windows 7, at least for me.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Probably one of my favourite games of all time. Stepping out of the vault into the harsh sun drenched wasteland is a moment in my gaming history that I will never quite forget. The thrill of seeing this open world stretching off to the horizon, knowing that adventure awaited me, left me almost awe struck.The game itself is a totally open game where you can chose your own path in a Post Apocalyptic hell hole. Will you be a heroic saviour of mankind, or a vicious survivor who does what is needed to survive? It is completely up to you. On your way you will meet a mix of people, some evil, some less so, and others .. well let's just say the wasteland produces a lot of strange characters. A great game, but made even greater by the modding community that has been built up around it. This is one of those games I highly recommend modding pretty much immediately. And if you have any worries about doing so, check out my tutorials for modding this game: 


YouTube™ Video: Modding Fallout 3 - Part 1 : Getting Started with FWE and Marts Mutant Mod 

			Views: 440,686		

			This video is aimed at people new to modding Fallout 3 or people who have been reluctant to install mods because they felt it was a little too complicated.		

Be warned however that this game is old, and will need quite a lot of tweaking to get working on Windows 7 or later. If you also own Fallout: New Vegas, I would actually recommend using the Tales of Two Wastelands mod to play the Fallout 3 story using the Fallout: New Vegas engine, which is far more stable and works fine on Windows 7. I have no tutorial on this mod yet, but when I do, I will update this review.IMPORTANT: I have played this game for several hundred hours, but not on this account, and most with certain mods installed that stop Steam from knowing that I was playing.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Excellent game.100% working on my Windows 8 64-bit system.Only limitation is impossibility to recover back after keys Alt + Tab.Note: there is no Steam achievements.Step 1 obligatoryStart Fallout, click Play, push the escape key and Quit.It will validate your game, detect your graphics card and create a fallout.ini.=======================Step 2 if neededIF CRASHING WHEN CLICKING "PLAY"Fallout 3 has an error that says "Ordinal 42 could not be found in the Dynamic Link Library" or something related to "Xlive.dll".This error message comes up when you do not have Games for Windows Live installed on your computer. You can download that client here: http://www.xbox.com/en-US/live/pc/DownloadClient Note, you will not be able to make any other use of the service at this time. If that doesn't work, click "options" and set your resolution to your desktop res, or try windowed mode.======================Step 3 if needed (I did not needed it)As Fallout 3 was created prior to the release of Windows 7 and 8, it is not tested or supported on either of these newer operating systems. There are, however, a few workarounds that players can use to run the game.First, you may be able to run it using compatibility mode. To change compatibility settings for Fallout 3:1.Locate the application file for the game. This can be found in one of the following folders depending on which version of the game you use: ◦Retail versions: C:\Program Files (x86)\Bethesda Softworks\Fallout 3 ◦Steam versions: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\Steamapps\Common\Fallout 32.Right-click on the application file and select Properties.3.Click on the Compatibility tab.4.Check the box Run this program in compatibility mode.5.Choose Windows XP Service Pack 3 from the drop-down.6.It may also be necessary to check the box for Run this program as an administrator.7.Repeat steps 2-6 for the Fallout 3 launcher file in the same folder. It is labeled: FalloutLauncher8.Run the game.======================Step 3 importantFallout 3 was not developed for use on PCs with more than two cores. If your PC has more than two cores, please try the following steps:1.Open your My Documents folder.2.Under My Games, open the Fallout 3 folder and select the fallout.ini file.3.In the fallout.ini file, find the following line: bUseThreadedAI=04.Change this line to read: bUseThreadedAI=15.Add another line after it that reads: iNumHWThreads=26.Run the game.======================Step 4 Optional but strongly recommended!Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch TONS of bug fixes. It would take dozens of pages to list them all.* The site registration for Nexus is free and quick.Patch v1.8 (1 November 2014)http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/19122/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F2Fwww.nexusmods.com2Ffallout3%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D19122&pUp=1

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Imagine yourself in a world that consists of daily routine and hard work. A small room for your house and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥for your neighbors. You dont know what lies beyond the safety of… The Vault. Fallout 3 takes you on a never seen before adventure in a videogame that still shocks and awes people today. With one of the largest maps in a videogame and 5 DLC’s, fallout 3 brings the post-apocalyptic future, from books and movies to life where you are the main character. with 100’s of quests and people, Fallout 3 is an amazingly fun game to explore.	It takes place in the post-apocalyptic washington D.C. which has 100’s of streets and even more metro tunnels. With everything from compounds to abandon buildings, you will come across everything from raiders to town dwellers to the enclave and more!Ok, now for the numbers:Graphics: 7.5/10 This is not concerning although because of new mods coming out daily for new experiences.Controls: (Pc) 7/10 and (xbox controller) 10/10. Buy a controller for this game, it is worth it.Handling: 9/10. A very smooth game.Story: 8/10. Story ha its moments and It's just ok. But the side quests where very good and a few DLC's where amazing like Mothership Zeta.Gameplay: 8/10. Falls short a bit compared to the rest of the game but it still has great moments, especially in the DLC’s.Creativity: 8/10. Never done before… in a videogame.Price: 10+/10. $20 in DLC with the game for only $20 full price. I have over 300 hours on this game and still i got it for $5 on sale!!! DO NOT TURN AWAY BECAUSE OF THE PRICE!!!Hype: 10/10. Enough said.Overall: 9/10. BUY BUY BUY!

She looks gorgeous all of the time and always does her best to keep you entertained for hours and hours and hours on end, she has a really nice and amazing futuristic 1950's style to her that no one could hate and she has some really good taste in music too!Sure, she has a few issues, she takes her time getting ready and sometimes when she is getting ready she will just stop getting ready and go to sleep until you wake her up again. Posted: July 28, 2016
												Is your Fallout 3 GOTY PC copy always freezing every 5 minutes? Here's an easy fix:1) Search the fallout.ini file (back it up if you want)2) Find the line: bUseThreadedAI=03) Change the line to: bUseThreadedAI=14) Now add another line after it and insert: iNumHWThreads=2This will limit the game to 2 cores, and prevent the engine from freezing. Ever since I've used this quick solution I've had zero crashes. Have fun!

Posted: October 8, 2016
												How to get FO3 working on Windows 10. This worked for me (AMD FX-8350, Nvidia GTX780),  so I´ll share it with you.1. Download Games for Windows LIVE Disablerhttp://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?Just open the exe and select Disable G4WL.2. Go to C:\users\yourname\Documents\My Games\Fallout3\FALLOUT.iniOpen the file with NotepadFind bUseThreadedAI=0 and change it to bUseThreadedAI=1, immediately below it add a line with iNumHWThreads=2This should be enough for most of you. 3. If the game crashes at a new game, download this modified d3d9.dll.https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B4rlGqEs-BxtcWdEdlh0TDM1SkkGo to C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Fallout 3 goty\ and paste it there.This dll makes FO3 think that you have a Nvidia 7900GS, so your graphic settings will be reset. Just adjust them to your liking again, most modern GPUs can run perfectly with the Ultra preset.Don´t forget to enable all the data files in the launcher. For some reason, the DLCs come disabled by default.Some screenshots:

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Gameplay is excellent. I've heard some complaints about the combat but i thought it was great. The V.A.T.S gives you a really cool tactical shooter perspective.The Animations are a bit akward and theres no sprinting which should be ESSENTIAL because the world is so vast. This is nothing that mods couldn't fix. The leveling system is amazing in which you can choose which skills you want to master based on your playstyle.Visuals:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441989686The visuals are alright. It's something you would expect since it was released in 2008. I thought the visuals were pretty good and nailed the vibe but looked a bit bland. I installed a few mods to fix this. If your computer can handle them i suggest modding the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game graphically.Audio:The audio of this game is AMAZING. The soundtrack fits right into the retro 50's post apocalyptic setting. Having the in game radio on at all times is a REQUIREMENT to fully enjoy this game.Environment:


Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: รкг๏๏ℓ๏๏รε




The environment in this game is big but not huge. It's an open world game much like Skyrim is. The map is filled with sidequest you can do for awesome rewards like laser guns or awesome launchers that launch 6 nukes at a time and causes an a explosion so big it might crash your game and make GTX Titan Z's cry.Optimization:This game is not very well optimized for Windows 7,8. But there are solutions on the internet that will fix the game for the most part. During my 60 hours the game crashed about 11 times. around 7 of those were in one of the DLC's(Point Lookout) which is almost unplayable due to low framerate and crashing.Verdict:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441062483This game is hands down one of the best games i have played and this a must buy for any video game fan. Even tho i put 60 hours into this i've barely scratched the surface since i have 3 full DLC's and their respective sidequest and half the sidequest in the main game to complete. After this i am definetly gonna definitely gonna pick up Fallout: New Vegas

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Part 1: How to play Fallout 3 on windows 101) Open the properties on the exes and active administrative mode and set compatibility to xp service pack 32) Open Fallout.ini in C:\Users\(insertusernamehere)\Documents\My Games and search for "bUseThreadedAI" no quotes, change the zero to a one3) Right below it add a line "iNumHWThreads=2" no quotes4) Download this and apply it to Fallout.exe --> http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?Voila, worked for me, should work fine for you.OPTIONAL: If you want a lot less bugs since Bethesda sucks at optimizing games, download and install this --> http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/19122/?(I know I kind of copied the guide, but since so many reviews are moaning about it not working, I think posting this here is more useful)for more info, please refer to this guide --> 


ULTIMATE Fallout 3 Setup & Mod guide Windows 10, 8 & 7 
A Guide for Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: BenWah

			The best setup guide for Fallout 3!		


I also recommend getting RH_Ironsights ( http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/6938/? ) and Realistic Wasteland Lighting ( http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/20346/? ), even if you're doing a Vanilla run through. The Ironsights mod adds an essential feature that for some reason Bethesda did not put into the game (all you do is just pull the gun a little closer), and the RWL mod changes the weather and lighting to get rid of that awful green tinge on everything, and makes it look wayyy more realistic. You can get a lot more mods through the guide I showed you above.ACTUAL REVIEW:Fallout 3 was my first entry into the fallout franchise, as such it will always hold a special place in my heart. It's not perfect, but it's a damn enjoyable game. Arguably the best location of all the fallout games, some great exploration. The storytelling is good too, but if you start thinking about it, then it starts to make less sense (why does it look like the planet was nuked only 10 years ago when it's 200+ years later, why is every building full of tons of ammo and loot after so long, why not use Megaton's water purifier?). Mainly I blame this on poor writing on Bethesda, but overall it's still a good game, still miles better than Fallout 4.Another minor issue of mine is that every 5 minutes the capital wasteland just spawns a random event out of no where, and unrealistically scales the events to your level, but I guess that's to prevent us from being utterly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥while exploring.Overall: Fallout 3 is one of the best post-apocalyptic games out there. It actually feels like an apocalypse, and plus you can explore a bombed-out DC that has so many awesome places to look through. Some may say... DERR BUT FALLOUT 4 IS NEWER AND LOOKS BETTER HAS BETTER GUNPLAY. Looks can be decieving my friends, I too fell for the trap that was Fallout 4. Yes, the gunplay is better and the game looks cooler, but it suffers in literally everything else.If you're looking for your first fallout game, don't get fallout 4, get this one, then get New Vegas.

												This is a great game from Bethdesda, it was the first I played in the series and it was a brilliant Survival Horror style First-Person Open-World Role-Playing Game. (SHFPSOWRPG).If you even remoteley enjoyed or found interest in games like Skyrim, Fallout: New Vegas or other titles from Bethdesda, this one is VERY MUCH WORTH IT. The narrative is great, the main story can be completed in about a few hours, but if you roam the world and try to explore, interact and enjoy it then it will take well over decades for you to finish it. If you ever manage to finish all the sidequests, storylines, locate all the places on the map, experience all the random events and meet all the intriguing characters and learn of stories in the past or present gameworld; then you can play the DLCs, Broken Steel, Operation: Anchorage, Point Lookout and Mothership Zeta. The DLCs accumulate up to even more hours of main quests, not to ignore the fact they add new locations and maybe even a whole new part of the game world.TL;DR: Get this game, it is ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant you slacker.-Stario

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												Ah, the good, somewhat old, Fallout 3. The best in the series, falling shortly behind Fallout 2, the god of such RPGs, in my opinion. If you care to put some time into optimizing the bugs and tweaking settings to make it run propely, this is a damn near perfect game by our beloved Bethesda. Expanding the universe of the already exciting post-nuclear America, we're shown what happens to the area surrounding Washington, D.C., called "The Capital Wasteland". A rather grimmy environment that is packed with creepy and eerie surroundings. There's not one moment in the wasteland where you can feel truly safe from the mole rats to the Deathclaws wanting to rip your head open with their giant fangs. Did I mention they're ♥♥♥♥ing terrifying?Gameplay has stayed somewhat true to its predecessors, you still have the V.A.T.S. system, but it's no longer turn-based, as you'd guess. The story is not the greatest, it has never been in the Fallout franchise, but what makes up for this is all the other stuff you can do in the Capital Wasteland. There's tons of different sidequests to do, multiple unique weapons and other stuff to collect, such as the bobbleheads - which increase your stats depending on which ones you pick up. The world is giant as you would expect, about 100+ locations to discover and, potentially, loot. Rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Overall: 10/10Probably my favorite game of all time, although I really liked Fallout: New Vegas for it's weapon and ammo variety I still preferred Fallout 3s' atmosphere, story and characters.Concept: 10/10You are born in an underground vault that's had no contact with the outside world for hundreds of years. Create your own unique character, male or female, and quickly escape to learn that the nuclear war from long ago has left a wasteland topside. With humanity struggling for survival, mutants occupying the DC ruins with a mysterious agenda, and the various irradiated creatures of the waste, the setting feels like "Fallout". Play how you want, investing in the skills you choose to develope your character to reflect your play style.Graphics: 8/10At the time the graphics were not bad, but not good either. I would give some leneincy to Bethesda however, considering how large and content rich their open world games are. Character models could be stiff as well, but I was able to overlook this because of the sheer variety of locations, items, people and creatures you interact with.Sound: 9/10One thing i'll always credit Bethesda for is having so much voiced dialogue. Every NPC has voiced dialogue despite their importance, greatly improving immersion. I was also impressed with the radio stations. Hours and hours of music and dialogue between several different radio stations made the long walks to new destinations less of a bore. As far as Audio effects go i'd say most were well done. Some guns didn't sound like they had enough "bang" to be realistic, but the energy weapons and melee sounds were entertaining.Playability: 9/10Amazingly customizable, even more so with mods. You can make your character look how you want, play how you want, and do what you want. Use the weapons and tactics you want to use. If you want to go off and explore 30 minutes into the game you can, and it's just as rewarding/interesting as following the main quest. I only knock a point off of this due to the many bugs/issues people had at the release of this game. While it's improved drastically, there is still the occasional crash, glitch, or corruption.Entertainment: 10/10There are literally hundreds of hours of fun to be had here. A lot of people complained about the main quest, but I found it to be interesting and more importantly, rewarding. The main quest however, is just a tiny piece of the games content. 90% of the entertainment can be found by just exploring on your own. The character customiztion enhances this, making a lot of interactions and situations unique to your character based on their skill set or decisions. Replayability: 10/10The amount of customization options and content ensure that no two playthroughs are the same. I've made half a dozen characters and still discover new things in this wasteland...

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Warning: Disliking this game is punishable by death.Methods of execution include getting beaten to death by drug-crazed raiders, blown apart by explosive weapons, turned into ash by one of the many laser weapons used here, and dying slowly and horribly from radiation poisoning. Fun! But all of these execution methods are, ultimately, better than becoming a communist. As Liberty Prime so eloquently puts it: better dead than red.Seriously though. Dislike this game and I will personally call a vertibird strike on your♥♥♥♥♥ You have been warned. o_OThe first Fallout game by Bethesda is noticeably different in tone from the old Fallout games, and particularly Fallout 2. This is one of the bleakest and most depressing games I've ever played, depicting a world that is in far worse shape than any other Fallout game where there are at least some signs of civilization returning. Here... everything is either dead or slowly dying as it is consumed by non-stop violence and pervasive radiation. How lovely. x_xThe most logical explanation for this, aside from the change in developer, is that whereas the previous Fallout games centered on the West Coast of the USA with only a few major cities (Los Angeles/The Boneyard in Fallout 1, San Francisco in Fallout 2) showing up in relatively small roles in the plot, Fallout 3 centers on Washington DC, the US capital (as well as Pittsburgh, PA in a DLC). A city that, in any nuclear war, would be a primary target for destruction, and that destruction is very much on display in a disturbing amount of detail. As someone who has visited DC three times in my life at the time of writing, the last of which occuring about a week after I first played this game (January 2009), strolling around the ruins of a place I have seen in the real world is really eerie. Almost every major landmark in DC can be visited in Fallout 3, except now they are all in various stages of ruin (The Washington Monument is more or less intact, while the White House is just a massive radioactive crater) and filled with ceaseless violence.If you have played Bethesda's other open-world RPG's like Oblivion or Skyrim, then you know how this plays: lots of quests and stuff to do, but mostly its about running around a huge world and seeing what you find. There are some glitches and crashes, so be sure to save often. GFWL is part of this, but you can tell that to bugger off pretty easily (and in fact you need to in order to use the best mods). Also while it might take a little work to get mods working, they are more than worth the effort. The superb mods for New Vegas and Skyrim found on the Nexus Network websites can be traced back to Fallout 3 mods, and many have the same creators (Fallout 3's FWE later became New Vegas' Project Nevada). In other words, this game has insane replay value by itself, and modding Fallout 3 can turn this into a game with virtually endless amounts of things to do.The GOTY version includes the five DLC's, which are a mixed bag of awesome, competence, and failure. Broken Steel is probably the best since it allows you to play after the end of the main story, along with the host of additional content it adds. The Pitt is a dark atmospheric journey into the industrial ruins of Pittsburgh filled with gray morality and disturbing choices. Point Lookout sends you into a similarly immersive swamp area with lots to explore and one of the most memorable (and by far the foulest-mouthed) characters in the Fallout series. But the other two DLC, Operation Anchorage's linear adventure into a simulation of a great battle before the apocalypse (It's ok) and Mothership Zeta's killing spree through an alien spaceship (ugh...), fall far below the other three in quality. Regardless, all of them add more to the game and give you plenty of new toys to use in the main game.I've heard this game has some issues with Win7 and newer operating systems, but I don't know anything about that since I'm still using the same PC I used when I first played this game so many years ago. I do believe there are fixes, but people with those newer OS's should look into them before buying this (or just get it on sale)Regardless of its bugs and other issues that keep it from being perfect, this is one of my favorite games of all time, and that's really all you need to know. Buy it. Play it. Like it. Or else I will call you a communist and point Libery Prime your way.Communism is the very definition of failure. :P

number of helpful: 88 of 101 people (87%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Just to clarify with you, I have been playing Fallout 3 ever since I was ten years old (yes, a ten year old played this game). I remember begging my mom for it day after day ever since the first day it was released. When I saw that lunchbox (collector's edition) shaped present under my tree, I opened it instantaneously and saw my dream present. I ran up to my room, launched it on my Xbox 360, and experienced one of the best things I had ever seen/played in my life. I think that overall, I have accumulated over 1200 hours playing this one game, so now you know that I have some experience with it. Moving on to the review...*By the way, I wrote this review as a huge piece, but I decided to divide it up with headers if you want to learn about a specific aspect only.INTRO and CHARACTER CREATIONFallout 3 is set in a post-apocalyptic version of Washington, DC. You are a resident living in Vault 101, one of the many underground shelters built by a company named 'Vault-Tec' before the bombs dropped in America on October 23, 2077.  About 200 years later, the game starts you off with a thirty minute prologue. You begin right at birth where you create your character's appearance and eventually set his/her's S.P.E.C.I.A.L. attributes and your TAG skills. If you played the original Fallout or Wasteland games, you will be very familiar with the character creation system. Basically, you have 33 points to work around with that can be placed in Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck and you will excel or be weaker in certain areas depending on where you allocate these points. TAG skills on the other hand raise three of your skills by +15 to give you boosts in certain areas when you start off.PLOT/STORY and QUESTSIn the beginning of your life, everything is fairly normal in the vault. You are raised by your single-dad, James (voiced by Liam Neeson), and deal with the usual experiences of childhood such as birthday parties, friendships, bullies, and school. Once you reach the segment when you are nineteen years old (five segments at ages 0, 1, 10, 16, and 19), things start to go wild when your dad leaves Vault 101 without you. Naturally, you decide to escape the vault yourself to find dear old Dad and discover why he left and where you can find him. Along the way, you will run into extremely diverse characters ranging from a grizzled man who is the sheriff of a town centered on an undetonated atomic bomb, a ghoul-hating, deceptive old geezer who owns a refurbished hotel, a psychotic, Russian pimp who is willing to sell his women's "services" to anyone who has enough caps (currency), and even aliens. I won't say anything more about the plot, but in my opinion, Fallout 3 has a very personal main quest that will pull your heart strings on numerous occasions.Accompanied by the main quests are an insane amount of side quests that will lead you to the many interesting settlements across the Capital Wasteland. They range from simple assassination and extortion missions all the way to solving a crisis between two "superheroes" disrupting a town or managing a cannibal situation. Whenever you play Fallout 3, your quest tab in the Pip-Boy 3000 will always have at least something in it for you to complete and you will never be left empty handed - especially with the amazing mods out there (I will get into that later). USER INTERFACESpeaking of the Pip-Boy, it is your main user-interface while playing. With the press of a button, your status, karma, missions, map, items, notes, and radio will all be easily accessible to you. It is a great, clean interface that makes everything very manageble for the player.SOUNDTRACKOne thing that is easily overlooked with Fallout 3 is its incredible soundtrack. All of the music is from the early-mid 20th century and it perfectly fits the atmosphere of the game. Eventually, you will know many of the songs note for note and for some reason, I have not gotten tired of the music six years later. However, the ambient soundtrack is another huge strength for the game. When you are exploring the Capital Wasteland without the radio playing on your Pip-Boy, you will get to hear the creepy atmospheric music play in the background. It will build up the suspense in you and keep you always on the lookout for any nearby threats. The combat music is good too and it will make encounters feel more deadly and action-packed.GAMEPLAYAs for the gameplay, the shooting mechanics are ok, but not the best. There is no iron-sights capability without mods, so if you are playing this on console or without the Fallout Script Extender, FOSE for short, then you are going to have to aim with a tiny UI crosshair. This is a bad system, but it is managable due to slight auto-aim. I think that the auto-aim was added with the intention to correct this flaw, but once again it can be removed using mods (we are getting there :P) and it is not a big deal. There are a variety of guns in the game that range from the categories of small guns (pistols, rifles, etc.), big guns (miniguns, rocket launchers, FAT-MAN's, etc.), energy weapons (laser and plasma pistols and rifles), and explosives. Melee combat is basically the exact same as The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion so if you liked it in that game, you will enjoy it in Fallout 3. You can go unarmed or use a bladed or blunt weapon.Weapons are not the only things to consider in Fallout 3. Secondary skills like repair, medicine, and speech all carry just as much weight as the combat skills. It is even possible to make characters that focus exclusively on non-combat skills and have hireable companions do all the killing for you. This is the beauty of the Fallout games, any character build can be viable as long as you do what is necessary to make it work.As you progress throughout the game your character gains xp by completing tasks like killing, discovering new locations, lockpicking, hacking, passing speech checks, completing quests, and more. When you reach the xp requirement to advance in level, you can allocate your skill points (amount of skill points determined by intelligence) to any of the thirteen skills accessible to you. This does not follow the "practice makes perfect" levelling module that The Elder Scrolls uses.MODSThis is the big one that you have been waiting for! The Fallout 3 nexus (fallout3.nexusmods.com) at this moment contains 13 526 files available to download for free to enhance your Fallout 3 experience, and the number grows daily. Just about anything can be tweaked or created by using the Garden of Eden Creation Kit, or G.E.C.K. for short, and can be uploaded to the nexus for others to try out. You have probably heard of mods that are commonly used like Fallout Wanderer's Edition, Energy Visuals Enhanced, RH_Ironsights, and Weapon Mod Kits, which can greatly add to the experience. These mods are excellent and add many things that should have been in the game to begin with. Just be warned, mods can cause instability with the game, save corruption, constant CTD's, and can be incompatibile with other mods. For your first playthrough I would highly recommend downloading strictly fixes and tweaks like the Updated Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch, the Fallout Stutter Remover, Fallout 3 - Enhanced Camera, the 4GB Patch, and texture mods. You could even download FWE, but I would 100% go to the preset options once you exit the vault in the FWE control panel and use the 'I Love Vanilla' preset to keep the original feel of the game. When you are done with your first playthrough of the vanilla game, go ahead and add in all the mods you want! Just make sure you know what you are doing and if you don't, follow Gopher's EXCEPTIONAL 'Fallout 3 Modding Guide' on Youtube.CONCLUSIONWar, War Never Changes... but in this case that's good.Follow this guide - http://steamcommunity.com/app/22370/discussions/0/828937546147175081/

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
TL;DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Fallout 3 is a first / third-person action role playing game that was made and published by Bethesda Studios in 2008.It is the third major sequel to the popular Fallout franchise featuring a whole new gameplay mechanic because, unlike its predecessors, it uses the first person / third-person type of gameplay reminiscent of the TES (The Elder Scrolls) series.PLOT (No Spoilers):The player takes on the role of a vault dweller in Vault 101. After his father leaves the vault for unknown reasons, the player escapes in search of him and discover the truth about the true purpose of the Vaults.As he steps out into the wasteland, he discovers that the world was not as dangerous as the other vault dwellers were made to believe. Sure it was still a sh** hole filled with dangerous monsters, raiders, fanatics, and mutants but it was not, as irradiated and inhospitable as he thought it was. This world was fully capable of supporting human life.Explore the so-called “Capital Wasteland” in search of your father and discover the wonders and the horrors that the nuclear apocalypse has brought.PROS:+ Good graphics for its time (8 years old at the time of this review);+ Vast open world with a lot of places to explore;+ Good story however...(see CON #1);+ Immersive and atmospheric game world;+ Easily moddable;+ Good adoption of the TES game mechanics;+ Solid gameplay;+ Massive amounts of side quests;+ Massive amounts of items to collect;+ Crafting mechanics;+ Good music, sound effects and voice acting;+ Lengthy game time;+ Cheap in price;+ Good DLC selection; and+ High replayability.CONS:- Very poor ending (not applicable if you have bought and installed the DLC 'Broken Steel' or the 'Game of the Year Edition' of the game);- Compatibility issues with later versions of Windows (7 and above); Fix- Compatibility issues with later CPUs (quad-core above); Fix- Low resolution textures even on high settings;- Poor level scaling for enemies which may turn the game boring after max level;- Poor enemy and companion AI;- Occasional physics glitches; and- No iron sights feature for the weapons.NEUTRAL:+/- Excellent radio music but limited in selection;+/- Game's difficulty is not that challenging, even on the highest difficulty;CONCLUSION:EXCELLENT GAME and a wonderful addition to the Fallout franchise. Fallout 3 delivers a wonderful RPG and first person experience that proves once and for all that solid game play mechanics and world building can stand the test of time.WORTH IT?Fallout 3 has a 'Game of the Year Edition' (GOTY) which costs $19.99 (or your regional equivalent) which is well worth the price. If you see it on a sale, then you may want to consider it as part of your RPG game collection.FINAL NOTES:The GOTY edition includes all the DLCs.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Decided to play the game with my spouse as my character, spawned into the Vault, and grew up.  I watched the place fall apart, fled, and found myself in a vast wasteland.  Ended up in a shack inhabited by a junkie with nothing but a BB gun to defend myself (my spouse) against the horrors of the wasteland.  Tried to take a gun that was laying around, not realizing that "red" meant "stealing."  The junkie started punching me, but she was so weak that I was able to shoot her to death with her own gun before she killed me.  Decided then that I was not a good person, killed and stole anything and everything in the wasteland...  until the slavers.  I found honest to god human slavery in the wasteland, was offered caps by the slavers to track down runaway slaves because of my hardass reputation.  I heard the slaves, humans in cages, pleading. It sunk in, my spouse would never stand for this.   It took nearly every chemical and every bullet I had on me, but I killed every slaver in that settlement and freed every slave that wasn't too scared to run once the shackles were loosed.  Discovering you're willing to shoot/beat a junkie to death to survive is not a quest, nor is destroying a hub of human slavery, but when you wander around the wasteland, you find our own quests woven between the echoes of the person you were and the person you are becoming.

content:
Posted: April 5
												First of all, I've played Fallout 3 on Windows 7 from the start, and I'm playing it now with Windows 10 without any big issues. Sure, I've seen a crush or two... actually, maybe around of 5-6 crushes for all the time I've played the game (and it's more than 200 hours and about 8 years now). But, I've seen much worse from other, "fully Win 10 compatible" titles. Maybe I'm just lucky? Well, I have 3 PCs, and all of them are playing Fallout 3 just fine. Screenshots aren't working, though, and Windows keep sending me troubling messages every time I start the game... But that's not so bad, I think. Obviously, you can live without my screenshots. And most probably, you can run the game on your PC as well.What troubles me from the technical side - is not Bethesda, but the very Steam itself. For I've bought the GOTY version right here on Steam store, but for some reasons, it thinks what I didn't accomplished that. So I can click "add to cart" button, and only after that Steam will recognize the fact I already own the game. But if I'll start any search through Steam store, again, it will be thinking that I'm still not owning the game. So far, Steam can't fix that problem, and that's really annoying, especially when it tries to promote me the same stuff again and again.Finally, to the game itself! In the part of texts, speeches, quests, characters motivation and overall complexity - among all other things I cherish role-play games for - Fallout 3 isn't good enough. It's even quite bad at many moments actually... but with that, some moments are simply unforgettable, must-see things. Like the character generation and intro story, as an obvious example.Next, I'm quite unhappy with GUI - and especially with Pipboy and inventory management. It's even worse than in the vanilla Skyrim. With all that stuff you need to carry just to be able fix your gun and armor in the field. And with irritating encumbrance system in comparison with the amount of useful stuff, spreaded across "Wastes"... It feels even worse than in the Diablo-like games, where you fight, loot, then sell the loot, and repeat the process. In such "action-RPGs" it is common now to have a companion which will be doing the trading part. But in the Fallout 3 universe, you'll be looting and walking overburdened across the wilderness way more often than doing something actually interesting, like solving quests and so on. And that's the burden of the most part of modern games with open world. There are much more uninspiring "flags gathering" than actual challenging adventuring stuff.On the other side of coin, with such big wastes, and the gross amounts of various interactive objects... Game designers made the whole game full of various eastern eggs and curious setouts all over the map. And that was really fun, exploring the wastes and discovering such installations.In the end, Fallout 3 is one of those "take good with bad" type of games. Where I don't like the storyline, the fighting part, the inventory, endless process of collecting stuff and gathering it at some storage.... And, with all that, turns out what I like some parts of the story (and some sidequests as well). I can even role-play and actually empathize with the protagonist - which is always very important. I like the feeling of the big and non-linear adventure, where I can really do quite alot, see many things... it would be quite clear to say that, while many things which made Faloot 1&2 legendary, were discarded by Bethesda... The size of what was done, is really helping the game to stay at the "enjoyable" zone. It is not a good successor of Fallout 2, but, it is still a game from Fallout universe. Just closer to a basic action, than to RPG.So, my mark is 7/10. Worth some time through while being quite questionable at some gamedev decisions.

number of helpful: 44 of 52 people (85%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
Fallout 3 – Game of the Year Edition is a first-person open world post-apocalyptic RPG. After escaping from Vault 101, a subterranean nuclear fallout shelter you lived in all your life, you explore the post-nuclear war-torn wastelands of Washington DC while on the trace of your father's footsteps.Pros: 1st person perspective is a huge departure from the original Fallout games that add to the immersiveness. The game offers a very large world to explore, filled with bandits, super mutants, ghouls and radioactive creatures. I love the bottle caps as currency, although you're likely to mostly barter for ammos and equipment in exchange for the incredible amount of scraps and junk you can scavenge. There's a nice amount of guns to get your hands on, drugs (or chems) to give you boosts, and an assortment of food and medicine to keep your health up, most of which is irradiated which forces you to carefully manage your radiation poisoning. Quests are plentiful, and everywhere you go you'll have people asking for help in these hard times. The RPG elements consists of your basic attributes and trained skills, while leveling up allows you to train those skills and assign perk points to an increasing list of perk options, so that you may make your character just the way you want it. The VATS system allows you do precision targeting in fights, with VATS points just limited enough to avoid over use.Cons: The world design is not on par with modern post-apocalyptic setting: wastelands feel barren and empty, buildings look and feel repetitive, and the urban DC area is nothing but impassable walls of concrete rubble with only the occasional building you can actually get in. Graphics and character designs feel repetitive and didn't age well. Gameplay does include a third-person option, but it's basically the same as the first-person option except that you see your character's back. Getting started can discourage newcomers as the early game is much harder and players spend most of their time going back and forth carrying junk with their limited carrying capacity to barter for barely as much ammos as they spent getting their loot, assuming the few vendors even have any stock of ammos compatible with the guns you have.Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to youI'm threading lightly as not everyone will enjoy this game: it's not as lively as Fallout 4, not as deep as the Metro series, and doesn't have the personality of the Borderland series. If you're a classic Fallout fan looking for a modern take on the isometric cRPG style, you should probably be looking at Wasteland 2. Otherwise, this game and its DLCs will give you dozens upon dozens of hours of gameplay, so of course I recommend it!P.S.: Those experiencing compatibility issues can fix this through the use of Mods. Unfortunately, these are not supported by Steam and installing an external 3rd party Mod manager will prevent this game from running normally through Steam. If Star Wars | Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords can have Steam Workshop support added a decade after release, I see no reason or excuse for Bethesda not to do the same with their original take on the Fallout franchise.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: April 8
												This is BY FAR my favorite game of all time.  My time on Steam pale's in comparison to the amount hours I've spent on my old PS3.  Only game I've completed 100% on.This game works perfectly, just don't alt-tab.To get it to stop crashing on Windows 7 follow these steps:-Download Fallout 3-Do NOT have Fallout 3 running during the next steps-Click on the Windows button in the lower left hand corner of your screen and seach "FALLOUT" (all caps)-Under "Documents", there's a file called FALLOUT, open it in Notepad-Use CtrlF to search for the line "bUseThreadedAI"-It will be set equal to 0-Change "bUseThreadedAI=0" to "bUseThreadedAI=1"-Add the line "iNumHWThreads=2" right under "bUseThreadedAI=1"-Save the changes to the document FALLOUT-Close the document-Launch Fallout 3, and enjoyHope this helps someone out there.

Posted: October 20, 2014
****4 out of 5Expansive, awesome and beautiful. Fallout 3 is what RPGs aspire to. Featuring a long absence from the 90s classics Fallout 1 and 2, Bethesda Softworks brings back Fallout for a new generation. Awaking in an apocalyptic nightmare, your own hope to survive in this new world is to explore, upgrade and befriend or back-stab as many people as you can.Fallout 3 is a gorgeously realised game not only in its visuals, but the narrative, its atmosphere and the unremarkable but noticable human touches throughout.Fallout 3 is one to recommend, albeit you can find yourself wandering through a carbon copy of the same underground tunnel or factory at times, but that's nothing to greatly disservice such a great experience.

												Still an unoptimized relic that will be sold to a world that has long since left Microsoft Vista and Games For Windows Live in the trash bin of history. Fallout 3 is the quintessential Bethesda game which puts the burden of functionality directly onto the consumer to mod the game into some shape that doesn't crash as soon as combat begins, even if it’s altering one line of code in the ini file. The qualities of game mechanics and story are nothing without the ability to run on a machine and operating system built after 2008. When GOG and Lucasarts/Disney patch the likes of KOTOR 2 or older games into something that can easily run decades after their initial release, Betheda should be able to hire coders to take out GWFL with their Fallout Shelter war chest alone.

												Bethesda should've patched this version better on Win7 or Win8.It IS a classic and has made so many revenue so you!!!Down vote until a better patch is out.------------------For now, you have to do the following thing from the link:http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/20371/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nexusmods.com%2Ffallout3%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D20371&pUp=1------------------Making Fallout 3 work on Windows 7 & 8Getting Fallout 3 to run on win 7 and 8Step 1: Copy the D3D9.dll from the “Source Files” Folder into the main Fallout 3 Directory (Not the Data directory)Step 2: Right click on the “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” and go to properties.Step 3: For both “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” right click and go to properties and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP (Service Pack 3)MAKE SURE THAT FALLOUT 3 IS NOT OPEN FOR THE NEXT STEPSFallout 3 Config File EditingBefore you try below copy the “Fallout_Default.ini“ file included in the “Source FIles” Folder and place it into your Fallout Directory (NOT THE DATA ONE)Manually Editing the config file if the above doesn't work.Step 1: Open up the Configuration file in Notepad in the fallout 3 directory, (Which should be named "Fallout_default") press Ctrl+F and find the following line of text. NOTE: THIS IS CASE SENSITIVEbUseThreadedAI=0You must change this to:bUseThreadedAI=1Step 3: Directly underneath the changed line of text, create a new line and type:iNumHWThreads=2Step 4: Save the config file and then close. Then try to launch Fallout 3.These steps are basically telling the game to launch using just 2 cores. This way it will make sure that the game will not freeze due to errors trying to find 'outdated' cores.This fix will usually solve your problems, however if this has not worked and the game is still crashing then try these additional steps:-Uninstall Fallout 3, disable .NET 3.1 under 'Turn windows features On or Off', then reinstall.-Renaming or deleting the music folder inside the Fallout 3 folder apparently helps as well somehow?Now it should work GOT FOSE get it to run on win 7 & 8 hereStep 1: Right click and go to properties. Then go to compatibility mode and set it to windows XP (Service Pack 3) and check “Run as Administrator”

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas?I see a lot of people asking about if they should play Fallout 3 first, or Fallout: New Vegas. I went through this dillemma myself. I chose to buy Fallout: New Vegas.Let me first give you a brief summary about the two games:Fallout 3: You are a vault dweller. Your father has left the vault for an unknown reason. You go after him and enter the Capital Wasteland. You're main goal is to find your father again.Fallout: New Vegas: You are a courier who had to deliver a package, but in the middle of your journey you were shot in the head by a member of the Chairmen (one of the families of the Strip). You wake up after being healed by an old man and you track him down. There is also a war going on in the Mojave Wasteland between the NCR, the New California Republic which is a faction that works with laws and such as they did before the bombs fell, and Caesers Legion, a faction based upon the old Romian Empire which is build upon slaves.There are two major differences in the two games.Fallout 3 is build upon the idea that you are fresh out of the vault. In the game, everything is new to you ánd your character.Fallout: New Vegas is not really build upon this idea. You were shot in the head and you start your journey from a little farmers town.Fallout 3 has an interesting storyline which I really enjoyed. It feels more personal then in New Vegas.Fallout: New Vegas has a lot (and I mean a lot) of choices. The game is bigger than Fallout 3, because it has more quests.I chose New Vegas because I wanted to have a lot of things to do in the game. But I now regret this decission. I think you should buy Fallout 3 first, it's a great beginning for Fallout games in general if you have never played one. You get all the basics early on in the game and your goal is pretty clear. If you already played Fallout 4, then I'd recommend you to buy Fallout: New Vegas.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
ROBCO INDUSTRIES UNIFIED OPERATING SYSTEMCOPYRIGHT 2075 – 2077 ROBCO INDUSTRIESSERVER 69 Welcome to this short Fallout 3 review_____________________________________In February 2015, I decided to start a new Fallout 3 play through. My goal was clear: Doing Everything!That means talking to all the NPCs, visiting all the landmarks, every little shed, cave, settlement and unmarked point of interest; doing every quest, obtaining every unique weapon, collecting most of the pre-war books and sugar bombs, and acquiring so many bottle caps that I could safely say that I could start my own soda manufacturing company!The apocalyptic open world of Fallout 3 offers the player a great atmosphere. The music is well suited in terms of capturing the essence of this devastated world, where everything is reduced to mere antiquated forms of junk and scrap. I am always amazed by how great the mapmakers at Bethesda recreated the ruins of D.C. There is even a whole metro system underneath the city, waiting for someone to explore it. The map is pretty cool, you can’t argue with that. So take your time and explore every square inch of it – you won’t regret it. Since I knew this was going to be my last playthrough for the next couple of years, I meant to do it in style! So I went ahead and spent countless hours of tweaking and installing mods to shape the game to my liking. The outcome was rather impressive, especially since I am not easy to please!I had a blast! It took me 200 hours (18 months of playing) to finish the game (including expansions). I could go on and on and explain what kind of character I played (he was neither good or bad by the way) and what decisions I made, but this is a review after all, right? So let’s get to it.The apocalyptic open world of Fallout 3 offers the player a great atmosphere. The music is well suited in terms of capturing the essence of this devastated world, where everything is reduced to mere antiquated forms of junk and scrap. I am always amazed by how great the mapmakers at Bethesda recreated the ruins of D.C. There is even a whole metro system underneath the city, waiting for someone to explore it. The map is pretty cool, you can’t argue with that. So take your time and explore every square inch of it – you won’t regret it.What is not so great, on the other hand, are the graphics. They were outdated even back in 2008, when the game was released. Bad textures, bad lighting and this green filter that was put over everything – Gross! Luckily, there are tons of mods that aim to fix what Bethesda missed, and if done right, the game can look absolutely stunning.


Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: WOOKIENATOR




 I would also like to make an observation on the combat system: While I don’t think it’s bad, it offers much space for improvement.BUT: Fallout 3 is not primarily a shooter, but a RPG with shooter elements - and it does a pretty good job at this. In my case, it was easy to stay in character throughout the whole game (unlike in Skyrim (in my personal opinion)). And I am not talking about the way I killed people, rather, it refers more to about how I approached situations, and how I resolved them. In many cases, the game offers the player a wide spectrum of possibilities - Some of them are hidden (that’s why I had the Wiki close to me). Fallout New Vegas did this whole RPG thing even better. 


Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: WOOKIENATOR




Remember when companies still sold expansions or add-ons instead of just DLCs? (I am looking at you, horse armor). Fallout 3 got some really good expansions, though they are not all great. Mothership Zeta is the worst of those add-ons in my opinion - You are basically trapped on an alien ship with only few characters to interact with, no interesting loot and no story or other assets. Also, you seem to simply be walking from room to room, through endless corridors, hoping for it to end after the one before.The best thing you can get in this add-on (referenced above), is the pretty cool (and not so lore friendly!) Samurai armor you can obtain by killing one of the few NPCs you meet on the ship. *Sigh* Operation: Anchorage (another add-on) is almost as bad as Mothership Zeta, but you get some pretty good loot at the end (nice for stealthy characters). It also offers a little bit more depth by putting you in the role of a soldiers of the U.S. Army during the 2070s. So lore-wise, this add-on is not a complete waste.Broken Steel is pretty good, since it simply expands the quite vanilla Fallout 3 story in a good way.Point Lookout and The Pitt are pretty amazing. Both add a new map for you to explore, with a main quest, side quests, new weapons, enemies, loot and characters. My personal favorite though is The Pitt, because of the dark atmosphere and the possibilities for the more, shall we say, evil characters.


New Laser Rifle re-texture. 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: WOOKIENATOR




 I could say so much more about this game, but I am lazy - so I will just say that I love this game and recommend it to anyone who is looking for a decent RPG with a great atmosphere; And if that’s not enough you can always enhance your experience (and you should do that, because the Vanilla version of Fallout 3 is rather, well, “meh”) with many awesome mods.Thank you for reading my humble review, and, if you need help with identifying the mods from my screenshots you can contact me via Steam. Comment on this review and I will add you as soon as possible. Have a nice day!

												See people posting poor votes because the game is unstable on windows 7 and later. When did this game come out now, 2008? That's almost 10 years ago. You people whine too much. Don't see anyone complaining that dos games aren't playing on windows 10. This game has long since finished it's active duty and is at the point you have to put a little bit of work into making it run. Also if you spent a moment googling isntead of complaining, you would have known that a quick google search reveals a solution in the top 3 results. This solved my rapid random crashes right up. The issue is due to the game engine not liking CPUs with more than two cores as it seems. To everyone complaining, guess what, in order to play System Shock 2, you have to literally disable all but one processor core for the running game instance, otherwise the game crashes. SOLUTION: Find and open (backup first!) the fallout.ini file in "My Documents\My Games\Fallout3"FindbUseThreadedAI=0change it tobUseThreadedAI=1Add this line after itiNumHWThreads=2

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Great game, great characters. However there are a few flaws.The first one is it's legendary instability under Windows 7 or later. Depending on your setup, the game can be anywhere between unplayable and crashing at the title screen to playable, but with scrambled music due to the Directsound kerfuffle. Heck, even though the game is playable under Vista the soundtrack is scrambled albeit still fixable if you're willing to go out and buy a Creative gaming sound card if just to use ALchemy to fix the soundtrack. The biggest issue is that Bethesda is not willing to fix the bugs even though there is a huge fanbase, and is even working against the fans by issuing takedowns at unofficial patches to fix the issues. That's right, the developer doesn't want fans to play the game with proper music. Secondly, the game uses the problematic Games for Windows Live framework for a lot of things, including copy protection. Microsoft recently announced that they're shutting down GFWL. Guess what this means for the game. Sure, again there are fanmade patches to work around this, but well, it shows Bethesda's mindset.In short, unless you're willing to go the full mile securing a decent Windows XP machine and then get your hands dirty with unofficial patches, don't buy this. If you absolutely must, get one of the console versions instead, PC gaming master race be damned. Don't get me wrong- It's a great game, and I support both consoles and PCs equally, but the PC version of this game is just not worth it and I'm not happy with the way Bethesda is treating the PC players of this game.EDIT: Just bought a new laptop and upgraded it to Windows 10. Won't run, period. The game installs, the Launcher comes up (along with a stern warning from Windows saying that this game won't run), and... nothing. Clicking on Play results in nothing happening. Additionally, the game's installation of Games for Windows Live bricked the laptop's internet connection until said item is uninstalled. It has went from bad to worse. I definitey don't recommend it now. It's a great game, but it's coding is so bad it's not even forwards compatible with newer versions of Windows.

number of helpful: 16 of 16 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I'd like to start this review by saying that Fallout 3 is an absolutely magnificent beast of a game and that it will remain one of my most beloved games for ETERNITY. I first played the base game, without any DLC, and I'm very glad I did. This is primarily because even without any DLC, there are a plethora of locations to discover and explore, so many quests to do and plenty of people to help or hinder (or shoot in the face and rob). This review might be a bit long, but it is one of the few games I can play again and again, time after time, and still become 100% immersed in, so bear with me ;)Some spoilers may lurk below, be warned!First off, Fallout 3 is a single-player, post-apocalyptic game set in a post-nuclear American wasteland. As I touched upon earlier, the game world is gigantic, maybe even dauntingly so. I'm the type of gamer who has to discover everything, so for me this was a massive plus in the game's favour. This wanderlust is helped and even encouraged by a compass at the top of the screen, highlighting discovered and undiscovered locations. Once you're out into the wasteland proper, you're not really limited in where you can go, either. The amount of freedom this game gives you is refreshing and liberating, though be careful where you wander! As I found out, the answer to 'What's that thing over there running at high speed towards me?' is not 'let's go have a look', but instead 'it's a bloody great Deathclaw, and it's now chewing my face off, cheers wanderlust!'Another point in F3's favour is that players can play in a way which suits them. Want to be a lovely guardian angel who wanders the wasteland helping others and destroying evil? Or would you be a horrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that goes round pistol whipping people in the face? Do whatever you want, there's a variety of options you can take regarding playstyle. Also, while the range of options for offense/weaponry isn't as massive as some other games, there's still a very wide selection. Weapons can also be built once you've found the relevant schematics, some of which, without spoiling them, are very fun to play with. You can also experiment with different types of armour, or walk round in your pants, it's up to you really. The skills and perks systems allow you to choose whatever path you want, whether that involves big guns or slapping people about with melee weapons.DLC aside, I was surprised at the relatively short length of the main questline in F3. For players who prefer to concentrate on the primary story arc, you may find the game ending somewhat prematurely. The full potential of this game really is unlocked when you take all of the side quests and exploring into account. The world is there to explore and it adds so, so much to the game. Some of the missions are downright crazy, while some locations are inherently creepy - I'm looking at you, creepy haunted place and acid-trip-gone-wrong Vault - and despite the length of the main arc, it is still an engaging storyline. I also found this game to be very immersive, especially when wearing headphones. You also have access to a radio through your Pip Boy device, and it's an oddly enjoyable experience wandering the wasteland listening to 'Jingle Jangle Jingle'.The game is not without it's downsides however (though sometimes even they result in some classic moments). F3 will sometimes glitch out, and sometimes, it will glitch out spectacularly. The game incorporates a follower system, whereby some of the NPCs you meet in the game will agree to come and help you out, fighting monsters with you and the like; now I was wandering around with one of these followers and we happened to be walking next to those metal roadside barriers. I jumped over and ran on a little ways and turned round to make sure no beasties had snuck up on me, only to see my follower doing what appeared to be the Hokey Cokey dance on the barrier; before I could fully process this he was slingshotted into upper orbit, disappearing into the sky like a big green blob. It was okay though, he dithered out of the ether again about 10 minutes later, just in time to stop me getting done in by one of the wasteland's hostile denizens.You may also find yourself randomly taking damage for no reason other than you trod on some clutter. Certain places in F3 are  immensely cluttered, meaning you will also at times be flung across a room as plungers apparently have a secondary function as trebuchets. When you're trying to sneak down a tunnel and not get your face shot off, suddenly treading on a cup and getting thrown into your assailants arms isn't much help. Also, if you've just left a crazy fight, uber low on health, and a wayward plate decides it hates your soul, you better prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥because it's probably going to do you in if you stand on it in the wrong way.While the ability to play this game however you want is a massive bonus, it also has its pitfalls. You can pretty much kill any NPC you find, and this can, at times, irrevocably screw up your game. F3 also has several console commands that you might use to help you out, such as using them to unlock a pesky door you keep failing to lockpick. Some of these commands can also screw the game up, so it pays to be mindful of what you're hammering into the console if that's something you enjoy exploring in a game.Overall, I found Fallout 3 to be a wonderful game. It looks fantastic, and the post apocalyptic setting is rendered beautifully. The developers did a wonderful job here, and my only regret is that I didn't play it sooner. It also has so much replayability, you can come back to it again and again and make different choices, choose a different path. While it has its downsides, F3 makes up for them with an engaging world full of interesting characters and factions. It also helps that a lot of the bugs are hilarious and often don't have a massive impact on gameplay (I, for one, don't mind vanquished Mirelurks pinwheeling off into the sky). I do however think to get the full benefit of what this game has to offer, you have to pursue the side quests and get your explorer hat on. I also think that while I've reviewed the base game in general, the DLC adds a massive amount to the game and are well worth the money.

												Before I get hate let me say, I do love this game, I have always loved fallout games since the very First.But, very sadly. content:
Posted: September 18, 2011
												Fallout 3 suffers a tad from having to follow up the original Black Isle titles since it's not the same kind of RPG but it is a good game. Exploration is rather enjoyable since there are goodies littered all over the wasteland and in this respect it reminds of of Morrowind (which is only natural of course). It's an enjoyable game even if your FPS skills are minimal due to the auto targetting VATS system and all in all its worthy to be experienced by any fan of the adventure, fps, and rpg genres. The game has so much replay value and that's before you start modding it so... definitely worth playing (though roleplaying an evil character isn't as well thought out as in the originals).

												Fallout 3 is by far the ultimate Wasteland survival game in the series so far. 3rd or 1st perspective in a land ravaged by nuclear war (pronounced nucular by war time leaders). Emerge from your vault and find your place amongst the barren landscape formerly known as the Capital of the USA.Seek and destroy your enemies that are now the mutated creatures of before, savage bandits of now, or the remnants of military corruption seeking future domination. Make choices and prepare to live (or die) with them.The future of the Wasteland is in your hands. 10/10

ENGLISH and Italian Review Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA                                                   War... war never changes.English:Don't trust my gametime, i've bought this game on Steam too, just for collection. This game literally ruined my life, i've finished it like 14 times before losing the count. No, i'm not crazy, yes, my social life imploded. And don't trust the grandpas that will tell you this game is garbage just because they played the first 2 Fallouts and refused to play this one, they are just ignorant. In this game you live a wonderful and touching adventure in first person (Identifying so with the character), watching the character growing and becoming the hero or anti-hero that he'll be. Oh yes, because obviously you can and have to choose between choices that will influence the events and your karma. So, we have an abnormus replay factor, if we consider that we can play as good, bad, neutrals or do a mixed playtrough, choosing maybe a different type of class for the fight. AND, the game is easily moddable and has a large and active modding community: Nexus Mods. So, even if you have finished it in every way possible, you can mod it and transform it in a new game to discover. Trust me, this game is AWESOME.                                             La guerra... la guerra non cambia mai.Italiano:Non fidatevi del tempo di gioco che dice Steam, l'ho comprato anche qui giusto per averlo. Questo gioco ha letteralmente rovinato la mia vita, lo avrò finito qualcosa come 14 volte prima di perdere il conto. No, non sono pazzo, si, la mia vita sociale ne ha risentito un pochino. E non fidatevi dei vecchiacci che vi diranno che questo titolo fa schifo, solo perché giocarono ai primi due ai tempi, e si rifiutarono di giocare questo, sono degli ignoranti. In questo gioco vivi un'avventura stupenda e toccante in prima persona (Immedesimandoti dunque nel personaggio), vedendo il personaggio crescere man mano e plasmandolo lentamente nell'eroe o antieroe che sarà. Eh si, perché ovviamente potrai e dovrai fare delle scelte che influenzeranno gli eventi ed il tuo karma. Abbiamo dunque anche un fattore rigiocabilità enorme se consideriamo che possiamo giocare da cattivi, da buoni, da neutri o fare un mix, scegliendo magari anche una tipologia di personaggio diversa per quanto riguarda i combattimenti. Senza contare il fatto che il gioco è facilmente moddabile e vanta di una community di modders vasta e attiva, ovvero Nexus Mods. Dunque anche avendolo finito in tutte le maniere possibili e immaginabili, potete ancora moddarlo all'infinito e renderlo un gioco nuovo tutto da riscoprire. Fidatevi, questo gioco è perfetto.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												You are now entering the wasteland of fallout. Please enjoy your stay and make sure not to stick your hands out of the trolley. We do not like mutants.As you see to your left these manhunters are the natural enemies of all living things they are called the death claws , they are quite deadly and remember to use VATS to target and aim for their vulnerable spots. VATS for you who have forgotten is a system that stops gameplay… I mean time and allows you to target enemy weak points and resume time with a touch of the button. This allows us to survive better but remember you have a limit to how much you can use it before it runs out. Which is why you should buy our nuka-cola energy drinks for a special price of 5 caps!Now proceeding near  the city of NPC"s... I mean homeless people. You will see that while the conversations with them can be dynamic with many ways to approach them and handle a situation. They tend to not be that expressive. Don't mind that though its just them being shy. Remember that how you develop yourself as a human being will change how you can approach these guys and other situations on your travels.Don’t worry though if you collect a bobblehead I’m sure it could make up for your lack of intelligence or anything else!Now put on your toxic suits thats under your seats we are heading into the toxic tunnel infested with ugly... i mean disfigured mutated humans. They are victims of the after-matches of the war and tend can be hostile towards you. Its important to note that you can choose to align yourself with one faction or another to win them over. Which tends not to be as complex as new vegas as a result of relying on equipment for doing this.Don’t worry while we don’t have casinos that are grand like New Vegas every day is a huge gamble to live or die so remember you can skip hours of a day if need be by sleeping.Up next is the ship of dreams, where scientists come together to figure out the future. Rumors have it that the main reason to come here is the research on clean water systems. The scientists are trying to find to make the water clear and drinkable for all. The incoming tour of an alien spaceship is brought to you by Unknown Inc. Where even the employees don't know each other. The DLC… I mean discoveries located casually during this tour.. are well worth your wait and price of admission. We have discovered that the environments are completely different and well thought out layouts are quite nice especially seeing new friendly face…Remember folks how you develop yourself as a human being is what this game.. I mean place is about and I highly recommend paying to move into one of these broke down… I mean luxurious homes.

												What can one say about one of the greatest games ever made? It's hard to put into words just how much I love the Fallout franchise and how much I adore this game. Bethesda have done a wonderful job with Fallout 3, bringing Adamowicz's amazing illustrations to life, sparing no detail. There are hundreds of NPC's who either want to talk to you or put your head on a platter, not to mention there are countless missions and some random encounters that will stay with you for the rest of your life.The Capital Wasteland can be a dark and depressing place; yet it's the little settlements and unique characters you come across on your travels, that make everything you work toward worthwhile.
