content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												I've tagged Fallout 3 as one of my top games in my Steam account. I've actually put way more hours into it than my Steam account shows (see note below), and it's one of my favourite games of all time.I love the post apocalyptic setting - this game really pulls it off. But unlike some of the other Bethesda games such as Skyrim (which I also love!) this one has a really engaging landscape. There is stuff to check out everywhere! I get so sidetracked when doing quests because there's always something that catches my eye and I think "oooh what's that?" and I go check it out. There's so much to do!In the most part the quests are really good, but I admit I was getting a little bit annoyed near the beginning of the main quest with the constant "looking for Dad". One thing that is great about FO3 is the very satisfying weapons. Some shooters can be a little weak, and RPGs are usually weaker still with the FPS elements but I found FO3 to be very solid. Yeah the AI is not brilliant but the weapons themselves feel very good. I particularly love taking somebody's head off from half a mile away with a sniper rifle :-)Also, you can't really talk about a Bethesda game without discussing mods! I'm a big modding fan and I never play these games vanilla for very long. I used FWE, MMM & EVE along with several mods that added new perks and a mod that allowed you to level up more slowly but get several perks per level which I really liked.Overall, it's a fantastic game and I'm really looking forward to playing New Vegas and then Fallout 4! (Yep, I'm seriously behind on my gaming!)Windows 7 Users Please Note:=====================When I first started playing the game it was around 2011 and I ran it on an Alienware Windows XP machine and it ran very well. Then I stopped playing for a few years and came back to the game later after I had moved into a Windows 7 machine.It crashed constantly, and when I saw constantly, I really mean it! After literally weeks of trying to get it to play properly on my 64 bit Win7 machine, trying every fix out there I gave up. However, I managed to get a pirated version of the game to work (doh!)So whilst I absolutely recommend the game to anyone who loves shooters, RPGs or post apocalyptic games, if you have a Windows 7 machine, don't get the Steam version. Try and find an old disc based copy instead.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												An unbelievable well made game, one of the best games ever made. The graphics, gameplay, plot, lore, music score, and art style are just astounding. Without dlc, this game is awesome. With the dlc, the game is utterly amazing. As someone who plays all games across multiple consoles and PC, Fallout 3 is easily in the top ten best games ever created. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of western style rpgs. Other games in the top 10 that I recommend(PC or Console): Mass Effect 2, BioShock, Legend of Zelda(Majora's Mask, Ocarina of Time, etc.), Civilization 5, Mario 64, Portal 2, Half-Life 2, Super Smash Bros Melee, Last of Us. Fallout 3 is a real treat of a game and if you haven't played this game yet you are sorely missing out. If you end up liking this game, I also recommend Fallout New Vegas. Not as good but still fun.

content:
Posted: March 9
												I remember getting Fallout 3 for Christmas years ago. I popped the disc in my console and... I wasn't feeling it. Probably because I was mostly playing FPS games (read: Call of Duty) at the time. I wasn't familiar with RPG's. But, at a certain point in time I decided to give Fallout another go. It's been one of my favourite games/franchises ever since. (Became a big Bethesda fan as well.)Spread across console and PC I have easily put a couple hundred hours into this game. It just doesn't get boring until there's absolutely nothing left to do. And believe me, that won't happen very quickly. There are many places to explore (at your own pace) and besides that, building up your character the way you envision it, is awesome.So, do I recommend this game? Absolutely.

number of helpful: 20 of 27 people (74%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												I don't know why but whenever I start playing FO3, I get bored of it after completing about 75% of the game and stop playing. I started a third new game 3 days ago and played about 23 hours in just three days but just got bored. I am guessing that this has something to do with:- Low citizen and human settlement count. Also some of these so called settlements only consist of 2-3-5 people (i.e. Girdershade).- Major settlements such as Megaton and Rivet City have no logical reason to be major settlements. Maybe Megaton stays alive thanks to travelling caravans and only two Brahmin located in the centre (even Arefu has three) but there is no explanation of how Rivet City can even survive.- Terrible gunplay, bullet sponge enemies such as Super Mutant Overlords, Feral Ghoul Reavers and Albino Radscorpions. For example a direct hit to a Super Mutant Overlord with a badass Fat Man will only take 33%-50% of its HP.- Downtown DC, the most interesting part of the game is just rubble (justifiable) and all travelling goes through dungeon like metro tunnels.- Quests are mostly forgettable and most of them are just glorified fetch quests. Some of the unmarked quests would make better quests if they were fleshed out.- Factions are not fully developed and more interesting minor factions like The Union or Republic of Dave can be fully explored and related quests can be completed very quickly, without any human interaction.Compared to New Vegas, where some major quests included very interesting and meaningful dialogues, a world that does not only revolve around you and combat being mostly an option and not as tiresome as FO3, Washington DC is just a post apocalyptic playground. Nevertheless FO3 can entertain a player for a long while even though you may not find yourself patient enough to complete it. If you want a real Fallout, a Fallout that continues the legacy of being a mature Post Postapocalyptic game, you can just skip this and get yourself over to Fallout: New Vegas.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
  Very good game,despite it's age  Fallout 3 is a very good post-apocalyptic action RPG game with a big open-world map filled with many locations to explore(221 with the DLCs,and 163 only in vanilla),a pretty interesting story which consists of 14 main quests,17 side quests,and another 38 unmarked quests(I recommend you doing the side quests because they're not related to the main ones and are very interesting).The game's time lenght is ~14 hours only for the main story and 100+ if you want to complete every quest in the game,the DLCs,and to explore every location.The game occasionally crashes on Windows 7,8,10 but you can reduce the chance by following  this guide .Below are the Pros and Cons of the game.  Pros   ------------------------  Big world with lots to do Very good post-apocalyptic atmosphere  Fun combat (both FPS and VATS) Many weapons to choose from Many perks and skills to level up (58 perks,79 with the ones from DLCs.And 13 skills) Highly moddable Each DLC takes place in a separate and unique map  Cons   ------------------------  Main story is kinda short Has fewer choices compared to other games in the series No iron sights (you can add them with mods) Occasionally crashes on Windows 7 and above (check the link above) Still has bugs (nothing game-breaking)Also,mini-reviews for the DLCs: Mothership Zeta I personally didn't like this one.It's way too linear,basically it was just running around,pressing buttons and killing aliens.The story was kinda boring and it doesn't even have side quests.But the ending is cool though.It's like 3 hours long. Point Lookout My personal favourite.It's a very good DLC with a beautiful setting and good story.It's open-world and has side-quests too.It's like 5-6 hours long if you do everything. Broken Steel It basically continues the game's main story.It's pretty interesting,has side-quests and free-roam and it takes place in the vanilla world except the last mission.It takes like 5 hours to beat everything in it.And also raises the level cap to 30 when installed. Operation: Anchorage It's a good linear DLC that takes place in a simulation.It's very short,like 2-3 hours. The Pitt Beautiful setting(yeah,I like post-apocalyptic settings) and nice story.It's ~4 hours long.Conclusion? It's well worth the full price and can't wait to play it again with different perks,builds,and quest choices. Note: This is my first ever review, so I'm sorry if I forgot to mention some important or necessary details.

												After finishing what i consider to be one of the most beautiful stories i have ever played, i can only say Wow... just wow!!!There are basically no words to describe, how awesome this game really is. Initially released in 2008 even after 6 years its far better than most post modern rpg game titles and that my dear fellow gamers says a lot!As i am writing this review down im trying to find any flaws that may pop into my head, but truth be told i cant find anything wrong with this title. Whether its the graphics, whether its the gameplay or the story itself Fallout 3 has everything in adundace and more. I myself am still shocked at the amounts of detail this game offers and the awesome vibe u get  when u follow the story of the nameless hero of vault 101 aka the "Lone Wanderer" as he roams the derelict wastelands of his nation's capital.A world filled with crazy wannabe mad max raiders, super mutants, aliens, fascist regimes, lone rangers, mutated animals and oc what every nuclear title requires Cockroaches. To help u fight all that as with every bethesda title u have to freedom to become everything u want and use every weapon at your disposal from pipe lines to future laser tech. And if u want to add a little bit of macho manliness u can be kenshiro from hokuto no ken series and fight all your way using only your hands in unarmed combat. And if u think thats not enough to keep u alive, thats why u have Liam Neeson as your papa to remind u how awesome u really are ^^.Fallout 3 game of the year edition is prolly one of the most awesome rpg titles to have been created this far. Personally i enjoyed it more than i did skyrim and truthfully i never expected this game to be so good. But it feels good to be proven wrong just this once.10/10 or 9/10 for those of u who will think the lack of any vehicle movement is enough to discourage you from trying this title!!!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												This game is a classic and, as I have already played the game when it was released with a physical disc copy, it would get a thumbs up from me under normal circumstances...BUTThe steam version, in it's current condition and if you're unlucky does not work as it should. There are crashes for just about every operation the game performs. If you google Fallout 3 crashes you will be treated to a cornucopia of nine or more fixes for reasons the game could crash. Do you have a processor with more than one core? Crash. Do you have a laptop with an integrated graphics card? Crash. Do you have autosave on? Crash. Do you have Windows newer than Vista? Crash. Did you forget to sacrifice to Cthulu before booting? Crash.This may not apply to you though, it seems some of these instances are more serious than others. I myself got the lucky draw of several of these risks, playing on a laptop running Win7 with an integrated graphics card and a quad core CPU.The only reason I didn't return the game after rebuying it digitally was that I got it to work somewhat after doing a convoluted set of tasks that may or may not have involved cthulu in some form of desperate plea for help.So after modding the game with a file that overrides the graphics options, fiddling with settings in both the launcher and ingame, setting compatability for WinXP and having to order the laptop to only use one cpu in task manager every time I load the game  (Because OF COURSE it resets every time you reboot the game) I got it to work, allthough it eventually crashed again and this time, having saved up it's spite for a good hour, it crashed so hard it froze my entire computer and I had to do a hard reset to make it work properly again.I do hope that I am wrong though, and that this was a case of the integrated graphics cards gremlins, which presents a much less all-engrossing scope. Fallout 3 is a legend in it's own right, a classic that everyone and anyone should be able to try out or re-visit.

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Fallout 3 isn't just a game, It's an experience.+ One big continuous open world. Loading screens appear only when entering major cities or buildings.+ Very atmospheric and immersive world to explore.+ Every NPC’s are really living in that world. They follow their own daily routine from morning to night. You’ll meet them, talk to them and even remember their names.+ Good writing and a touching story. It is fun to talk to NPC’s and trying out different dialogue options to see the outcome.+ Freedom in almost every aspect. A quest can be completed in many ways. You can almost kill anybody you meet (even an entire town). You can be a good guy, a bad guy or have a mix of both. You can play as an action game or you can play stealthily. You can choose to play in 1st person or 3rd person. You can roam anywhere you want but...+ Enemies don’t scale. So if you wander off to the wrong area during early levels, you will die easily.+ Many types of interesting enemies. Some are scary.+ Graphics.+ Voice acting.+ VATS+ Mods. A lot of them.+ Galaxy News Radio and...+ Three Dogs.+- Progression system and level cap (max level 30). The progression system is fun and addictive (with a lot of useful perks to choose) but I personally prefer Elder Scroll’s progression system where you get better at what you use. This way you can shape your preferred character with more flexibility and can even change your play style anytime. That’s why it is not a negative, it’s something that I have a mixed feeling.+- Dynamic day & night cycle. This game has day and night cycle but it is purely for cosmetic effect and doesn’t change or affect gameplay.- A.I’s are stupid sometimes, especially if you play stealthily. (Mods fix this)- Stealth gameplay could be better. Most area design doesn’t encourage stealth gameplay. No non-lethal option either. (Mods fix this)- Crafting options are very few. (Mods fix this) - No iron sight aiming in 1st person. (Mods fix this)OVERALL: Solid 10/10, best in the series.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Lots of people would have a couple hundred more hours if Bethesda would fix & optimize the game to work with Windows 7 & 8.Other than that tedious issue, it's an amazing game, especially with mods! Mods like GNR Enhanced, Point Lookout Reborn, Alton Il, Vault 101 Revisited, and more really spruce the game up.There's lots to do in the wasteland, such as...-Slavery! (Yes, really.)-Destroy an entire town!-Kill a mugger!-Shoot things!-Use V.A.T.S.!-Give water to people!-Explore!-Save/Reloading!-Modding!-Kill aliens! (Mothership Zeta)-Loot!-Steal things!-Be evil!-Be good!There's lots more to do, but let me get to the gameplay.It's an RPG, FPS, game. You are also given V.A.T.S., which lets you take a moment, and plan your shots out. You can cripple an enemy's legs, then deal with them, shotgun style, or just shoot their head, like everyone does. You can talk to many residents of the Wasteland. Some will be your companion, others will give you quests, and some prefer shooting first.Fallout 3 has quests. Main storyline quests, sidequests, and unmarked quests. Storyline and sidequests show up in your Pip-Boy 3000 under the Quests tab, while unmarked quests don't. Things like supplying people with Sugar Bombs (food), or Scrap Metal are unmarked quests.If you're a fan of shooters, and RPG's, this is a game for you.

number of helpful: 28 of 45 people (62%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												"Are you sure", he asked.I took a deep breath and started typing."Yes, I am. I know, I know, I have a huge backlog and I want you to buy me Game of The Year edition that will probably swallow hundreds of my hours that I don't have if I don't give up."Soon enough, Fallout 3 GOTY landed in my library.I consider myself to be a completionist, however, my work and habits prove I've become more of a collector. I was happy to get Fallout 1, Fallout 2 and Fallout Tactics on GOG for free when they were removing them from their library back in 2013. Then I've replayed Fallout 1 and started playing Fallout 2, creating character named after my daughter. I've stopped middle game and decided to return later (never did, but I will probably at some point). Same friend that got me Fallout 3 GOTY gifted me Fallout: New Vegas that I also didn't complete, but I've used to justify my laziness as 'my own plan to play the series in chronological order'. So of course, when I got GOTY, I was stuck and needed to deliver - at least to myself.Fallout 3 GOTY stands independent of the other titles in the series. It was Bethesda's revolutionary change of perspective. Instead of old isometric view, Bethesda went with first person, immersing playerbase even deeper in 50's inspired postapocalyptic nuclear wasteland. We went upclose and personal with mankind's ♥♥♥♥ed up end. To make a long story short and to avoid any spoilers, your main mission in F3 is to find your dad who left Vault 101. That requires exiting the Vault yourself for the first time in your life. Your first encounter with other humans and their pitiful destinies will probably happen in the city of Megatron from where your adventure will explode in every single direction possible. It is hard to describe Fallout 3 properly in short form. However, if we say we're having an unbeliveable, mature, choice-and-consequence heavy RPG title that sometimes intentionally goes silly and offers almost unlimited freedom along sidequests more complex and interesting than the main questline, we wouldn't go wrong.F3 GOTY comes packed with base game and additional DLC materials that will make you chase ghouls, mutants and raiders for tens and hundreds of hours, even in military virtual reality program. Its rich lore, interesting characters and unexpected plot twists here and there, along with the possibility to drive the game your way based on your choices is what makes it so appealing. It's hard not to enjoy sounds of rustling wind in the outskirt of devastated Washington DC. Letting go and losing yourself in loneliness of human misery never felt this good. Game fails a bit short in the shooting section. Hit detection is appearantly offset to simulate RPG system of risk and chance, luckily for us, F3 integrated V.A.T.S. queuing system that lets you hack the enemies to pieces, cripple their limbs and create some dramatic fighting scenes, all based on some sophisticated dice rolling.But, here comes the big but(t). It's silly to recommend Steam's version of Fallout 3 GOTY. Simply, it doesn't work.I was informed of several issues that Windows 7, 8 and 10 users were complaining about before I've decided to play the game. But how severe these problems are, I had no idea. My hours in the game were characterized by random crashes, sound and graphic problems and unbeliveable glitches. I've tried it all - vanilla play, unofficial and official patches, different and recommended high rated Nexus mods, uninstalls and reinstalls, LOOT launcher installation. Latest problem occured literally out of nowhere. After 3 hours of installing and reinstalling drivers from different sources and ultimately completely messing up my display settings without being able to run the game, I've decided to quit.I feel sad and angry. Fallout 3 is, in the end and as much as I've managed to play, a great, great, loveable game. However, Bethesda's ultimate and insolent refusal to patch this gem is the reason why you shouldn't get it. Chances you will end up with good game badly broken are pretty high and that's something not worth risking. There are no excuses for not fixing what can be fixed, especially when almost 20 years old original and sequel are running flawlessly on modern systems. ***Hey, you've liked this review? Hated it? It made you buy the game / abandon the idea of buying this game? Super awesome! Share the love and join the group here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews Follow the curator's page here: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10953338/

Fallout is love. Fallout is life.If you're like me and never played previous fallout games then you will be a bit confused when you play the game for the first time. But after about an hour into the game you simply can't stop playing. Okay so here is my story: i started playing this game right before Fallout 4 came out since i was too poor to afford FO4 at that moment so i watched a few reviews on YouTube and decided to play it. As i said if you're new to the franchise like me, you will be confuse about how some elements in the game work right off the bat but that dissapears shortly after 1h into the game. You are born and raised into a vault untill the age of 19 i think because of a nuclear blast and after some incidents you are bound to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of the vault. After that the fun begins. It's YOU vs THE WASTELAND.The fallout 3 world is so god damn massive that even with my 10 hours of gameplay i haven't come close to completing even 10% of the game. There is a main story and many many side quests that you can choose to do. They are all equally fun so i suggest doing them all, well, you don't really have a choise to be honest. you will be so addicted to the game that it will be hard for you NOT to go for all quests. You can choose how you want to play the game and every action you do effects the ending of the plot. There are many endings so prepare yourself to be either as good as possible or as evil as possible. 10/10 would recommend

												I guess I should write a review about the best RPG game I have ever played. Don't let my hours played fool you, I have played through the entire story and all DLC's on my playstation 3 a lot of times and still I haven't seen everything (EDIT: I am also playing with mods currently so all the time I have played in the last month and everything I will play won't be counted (as of 19-3-2016)).Which brings me to my first 'Pro' Pros:-A HUGE amount of content, it is insane how much there is to do in Fallout 3. The map is big, there are a lot of places to discover, people to talk to, quests to do, items to find, computers to hack, locks to pick and enemies to shoot. A vast assortment of mods add a lot to this already amazing game!-The story is good, its nothing special but it is good enough, the DLC's are also amazing and have their own stories!-DLC done right, this isn't some cash grab DLC game, the DLC's add new items, enemies, lore and more to the game!-Great atmosphere, the music is really good too!-Your choices matter, the dialogue system is great, although the characters you talk to are a bit 'lifeless'. Cons:-Stiff NPC's/unrealistic animations, When you talk to someone they stand still like they are a tree, the animations aren't very good either.-Graphics are very outdated, this isn't a con to me personnaly but it might throw some people off, ofcourse there are mods to make it look better!-Bugs and glitches, sometimes funny, sometimes game breaking.I recommend this game because I think it is amazing, video games are truly a form of art.Steel be with you!

number of helpful: 43 of 74 people (58%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Have you ever been a long-time fan of something, gotten really excited when you heard it was coming back, only to be massively disappointed with the result? Fallout 3 had this effect on many fans of the Fallout series, myself included. When developing Fallout 3, Bethesda only kept what was valuable to Fallout. Not “valuable” to the series and what made it so great, but valuable in terms of measurable monetary value. Fallout 3 is an attempt at bringing Fallout to the “modern gamer” and it’s one of the few things Bethesda did right.Right from leaving the Vault you can see that the game is very good looking with a nice aesthetic style, too bad it’s ruined by that horrendous green tint. Despite being pleasing to look at the game world is very badly designed. Locations are randomly placed and most of them bear little or no significance at all. On top of that, there is almost no variation in the caves, buildings or those damned metro tunnels. Once you been through one, you’ve been through them all. And to make matters even worse, exploration in the game in more chore than challenge as enemy levels are scaled with the player, meaning as long as you’re decently equipped and not caught off guard, you’ll breeze right through anything.Gameplay is familiar; it plays as if it’s “The Elder Scrolls IV.5: Fallout”. Bows replaced by guns, skills reworked, etc. On the surface it’s not really a bad thing, combat is more complex than TES but (much) less so than previous Fallouts. Your weapon skill determines your accuracy and damage dealt (this also applies to guns, even though that’s not how guns work) and your number of Hit Points is derived by your Endurance. Skills have been reworked so that “Tagging” a skill only increased its base by 15 points, no longer increasing the rate the skill increases during point distribution on level ups. Also, perks are now gained upon every level up as opposed to every third. Meaning by the time you reach the default cap of level 20, you’ll be nigh unstoppable. Attributes (Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck) have been almost completely trivialized, doing little outside of increasing the base number for your skills. And the availability of the perk “Intense Training” only further trivialises the allocation of attribute points. Unfortunately even 5 years post release, the game is still full of potentially game breaking bugs, even after being blatantly dumbed down for the 360 and PS3. And the PC version isn’t much better either, unless you’re running Window Vista then get used to reading “fallout3.exe has stopped working” every hour or so. The original Fallout sent you on a quest to find a replacement controller chip for your vault’s water purifier and Fallout 2 had you finding a Garden of Eden Creation kit to save your tribal village from a severe drought. Both are for the benefit of many, where Fallout 3’s main quest is personal. Leave the vault and find your father. Having a personal goal in a Fallout game was a strange choice. In the first two games you end up having a great impact on the rest of the wasteland, eradicating the Super Mutant threat or the Enclave in Fallout and Fallout 2 respectively. Fallout 3 main quest ends up being a lazy compilation of all these objectives from the previous games and seems pointless. Why are we competing against the Enclave when A: The Enclave was destroyed in Fallout 2 and B: They want the exact same thing we want. So why not team up? It’s certainly not for control of the area, because people seem to be doing fine without a source of pure water. The illusion of player choice exists but you have almost no influence on the story or game world with your decisions. The Evil path doesn’t seem like it is there for players who want to commit to being evil, but there for players who just want to murder people for the fun of it. An example of this wasted potential is in an early side quest, where you can either blow up a town for two obnoxiously stupid characters for reasons which are cryptically arbitrary, or you can save the down by defusing the bomb the town is for some reason based around. Blowing up the town nets you destroying one of the game’s main hubs for nothing more than a cool looking explosion.You’ll find through your travels that there is a strangely limited number of NPCs/town in most of cases, a couple generic citizens with a handful of named characters. How the player can interact with the NPCs is even more limited. Dialogue has been seriously dumbed down since Fallout 2, both in terms of writing quality and sheer number of choices of what to say. Speaking of writing quality, you can’t expect me to believe that “You can’t be President. You’re an abortion of science. You need to die…” (one of the game’s skill check dialogue options) is something that a scientific mind would say, can you Emil Pagliarulo? The delivery of dialogue is just as bad. The number of voice actors is extremely small all sound uninspired, even celebrity Liam Nesson’s performance is off on a few of his lines. Bad writing, bad delivery along with bad facial animation makes NPC interaction nothing to look forward to, at least most of them have very little to say.It’s obvious that Bethesda aren’t familiar with the Fallout universe as there are many inconsistencies to be found in Fallout 3, both with lore and its own story. Most obvious is the changes to the Brotherhood of Steel. Because of Bethesda’s apparent inability to creatively and skilfully write opposing factions with unique and believable motives, they wrote the Brotherhood of Steel to be the goody-two-shoes of the game, as opposed to them being the xenophobic tech-nuts they once were. This is explained in-game as the Elder of the BoS chapter exploring the east suddenly deciding to abandon the Brotherhood’s primary goal of recovering advanced technology to do nothing but help old ladies across the street. This “explanation” was clearly an afterthought used so that the BoS could be in the game for brand recognition. The Garden of Eden Creation Kit was just a mere collection of seeds and horticulture tips in Fallout 2, but in Fallout 3 it’s completely rewritten as some kind of magical life-bringing device to save the wastes from radiation for no reason other than it suited Bethesda’s writing. It seems that rather tell their story in the Fallout world Bethesda shaped the Fallout world around their story, which makes very little sense in of itself.The game’s atmosphere is good as a standalone, but as a Fallout title it’s completely off. Bethesda did a great job of capturing the mood of Fallout but not its atmosphere. All this assuming you’ve turned the OST off of course. For some reason Bethesda chose to abandon the atmospheric music of the first two games in favour of the action movie soundtrack that assaults your ears. Which gives player the only difficult choice of the game: Do I listen to this travesty of an OST? Or do I listen to THREEEEEEEEEE DAAAAAAAAWWWG, the most out of place character in the game.If you’re looking for a fun shoot and loot game with lots to explore then this is the game for you. If you’re looking for an RPG experience with complex characters and depth in the gameplay then you’re better off looking elsewhere. It succeeded as a way of bringing a loved series to a new generation of gamers, but it alienated lots of fans of the original games.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Broke game in two minutes by closing the gate on the playpen before dad could get out trapping him forever. 10/10I have only eleven minutes logged on steam. However I played this extensively up until the release of NV and beyond then too on my 360. I use FSE so the time doesn't get logged on steam as it removes the overlay. So my total playtime is over 1000 hours I expect. This is a post-apocalyptic masterpiece. I played it for countless hours discovering every solitary bobblehead, nuka cola quantum and all 5 behemoths. I bought the DLC on release out of a desire for more of this post apocalyptic adventure. *spoilers*I left the vault in search of a father who left me feeling betrayed. I found him only to have him taken again so soon. I killed Colonel Autumn as vengeance for my father. I came back from the dead to continue my fathers dream and the war against the Enclave, I became a member of the Lyons Pride and the Brotherhood of Steel to cram a power armoured fist down their throats in an effort to rid their evil from the capital wasteland. Then I settled down in my Megaton home, and life was good.*spoilers over*Then I started all over again. This time as a knife weilding pyromaniac, then again, as a tech expert with a knack for explosives and lasers. I kept playing this game over and over, because while the story wasn't NYT bestseller material, it engaged me. The world was interesting with interesting people such as a benign super mutant and old lady hoping for a violin and a man seeking freedom for his band of former slaves and the smart mouthed little p12!ck who lead a town of children. The game looked good to me with its blasted landscapes and shiny monochrome vaults and misplaced tower rising in the south, broken D.C landmarks and its mushroom clouds which conjured a sense of horror as you realise just how much devestation the power of the atom can bring. This game is one of my all time favourites. Sure it has bugs and glitches. Sure the graphics and gameplay are dated but this is still a damn good game. A lot of the old time FO 1&2 diehards hated this. And that is ok. Because sometimes the old games just feel right and this dramatic a change can turn some off. I never played the originals. I tried, but they are too dated for me and I wish I could get into them, but hey.  If, somehow, you don't own this game. I beseech you, get it now and know the cell mutating joy that I did the first time I explored the capital wasteland and became the lone wanderer.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Fallout 3 is an action role-playing open world video game developed by Bethesda Game Studios, and is the third major installment in the Fallout series. It was released worldwide in October 2008 for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360.Fallout 3 takes place in the year 2277, 116 years after the setting of Fallout, 36 years after the setting of Fallout 2 and 200 years after the nuclear apocalypse that devastated the game's world, in a future where international conflicts between the United States and China culminated in a Sino-American war in 2077, due to the scarcity of petroleum reserves that ran the economies of both countries. The player character is an inhabitant of Vault 101, a survival shelter designed to protect up to 1,000 humans from the nuclear fallout. When the player character's father disappears under mysterious circumstances, the player is forced to escape from the Vault and journey into the ruins of Washington, D.C., now known as the "Capital Wasteland", to track their father down. Along the way the player is assisted by a number of human survivors and settlements, and must battle a myriad of enemies that inhabit the area.This is my most favourite game of all time, it is filled with endless hours of fun, such as: Blowing up cities, killing ghouls, killing, killing and um killing... The story is suprisingly good (it's replayable). The characters are good, the story, is good, weapons good, everything amazing, this game is 100x better than fallout 4, I've been playing it since the year it came out and I still revisit it on PC and xbox. After all the story and killing you can still rely on mods to give extra hours of playing with: new missions, guns, followers, worlds, etc, it's endless!!  I would definetly rcommend this to this day! 100%, I love it, 10/10 , buy this now when you get the chance! especially with DLC!

So:I actually did start the game and died.9/10.I'm just kidding.Soon after I left Vault 101 and the sun♥♥♥♥♥♥♥my eyes I realized "I will have a lot of fun with this game".I jumped down the hill and, without a real reason, drank from the irradiated puddle directly in front of the Vault and ... died.After enabling god mode I drank from the same puddle again an ... died?!What the heck is wrong with these damn puddles?Irradiated Cheat-breaking puddles: 7.5/10I went to Megaton, a lively and beautiful little settlement (for wasteland conditions) inhabited by a lot of warm-hearted, welcoming NPCs. In an unfortunate turn of events I accidently blew the city up from a Tower miles away. I really can't recall why.Ability to blow an entire city up, avoiding really funny quests and destroying the lives of dozens of people: 10/10Some kid ran into me, asking me for help because his city was "attacked by giant ants". I knew that little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tried to trick me so I kindly asked him to get lost. I also stole his sweets.My search for Dad continued as I reached a seemingly abandoned ship, Rivet City. Instead of asking for information I just killed everyone, breaking the main story line leaving me unable to finish the game. But I pushed a hobo from the deck and nobody noticed it, so I got that going for me, which is nice.Able to break the game by killing essential NPCs: 6/10. Only amusing in the beginning.I aquired Abraham Lincoln's very own rifle. 10/10I got killed by a deathclaw. Multiply. Within a matter of minutes. On easiest mode. With god mode on. 0/10. Bethesda please nerf.I found dad, he was playing some sh*t game with Oculus Rift. Was all black and white and way too happy, so I hacked into the game and killed everyone spawning Chinese invaders. I also dropped a chandelier on a b*tch. 10/10.Dad and I went back to Rivet City. He was not amused everyone was dead.Blablablabla, middle part, I saw Dad die, blew up a secret underground base, killed the President and their leader destroying the whole faction, saved the entire wasteland by cleaning the entire water from radiation, gave the water to wastelanders for free, helped the BoS establish their influence in D.C., helped a man liberate his home and finding a cure for a disease that turned people into ghoul-like, crawling mutants, solved the mystery of a dangerous island in Maryland, brutally slaying a tribe of uncivilized brats and solving the fight between a brain and a ghoul, I helped the US army win versus the Chinese who attacked US soil via Alaska, GOT ABDUCTED BY ALIENS, saved the entire PLANET by destroying the mothership AND killing their captain, and when I got back I was killed by THE KID I STOLE THE SWEETS FROM.TEN OUT OF FRIGGIN' TEN!BUY THIS GAME! MOD IT UNTIL IT CRASHES!

content:
Posted: January 15
Hello! I'm going through some of my favorite, and less-so, games, and giving them reviews! You can go see some of my other reviews if you'd like through my profile!*Note* I have played many, MANY more hours than my Steam profile shows, as I played this quite often on my sisters account before I bought it, years ago.TL;DR: This game is a fantastic first entry into the world of Fallout from Bethesda, and if you love being whatever kind of person you'd like to be, I completely recommend this game, but it's best with a few mods, which can be located here: http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/I'm gonna be givin' you the truth about this game, no matter HOW bad it hurts!Fallout 3 was my introduction to the entire genre, and while I am a young gamer, I like to believe that this really shaped what type of a gamer, and person that I am in general, even the small things.Now, I have to agree with a lot of people's complaints, which is that the story is actually quite linear. You aren't given many choices on what you'd like to do in the main campaign, and it will almost always end the same way. But the thing is, you can't judge this game purely on the main story, because it's only a few hours long if you rush a bit.This is an open world game, and when you finish the campaign you can really burst into the world. Well , you don't even have to finish the campaign, really. There are a lot of different people you can meet in the wasteland, and how you choose to use your time can truly mean the difference for your own experience as your character.It may fall short of your expectations on occasion, but overall it's a game experience I doubt that you will regret, and that I personally think is WAY better then New Vegas, but that's a story for another time (I'll link that review once I come to it).I personally love the music in this game, and the other Bethesda entries, and I feel that the radio system adds depth and keeps you immersed in your character. Nothing is too out of whack that you can't roleplay!Pros+Some) Excellent character writing+Interesting story line which kept me engaged+Easily moddable, with a great community+Many ways to play-THREEEEE, DOOOGGG!+Many of the songs in this game are my favorites... EVER!+Still being modded today, with major entries coming in every so oftenCons-Terrible gunplay (Fixed with mods)-Not optimised for an OS past Windows 7 (Fixed with mods)-Dated Graphics (Fixed with Mods)-Some of the voice work could be better.Overall, and excellent game, which still holds up well years after release.Now, for the DLC...TL;DR: The DLC for Fallout 3 add some interesting new places and characters, but it's sad that you have to pay extra for a continuation of the main story, which provides a satisfying end.Point Lookout: Didn't particularly enjoy, because I prefer a bit more of a vibrant area, whereas this was foggy and eery, although this may suit you. You take a ridiculously expensive boat ride to a place where strange plants grow, and creatures lurk, and end up in something deeper than you thought.Do I Recommend: It's got more good things than bad, so yes.Mothership Zeta: After exiting for the evil compound of the Enclave, I discover a crashed ship of some kind. As I go to investigate, I see the rocks and dust around me floating up, and I see my companion drifting away as I float up into the Mothership...I had a lot of fun with this DLC, and while it may not be the most realistic, it still adds a lot of new weapons and a few interesting characters.Do I Recommend: Yes, overall it's a fun experience for something different in the Fallout world, and it's fun to blow up some little green men.Operation Anchorage: This DLC introduces another side to one of Fallout 3's main factions, the outcasts of The Brotherhood of Steel. They want to get a surplus amount of weapons for reasons you can keep your nose ot of, but the only way to do this is to complete an army simulation for the days of the "big ka-boom". It's an interesting new experience, and it gives you a bit more of an idea about the world before it went to "waste"...Do I recommend: Yes, I really enjoyed taking a look at some of the machinery that the soldiers would have worked with in the war (I know it's not real :P)The Pitt: Now this one got me really excited, because I love covert operations, especially when I can choose my own adventure. You are asked to sneak into a Raider's slave camp, and free as many people as you can. You discover the harsh treatment that these people are treated to, and get a real sense of atmosphere.Do I recommend: Absolutely. You are sent in with nothing but leave in triumph, or perhaps something else, depending on what type of person you are. I loved this DLC.Now, for the final, and quite possibly, the most important DLC...Broken SteelThe first think you'll notice about this DLC is that it raises the level  cap to 30, allowing you to get a few more skills in, for this extended campaign. This completes the battle between the pre-war Power Armor and Laser Rifle wielding Brotherhood of Steel, and the Specially designed Power Armor and Plasma Rifle wielding Enclave. Who is good, and who is evil is up to you, but one thing is for sure... This battle will be Epic...[h1Do I Recommend:[/h1] I think that if you plan to buy Fallout 3 at all, you HAVE to have this DLC, as it adds so much more incredible story and combat.BONUS! There's a giant fighting robot with laser eyes!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
BeginningDon't get scared of my playtime, becouse I've bought it for a easier game acess and from the personal respect.I played it long time ago at the release date ( 2009 if I'm correct ).Also being a veteran fan of Fallout 1 ,2 and infamous Tactics. I have found Fallout 3 to be a pretty good sequel of the previous games. Not perfect though.I have always dreamed to experience a wastelands from the first person and this game does it good. I will never forget that feel of exiting Vault 101, fantastic experience. Scavenging through the destroyed cities, looking for supplies and watching out for the mutants or bandits. This game knows how to create a "immersive experience".Also it was a first time when I drank a radiated water from the toilet.Being accompanied by a Beautiful soundtrack and Wonderful "ol'times music" from the radio doubles that effect.While this game lacks few details from the previous series , like extensive dialogues or better Charisma system with a lot of choices. It fixes that problem ( a bit ) with a great voice acting.Being a hobbyist level designer by myself it amazes me how much they put detail into every location. There is a story everwhere, every placed rock had some kind of backstory or it can even lead you further.Exploring wastelands, city ruins , old metro's never felt so amazing. Especially School or RobCo factory.I loved also how much story was put into the game, you can read about people last moments right before the bombs fell down. When you enter some abandoned office building , its like a time has stopped. Not to mention quests, while there are not that many they are very well designed and don't feel repetive or boring ( aka kill, bring, deliver ).The main storyline of Fallout 3 is quite interesting too, it might feel a bit personal here but It got me hooked a lot more than a New Vegas story. Yeah it seems quite a generic becouse you are a superhero guy that is going to save a wasteland from the bad guys. I like New Vegas but even if it had better design choices, the atmosphere of the game was "lost somewhere". It lost its post-apocalyptic feel that Fallout 3 had.But even in the last moments of the game , you had a choices. Especially if you are a pacifist ( or you like a more diplomatic way of playing this game ), then you might find it really interesting. You have a choices and they actually change something here.Its a possible to play this game with a a 10 INT , 10 CHA character by only talking or bluffing.  You can hire some mercs of followers to do a dirty job for you and this is what I also like here. You are not limited to your gameplay style and you are not a "jack off all trades", like in the Skyrim.What about DLCs?They are amazing and well done. Each of them offers a different theme so it doesn't feel like a "1 new quest DLC".- Operation Anchorage , its a simple shooter. Almost no dialogues , just go and shoot gooks. Some say its the worst DLC , I can agree but not fully. It still allows you to experience a pre-bombs era with a sweet rewards at the end.- The Pitt, this how DLCs should look. Offer a new interesting stuff and continues a amazing Fallout 3 experience.- Point Lookout , was more like a horror game. Really decent DLC. I would like to see a full standalone game set in this theme becouse even for a DLC it was amazing.- Mothership Zeta, a short funny addon where you shoot aliens and meet a lot of strange people from the past.- and the last one Broken Steel , which expands the main story after Fallout 3 events.BETTER DEAD THAN REDLast worldsIt might look old now but with a few graphic mods it looks fantastic. There is a high replay value becouse of many in-game player choices, builds and endings.If you want harsher experience you might try to download some combat overhauls and all that stuff. There is a lot of good mods that kept this game fresh for a several years. As always , Bethesda games are very open to the modding. Thats a huge plus. Becouse if you don't like X part , you can fix it with a Y mod.They gave us a game where we can shape it by ourselves, to fit your gaming tastes.Just don't make Fallout 4 look like a Skyrim, don't "casual" it too much please.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												For the most part, Fallout 3 lives up to the hype.  I had a great deal of fun with this game for the first thirty hours of play or so.  The RPG character development is strong, the FPS aspect is great considering it's an RPG, and the VATS system which is a combination of both is unique and adds a certain cinematic appeal to combat.  And of course, the perk system adds a certain excitement to leveling up that wasn't standardized for RPG gaming yet at the point of this game's release.The open world is exciting to explore as you seem to run across all kinds of events and quests that (as far as I could tell) you weren't handheld and led to from any other place in the game.  The main storyline and the enjoyable DLCs lead you to the far corners of the map, though additional quests are plentiful.  Multiple quests also seem to offer something entirely unique, especially those related to the DLC, where you'll unlock special perks and otherwise unobtainable weaponry - weaponry which often has its own mechanics that differentiate it from other gear in the game.My only complaint with the game, and this may be self-inflicted, is that as I neared the end and started playing the different DLCs it seemed to begin to drag.  I ended up having to push myself to start the game up, even though I, generally, enjoyed my time playing the game even then.  This could be related to your character becoming drastically overpowered if you allow them to in the higher levels.All in all, a great game and one that I highly recommend to RPG and Post-Apocalyptic fans.  I secondarily recommend this game to FPS, as the gunplay is fun, but it won't blow your mind if that's solely what you're hopping into the game for.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Disclaimer: Long, and a side quest spoiler. TL; DR This game takes awhile to get exciting, but its well worth it.Rather than discuss why I recommend this game, allow me to post a slight side quest spoiler, as it really captures the moment where I fell in love with Fallout 3.As I was exploring the wastes, I came across a sizeable tower. As I neared this tower, I saw a Ghoul (ie looks like a Zombie but is  in full control of his body/mind) aruging with someone over an intercom. Naturally I eavesdropped and discoverd the Ghoul wanted to bring his people into the tower, and the people in the tower, very clearly did not want them in. So as the dismissed Ghoul left I naturally tried my hand at getting into the tower. As I was a human, they let me in no problem. Its there that I picked up a quest to eliminate the Ghouls, as they were become increasingly bothersome to the residents. So I ventured into the tunnels, and found the leader whom I saw previously yelling into the towers intercom. He proposed a different solution, one that would let him and his band of ghouls forcefully take over the tower. I weighed my options. Most tower citizens were not bigots, so I saw no reason to kill them to let the Ghouls in, yet I did not want to elimite the Ghouls. Not agreeing with eliminating either party, I opted for a more peaceful route.After a few speech persuasions, (maybe a few stealthy murders) I persuaded the majority of the citizens in the tower to let the Ghouls in. The ghouls moved in shortly after. All was well. I had done it. I had solved a problem, with both parties intact.or so I thought.I returned to check up on my Ghoul/tower residents, and I noticed something amiss. The former tower leader, was gone, and so were a few of the other human residents. Some investigating later, I found the bodies of a few of the previous Human occupants, shoved in a storage closet. I questioned the Ghoul leader, and he dismissed the murders as "accidents" related to "disagreements". I lost it. I slayed every single Ghoul in that tower, I felt betrayed. Had I not done the good thing? I made two groups coexist. In my quest for an ideal solution I did not see the underlying problem. And now my charecter sits in an empty tower. Filled with neither Ghouls nor Humans, contemplating the error of my choice, dwelling on my unsastisfying rampage against the ghouls that betrayed me. All the while marvelling at the game design, and how it made clear moral choices murky.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
I have over five thousand hours in this game. I have it for Games for Windows LIVE and XBOX 360, now I have my 3rd copy, Steam. I have completely finished the game and every aspect it has to offer time and time again, creating countless mods with the GECK. How did I do this, you may ask? Well, I've played it ever since its US release in 2008 and played nearly every day on my old Windows XP and more recently my Windows 7. The way you get it to work on your Windows 7 is you go to your Documents > My Games > Fallout3 > FALLOUT.INI. In lines 88-89, change bUseThreadedAI to 1 and add iNumHWThreads=2 just after it. This makes the game use Threaded AI and it makes the game use only 2 CPU cores; otherwise the game will continuously crash. After you do this, the game will be more stable than Fallout New Vegas.Alright. Onto the review.SettingThe game is set in a post-apocalyptic, retro-futuristic Washington, D.C. following the Great War between the U.S., China, the Soviet Union and other countries. The Great War occurred on October 23, 2077 which caused immense damage and destruction despite lasting less than two hours. Before the Great War, there were the Resource Wars that nearly crippled the world and brought riots to the streets, during which the United Nations disbanded, and a Forced Evolutionary Virus plague coupled with global terrorism rendered the United States paranoid of both real and imagined communist plots. Canada was annexed by the United States in order to help the U.S. war effort against the Chinese in Alaska. The fact that Canada had the plentiful resources of nearly untouched wilderness made America's effort well worth the protection the U.S.A. promised to provide.The WorldRust, decay, and creeping vegetation infest monuments from before the Great War. Amidst the ruins of Washington, D.C., the Capitol, the Jefferson Memorial and the battered remains of the Washington Monument still stand in the desolate area that is now known as the Capital Wasteland. The central hub of civilization in the ruins of the former capital is Rivet City, based in the remains of an aircraft carrier carried far inland and beached by a catastrophic tsunami whose waters have long since receded. Other settlements include the towns of Megaton, Arefu, Tenpenny Tower and Paradise Falls. Movement through the downtown area and settlements is possible through the Washington Metro tunnels and crossing the desolate nuclear wasteland.The Brotherhood of Steel community is stationed in the Citadel, built in the ruins of the pre-War Pentagon where they attempt to preserve as much pre-war technology as possible. Super mutants, who since emerging from their refuges, have waged an unceasing war against what remains of humanity, trying to invade their territory and capture them. The Enclave - the self-styled inheritors of the power of the United States government - under the leadership of their new President John Henry Eden and his ruthless second-in-command Colonel Augustus Autumn, are the player's biggest foes in the game.Emotional ImpactAt the very beginning of the game we are introduced to the Player's father, voiced by Liam Neeson. Character development is thown at us in the first few seconds of the game, great start. I shouldn't already be bored within the first 10 minutes of a game. Fallout 3 does very well to keep it that way.The one (but not only) thing Fallout 3 does fantastic is character development.There'd be more to this review but I would be spoiling it; if you haven't already done so, BUY THIS GAME!!! WORTH EVERY PENNY! Take it from me, I have 3 copies of this game!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												Third canonical entry of the beloved classical RPG franchise Fallout. First one ever produced in a decade, if you discount the spin-off Brotherhood of Steel tactical RPG and the action game released on Playstation. Also the first title since Bethesda took over. This one generate quite a bit of controversy within the Fallout community, largely due to the fact it plays different than previous titles, as Bethesda decides to use the Elder Scrolls' engine based on GameBryo, which obviously is what they excel at.Contrast to previous titles' isometric CRPG aspect, Fallout 3 is recommended by the developer to play in First Person perspective, even though a third person is present in the game. Some may mistake this game as an FPS on first glance, but rest assured this is still a pretty heavy CRPG, where character development, stats, skills and perks play the most important role in terms of gameplay, rather than the player's aiming skill.Suffice to say, Beth created this Fallout title with love and homage to the original titles produced by Interplay, who sold the license and rights to them. This curiously gathered a lot of hate within the community towards them, even though in my opinion it was Interplay's fault to mismanage itself and go bankrupt. Other than the perspective, this game plays and feels like a true Fallout title, all the concepts and aesthetics were nicely adapted into the familiar Elder Scrolls-like gameplay, which personally is quite a happy mix due to my loyalty to that series.Needless to say, the gameplay leans more toward Elder Scrolls titles rather than the old Fallout games in the 90's. Some may see as a problem, but I don't. Especially if you live in 2015, you can literally find spiritual successers to every classic RPGs: Wasteland 2 to Fallout (and of course the original Wasteland, which Fallout is loosely based on), Pillars of Eternity to Baldur's Gate, Torment: Tides of Numenera to Planescape, Divinity: Original Sin to Ultima, and a bunch of excellent tile-based dungeon crawlers to the classics like Eyes of the Beholder in early 90s. So you see, Fallout 3 being different than before isn't a problem for me personally, and it surely wasn't a problem for the original Fallout crew, of which a large proportion of developers work for Obsidian to strike a deal with Beth to work on a title truer to the original spirit of Fallout to based on Fallout 3's base game. See New Vegas.One benefit of Beth's taking over that no one can deny is obviously the production value. Fallout 3 is a step up in almost every direction up from Oblivion, which FO3 is built upon. Some folks jokingly name the new Fallout as "Oblivion with guns", which indeed tells some truth. Gone is the old turn based tactical combat, in with the new hectic real-time action with pausible VATS system which allows you to plan and spend your action points. I wouldn't favor one system over the other,  but FO3 does bring some fresh air to this aged franchise.Worldcrafting wise, Beth does what it does best. Exploration is rewarding as ever. This time around, the game is set in DC and has an east coast vide, as opposed to the West Coast settings in Fallout 1 and 2. You can definitely tell this is due to Bethesda locating in Maryland. The gameworld itself is slightly smaller than that of Oblivion. This doesn't mean it has less details. If anything, the world in this game is even more vibrant. Beth clearly learnt their mistake with the generic tones of the Radiant system in Oblivion and improved upon it. This also paved the road for future titles like Skyrim and Fallout 4 to progressively become more and more organic and polished. The excellent sequal New Vegas developed by part of the original Fallout crew also take advantage of Fallout 3's engine and many of the existing gameworld assets. which is a nod to Beth's skill and will to inherit this franchise.Final verdict: 9/10. A true Fallout fan's must have. Niche audience of open world and CRPG genre will also find quite a bang for your buck. Although avid fans only waiting for Van Buren project should be advised to find nostalgia elsewhere in titles like Wasteland 2. You may reserve your opinion towards many of the new aspects of this new title, yet nobody can deny this is hell of a game and a truly a rewarding RPG experience.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
Short version: 82%Is it The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion with firearms and a burnt-out wasteland? Yes, it is, with all of the good and all of the bad. The good being a masterfully crafted world that is a joy to explore again and again, with enjoyable combat, loads and loads of items, and an atmosphere that will never let you go. And the bad being the paper thin plot line and almost amusingly bad dialogues, complemented by equally atrocious voice-acting. So, in essence, it’s your usual Bethesda game: a great dungeon crawler with a bad story.Long version:When the first previews were seen about Fallout 3, everybody thought that the new owner, Bethesda just re-skinned their high-selling game, Oblivion, slapped in some firearms, and called it a day. In some manner it’s true, Fallout 3 is not like any other previous Fallout titles, which included two turn-based isometric RPGs, a TBS/RPG hybrid, and a top-down button-mashing hack-and-slash. Fallout 3 on the other hand is an action-RPG/FPS hybrid dungeon-crawler, which features all the trademarks of the Elder Scrolls series, including the good and the bad.The Good: The game world is jaw-dropping. The ruins of Washington D. C. are a marvel to look at, and the surrounding wasteland offers plenty of smaller and larger places and secrets to discover. The map is enjoyable enough to start a new character for the sole reason of exploring it again.The combat is heavily biased in the player’s favour, but it’s still fun. It’s also very violent and gory. Although it features less death animation than the old 2D games, they are so brutal it’s almost a guilty pleasure to wander around and blow the super mutants and the raiders to tiny, bloody bits.The Bad: Practically everything that involved the writing staff. The main plotline is just a mishmash of Fallout 1 and 2 with little cohesion and a plethora of plot holes. The established lore is either misused with little understanding, or simply contradicted (again, Elder Scrolls players are probably used to this). The dialogues and the voice acting ranges from somewhat tolerable to downright painful.Also, like in the case of all GameBryo engine (and Fallout) titles, it’s essential to install the community-created patches to get rid of the thousands of bugs and game-breaking glitches, including one where it’s impossible to start the game on Windows 7 or later. (Visit the community for a guide on how to do this.)Overall, Fallout 3 is an immensely enjoyable dungeon crawler. Just forget the storyline and that it’s supposed to be set in the same world as the much-loved originals, and enjoy the hundreds of hours of exploration and mutant hunting!

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Kay, so I have 33 minutes on record because most of my time spent with this game was through the Tale of Two Wastelands mod. My first Fallout game was Fallout 4. I rather disliked the game despite having no previous experience with these games. I here a lot of people say that it was a great game but a terrible Fallout game/RPG, most of which I disagree with. It excels at nothing in paticular and you can get a better open world shooter experience from many other games, while the RPG aspect of the game is borderline nonexistint. The second Fallout game I played was New Vegas, which I absolutely adored. It has become my favorite game of all time, in fact. I was pointed toward this game rather frequently due to my love of New Vegas, and as such I bought it when the game was on sale. I found it rather surprising that this game shared many of the same problems as Fallout 4. For starters, this game's story is terrible. The concept is decent at its core and the world is great, but the main plot line is abismal in its excecution. The characters are all incredibly flat, the villains have no motivation for anything they do, and the story relies very heavily on people making incredibly stupid decisions. It's not good, and I find it a bit puzzling when people say otherwise. I'm not saying they're wrong, but they certainly viewed it from a very different angle from myself. This puts me in a rather difficult position, as naturally I am going to compare it to the other entries I have played. New Vegas had a story leaps and bounds ahead of this game in pretty much every aspect, and I don't think many people would argue that. However, I do think I would actually put this game's story ahead of that of Fallout 4. Fallout 4 had much better presentation with the superior voice acting and art direction, but it was very linear and frankly one of the most incoherent messes I have ever seen in a triple A videogame. I get the feeling that nobody working on it cared in the slightest. 3 is similar, but to a lesser extent. While arguably more linear, the story is at the very least coherent. The dialogue, while not as good as New Vegas, is still very good in my opinion. It gives you a lot of options and is vastly superior to most other dialogue systems in games. The combat kinda suck, same as New Vegas but you can ignore that as it isn't the focus of the game. The world sells this game though. It's great. 4 had a prettier wasteland, but there was nothing to do in it outside of killing people for the most part. Fallout 3's world is much more interactive. There are many more populated areas and people to talk to. A lot of quests have you exploring really interesting locations without murdering everyone. The gothic architecture in the city of DC is another great aspect of the world. The world glows with dark charm and personality, and I think it is more than worth the asking price for the exploration aspect alone. This is kind of a roundabout way of saying I like the game. I love it, actually. Whereas I think Fallout 4 was legitimately not a very good game, I find that most of the complaints for Fallout 3 come from comparing it to Fallout 1, 2, and New Vegas. By its own merits, I think it's a really good game.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												If there is any Fallout game after 2008 that has an eery, hopeless, childhood nightmare atmosphere, its this one. Where do I start? Everyone in this world has extreme hardships, wearing from your father being killed by fireants, to finding a violin. In this game, its cowboy rules, you kill, you get killed. You steal, you get your life stolen.  This game also includes some of the best DLC I have ever played. Period. I'm going back into the aspect of the atmosphere.  Point Lookout  Point Lookout takes place in the Fallout equivalent of Point Lookout State Park, a new swampland area with new quests and enemies. Point Lookout in the Fallout setting has a landscape between one-sixth and one-fifth the size of the Capital Wasteland where "the bombs didn't actually fall, but the world has left it behind".[/1]My review of this is very simple. The hopeless scale can't even be measured on a Vitomatic Vigor Tester. It makes you feel like a tiny bug, as it continuously pushes you to cultists, fight inbreds, and help ghoul mansion owners. The eery. nightmare world it makes it seem adds a classic horror film aspect. It's my favorite Fallout 3 and Fallout in general DLC. The Pitt The Pitt allows you to travel to the post-apocalyptic remains of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and become embroiled in a conflict between slaves and their raider masters. Explore a sprawling settlement ravaged by time, neglect, nuclear radiation, and moral degradation. The Pitt is filled with morally gray choices, shady non-player characters, new enemies, new weapons, and much more. 2 Words. The Cure. Mothership Zeta Defy hostile alien abductors and fight your way off of the massive Mothership Zeta, orbiting Earth miles above the Capital Wasteland. Mothership Zeta takes Fallout 3 in an entirely new direction – outer space. Meet new characters and join with them in a desperate bid to escape the aliens’ clutches. To do so, you’ll wield powerful new weapons, like the alien atomizer, alien disintegrator, and drone cannon, and deck yourself out in brand new outfits, like the Gemini-Era spacesuit and even samurai armor.Pretty cool. On the scale of the coolest and most fun and controlling DLCs, it ranks up high. The way it includes ancient people (i.e. cowboys, samurais, astronauts) really makes me happy, including the special samurai armor, and cowboy revolver really quenches a thirst for special, yet pretty silly items.

Posted: September 24, 2016
												My steam profile might say I only have 0.3 hrs or so currently (that may change soon), but I have played this game extensivley on the X-Box 360, and I can say that it is definitely one of my favorite games of all time. The story is so interesting, and your quest seems so important that when you reach a goal, or finish one of the quests it flows so naturally into the next. I could sit down and play this for HOURS (although I could say the same for any Fallout game). The only problem with playing this on steam is that it WILL NOT RUN on WINDOWS 8 or 10 (unless 3rd party software/code manipulation is done, which still might not work). It will work, however, if you run on Windows 7, Vista or XP or if you have a comp that can switch from different versions. Honestly, if you want to play this game, but don't have the right os, don't spend a bunch of money getting Windows 7, just play it on PS3 or X-Box 360. If you enjoy an open yet isolated feeling, an eerie feeling everytime you see something move in the distance, or an enthralling story with exciting combat and endless hours of fun, it doesn't matter what you play it on, as long as you play it.

												Fallout 3 dawned a new era into the franchise. Now, Bethesda's first Fallout, may even be more iconic than the original two. Personally, I had a medium amount of experience to Fallout 3 as a kid, I played it when I got my hands on it; but my trip through the wasteland really began with Fallout New Vegas, a few years on. Finally, I am playing Fallout 3 properly. I would say my only complaint is that it does not capture that lust to explore, like the Commonwealth and Mojave Wasteland did for me. There is no way it comes close to New Vegas, but if you're a Fallout fanatic it is worth pumping some hours into. Specifically, the GAME OF THE YEAR EDITION offers up some of the best DLC in the franchise, such as Mothership Zeta or Operation Anchorage.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
OK, A QUICK EXPLANATION: I tried to modify the executable files to allow the Fallout Script Extender to work, and it did, but it wouldn't work with the Steam Overlay and still doesn't. According to my save i have about 92 hours, 58 minutes and 55 seconds of play time, so know that despite the appearent playing time of less than an hour according to steam, I have given this game a considerable playthrough.PROS:Large world to explore  - It feels great to adventure across the wasteland seeking it's wonders and surviving its horrors. DLC content adds more things to do and places to exporeCONS:Weak Story - The story is pretty decent right up until the middle and then it all falls apart. None of the actions of some of the chracters make any bit of sense and the fact that a piece of DLC had to retconn the end (by fixing a BIG plothole) doesn't win points in my book. There is just so little love in the story compared to 1 and 2 (and even New Vegas), shoehorned allegories and cliches, etc. Why is Lamplight Caverns just children even after 200 years, "DON'T THINK ABOUT IT" says Bethesda. "Why do i have to die for the wasteland?" 'BECAUSE IT'S A CHRIST ALLEGORY" says Bethesda. *sigh*Bullet sponges at higher levels - A stronger enemy should deal more damage and make you think on your toes, not sit there and take it like the world's least satisfied ♥♥♥♥♥.Still pretty buggy - I've had this game crash on me at least 30 maybe 40 times during my playthrough. Also weird things, like entire chunks of the wastes dissappearing into a strange void, Dogmeat died randomly as i was wandering through an already pilfered vault void of enemies. I had a mind-controlled deathclaw with me from Broken Steel, respawn in Megaton with me after completing said DLC and even after killing it, it respawned sometime later in Point Lookout before being killed by hillbillies.Broken combat - The combat is kinda broken. Sometimes functional, but there would be times in which i wished things were tighter.  I found myself many times dealing with the Combat Shotgun that would fire sometimes and lock up in others. Not a lot of replay value - They just offer slightly different still framed images depending on karma level, but tell nothing of the actual consequences of your actions or the fates of those involved, like most RPGS would.The GOTY version includes all DLC, which consists of:Broken Steel: the aforementioned DLC that reconns the story's BIG ending plothole. It continues the fight against the Enclave to crush them once and for all. Decently climactic, and you can blow up the Brotherhood if you want to!Operation Anchorage: Help the Outcasts get into a sealed armory for some nifty Winterized T51-b armor by completing a weirdly Call of Duty-esque simulation in prewar Ancorage, Alaska to take it back from them dirty commies!Point Lookout: Travel down south to the swamplands to shoot at mutant rednecks and finish a feud between a ghoul and a brain once and for all. Not bad, but the only thing i remember is the druggy sequence halfway through.The Pitt: Travel north to what was Pittsburgh to join the slaves down in the muck and rise up to either join the slavers or grant long awaited freedom to the slaves. Admittedly, this one actually did make me hestitate, as you must make a choice that doesn't leave you with a "and they all lived happily ever after" result in either instance. Not bad.Mothership Zeta: You are abuducted by aliens and must escape! This one was just weird, and not really in a good way. Usually aliens were included in the series as a joke, but this just puts it into the main game with a serious face. Mostly meh, considering that most of the aliens have shields that turn them into bullet sponges.Admittedly, i played New Vegas before i played this one, so some of the things were just annoying, such as the repair system, lack of variety in weapons, and the lack of a Damage Threshold  and Reputation system that previously appeared in Fallout 2. Granted, without Fallout 3 there probably wouldn't have been New Vegas, but there's still so many problems. Its the first stab at a 3D Fallout title, even if it's become appearent that Bethesda doesn't care about it as much as they do the Elder Scrolls series. Think of it as a historical document, even if it doesn't stand up to time.

If you enjoy an open yet isolated feeling, an eerie feeling everytime you see something move in the distance, or an enthralling story with exciting combat and endless hours of fun, it doesn't matter what you play it on, as long as you play it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Disclaimer: I got way more hours on this game than shown.TL;DR Pretty good game if you're into Bethesda games, with typical emphasis on dialogue and exploration. Like any Bethesda game don't look here for particularly good gameplay though I would say it's not that bad, but at this point it may feel rather dated for an FPS.I quite enjoyed this game, I rarely replay games, and this is one of the few I have, albeit my second playthrough was quite different from first. First being vanilla, no DLC with second being all DLC + a few of the most well known mods for the game.Story - The main storyline is... Ok. Nothing special but passable for Bethesda main quest. As usual, side quests are where it's at for interesting story chunks. Though the last main mission is pretty epic. Setting - Awesome world to explore. Chronologically it feels off but ignoring that, the world really gets what it set out to do, a lonesome nuked world. You can have plenty of fun simply walking around the world.Gameplay - Pretty loose, wonky for an FPS. Personally on vanilla Fallout I just used VATS all the time. I wouldn't praise the game much for the gameplay, personally I find VATS to be decent but it's no top tier shooter or rpg in terms of action gameplay. Late game the game gets really easy, nothing will kill you once you hit higher levels. The dialogue system is great though and allows for choices that seem to matter, unlike fallout 4. The leveling system is great. All in all, the game is an rpg first shooter second.Audio - The ambient non-radio music is very fitting, probably underrated since few actually listen to it. The radio has got those distinctive oldies retro songs everybody has come to love. Gun sounds are fine. The voices used for characters are pretty good.Mods - The mod support for this game is top of the line. You can easily mod it to feel very different. Good♥♥♥♥♥♥Lore - Something worth pointing out, though probably not an impact to many is that this game is NOT lore friendly to Fallout 1 or 2. This one of the biggest criticisms of this game, though many have not played those games (including myself) so you probably don't care, but it is what it is.Really if you really enjoy Bethesda type games, where you just explore the world, get interesting sidequests, have great dialogue with npcs, then this really does it right. Just don't expect an amazing shooter, or a pretty looking game.
