number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Fallout 3 is one of the best examples of the FPS-RPG Hybrid genre, combining the sprawling depth of a traditional isometric RPG  with the reflex-rewarding immersion of an FPS.  Rather than dumbing down the game to fit the expectations of the fast-twitch FPS gamer, Fallout 3 keeps nearly all of the Fallout series' trademark complexity, nuanced plot, numerous areas to explore and seemingly endless sidequests.  All this adds up to a truly HUGE sandbox game that you can easily spend hundreds of hours on, never getting bored.That is not to say that Fallout 3 is perfect.  Like most Bethesda titles, Fallout 3 has quite a few bugs, ranging from minor to serious.  Hardly surprising given the sheer scale of the thing, and percentage wise it's a very small portion of the game.  Of course, the bug problem itself leads me to mention one of the best things about Fallout 3: moddability.Fallout 3 is one of the most moddable games ever released on PC, with mods not only supported but encouraged by the publisher.  While you can't get into the nitty gritty of the engine itself using the SDK (unlike most Source or early Unreal games), basically everything else is fair game for being modded.  This can range from the mundane to the fantastic, anything from increases in weapon damage to entirely new plots with numerous side-quests and fully voiced dialog.  Fallout 3 in itself is an amazing game, but with the appropriate mods - chosen from the literally thousands available - it can become truly awe-inspiring.Mods can also include fixes to the bugs that Bethesda left in the game.  Yes, Bethesda may not have fixed all their mistakes in Fallout 3, but they at least left behind tools so that the fans can.All that said, what you should take away from this review is that Fallout 3 is a really, really, really good game.  It takes very little time - as little as fifteen minutes - before the game has thoroughly sucked you in, and once you're hooked you can spend literally hundreds of hours playing and enjoying.  At time of writing I have more than 200 hours logged on the game and there are STILL areas in the Capital Wasteland I am encountering for the first time.  That's serious replayability.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Fallout 3 was my first foray into Bethesda as a company and a developer. Originally completed on the PS3 years ago, the quality of Fallout 3 warranted another purchase for the PC. It was a purchase that I did not regret. Fallout 3's 1950's representation of a post-apocalyptic setting is both visually stunning and conceptually very well done. It manages to deliver an astonishingly accurate world that attempts to keep what we know of the 50's in check, yet sprinkling it with a dose of future technology and the consequences of said technology - which effectively suspends the 50's style similiarily to what the Dark Ages did after the enlightened Renaissance period. Fallout 3's characters are as much "of the times", as they are diverse. The NPC's mannerisms, beliefs, and way of life are decidely 50's oriented. There are the mutants, the human enclaves, the militant powers, the underdwellers, and the radioactive fauna. These factions breathe life into an admittedly grey, dead world (as befits a post-nuclear setting).Fallout 3 is a dark, gritty story based on the freedom of exploration, role-playing, and as such is what makes the game so incredibly entertaining. There is a linear story, but it's not essential to get the feel of the game because in almost every title of this game type, the side quest content far outweighs that of the linear "campaign". Mechanics are simple, the movement a tad clunky, and the combat a tad frustrating. Melee is essentially whack and run, and aiming down sites is near nonexistent. To combat this shortcoming Fallout 3 makes use of VATS, which enables you to aim and fire at specific parts of the body, greatly increasing accuracy and a chance at survival. This aspect incorporates melee as well. There are two incredible soundtracks within the game, the usual OST and in this case, the radio station. These two soundtracks add much to the overall quality of the atmosphere, and in turn the end product.I highly recommend the fantastic Fallout 3.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Fallout 3 does many things right. The most important of its strengths in my opinion, however, is its ability to immerse the player in an atmosphere filled with choice, unique experiences, and a world worth exploring.The Fallout franchise has always done these things right, but Fallout 3 brought a new atmosphere and a new set of mechanics to an already great model. These mechanics all work extremely well and make Fallout 3 a revolutionary game. The combination of the dialogue system, V.A.T.S., and the functionality of the Pip Boy make gameplay smooth yet still very refreshing. The primary narrative is strong and supports the immersion of the gameplay, while the entirety of the wasteland is filled with areas full of depth and story that is present in almost no other game.Revisiting Fallout 3 has only confirmed the undeniable strengths and with each playthrough, the player will surely find new areas and characters worth exploring and experiencing. For these reasons, Fallout 3, along with its predecessors, stand alone in their own sect of games. Along with these strengths, Fallout 3 added a certain undefineable charm as it broke into the 3-dimensional realm. NPCs, the world, and the physics make playing the game a real joy and keep a smile on your face the entire time.Fallout 3 is a must-own game and represents a special era in gaming in my personal opinion.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Originally when you download Fallout 3 GOTY it isn't compatible with Windows 10 and the game will crash after clicking play on the launcher. This is because Windows 10 is missing a Games for Windows Live document. A quick download will fix this. Then you will be ale to go as far as the main menu for the game and then it will crash. If you have an Intel Graphics card then you will need to download an Intel bypass from Nexus mods and drop it into your GOTY folder. If you have a multi-core PC then you will have to edit the games files to allow it to use multiple cores. If you are using Windows 10 then I suggest opening your desktop Steam application and right clicking on Fallout 3 GOTY. From here go to Properties and then to Compatibility. Select Run in Compatibility mode with: Windows 7. Also select Run this program as an administrator. Games for Windows Live download:http://www.xbox.com/en-CA/Live/PC/DownloadClientThis video shows how to edit the Fallout 3 file to use multiple cores and the GFWL download:


YouTube™ Video: Fallout 3 ON WINDOWS 10 FIXED (New game crash) 

			Views: 17,277		

			This is everything I had to do in order to play fallout 3 on my PC. It took me awhile to fix the issue but hopefully this help.		

This link is to Nexus for the Intel Bypass mod:http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/17209/?When you download the Intel bypass, open a new File Explorer tab and open the Intel Bypass package. Open your Fallout GOTY file which is in your Steam/steamapps/common. In your Intel bypass package, drag the D3D9 file into your Fallout GOTY folder. Make sure it says 'Copy to Fallout GOTY file'. I recommend playing this game through a couple times without mods. This way you really appreciate the work Bethesda did and the mod authors later on.

												I haven't played this much yet since I aquired it on Steam, but I bought it on disc when it was released and I purchased each individual DLC upon release as well. I don't remember exactly how many hours I spent playing this game back in 2008 and 2009, but it must have been close to 100 hours. As a huge Fallout fan since the first back in the mid 90s, this was just the ultimate awesome!This is truly one of the few games that kept me glued to my screen for a half a day at a time or more. I remember one week-end when I got home from work on Friday evening and played pretty much through to Sunday evening non-stop (minus food and required hygene etc.), but not many games have been able to do this! It's so immersive, so atmospheric and you just want to keep going until the next level, the next upgrade, the next weird encounter.The GOTY edition includes all the DLCs, so you can definitely no go wrong here. If you have never played Fallout 3 yet (or any of the other Fallouts -- an complete sacrilege if you ask me!!), then play. Seriously, leave your vault and play. This is pretty much an all-time-hall-of-fame game

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is my 200th game review, it is also the first in a trilogy of Fallout games released since 2005, which are a continuation of the original Fallout series for the PC. Fallout 3 takes us to Vault 101, where you play as a male/female character of your choice who leaves the vault to search for their father. Along the way you encounter struggling towns, various NPC's, complete quests, explore, and dungeon delve buildings, ruins, and other vaults as you progress through the story.Fallout 3 is a First Person RPG where you interact with your environment and engage in FPS-style combat with enemies. It has an impressive list of voice actors and an immersive story that pulls you into the world of the Post-Apocalyptic Capital Wasteland, essentially the ruins of what was once Washington, DC. Fallout 3 was a blast to play on the PS3, as well as the PC and spawned 2 sequels which take place after the events of 3. If you enjoy post-apocalyptic games as well as FPS combat and RPG's, I recommend picking this game up and giving it a try. The Game of the year edition comes with all 5 DLC's included, so make sure you pick up this particular edition to get the full Fallout experience. Don't forget to tune into Galaxy News Radio, and everyone's favorite disk jockey, Three Dog, for some memorable dialogue and music.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												October 31, 2008. Finally, after more than 10 years I would be able to continue my adventures in my most beloved franchise ever 'Fallout' (I did not count Fallout Tactics, which I also loved). I was sceptical at first, since this would be first Fallout game made by Bethesda. Like others, I did not just want a 'Oblivion with guns', also being on the East-Coast would feel differently, compared to the other games in the series. Right from the start the hand of Bethesda was clearly visible. Starting the game as a baby/toddler/teenager was probably not what Black Isle would've done. Also the storytelling is a bit more childish and immature (like in Oblivion). The story was praised by many and even got an award for best story that year. In my opinion, the story(telling) is one of the worst parts about the game. If you have played Fallout 1 and 2, you will notice the story of Fallout 3 is simply Fallout 1 & 2's story put together. There are also weird locations/quests and multiple things that do not really add up to the Fallout lore.Aside from the story, Bethesda still did manage to create a beautifully post-apocalyptic world and kept the Fallout feeling mostly throughout the game. Graphically, the game has aged but it's still well playable.The thing I love most about Fallout 3 is just wandering around the Capital Wasteland and find new locations, items/weapons/armor and/or easter eggs. Often you will enounter various enemies and npc's which either want to help you or destroy you. Gameplay is fun aswell. Killing enemies feels satisfying, there are tons of weapons for you play around with, quests to finish, secret locations.... there's just too much for me to write down. simply put, Fallout 3 will most likely enjoy you for hundreds of hours and is a must-have for every RPG-lover.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Fallout 3, surprisingly, is a game that was actually developed and made by Bethesda, and not a fan made mod. This is surprising because from just playing it, it can be hard to tell at times. I know I'm late to writing this review, but I wanted to remind both myself and anyone who reads this of how Fallout 3 was in case Fallout 4 doesn't seem as good as it looks when it comes out. (It may not look like it with the 90 minutes I have tracked, but I have completed the game twice; once from a retail copy and more recently through New Vegas using the Tale of Two Wastelands mod.)Fallout 3 is set in the Capital Wasteland, a new location set on the opposite side of the US from the traditional west coasts of Fallout 1, 2, and later New Vegas. By doing this, they allowed themselves to have a clean slate of sorts, and have more creative freedom in writing the story. So naturally, being skilled writers as they are, they just copied a bunch of stuff from the old games and rewrote it to be worse. The Brotherhood of Steel is back, only this time they're a splinter faction that's a bunch of goodie two-shoes that go from shunning you to thanking you for letting them bask in your presence over the course of one quest (the "real" brotherhood is still technically there in the form of the Outcasts, but they barely have any presence in the game). The Enclave is back for no real reason at all, considering they were pretty much ended in 2. They made up their own east coast brand of super mutant just so they could flood the game with them. Even things like caps don't really make sense, since the only reason caps were used as currency in the west coast games is because they were backed by the Hub. The whole game just feels like they went through a picture book of Fallout and saw cool things and went "hey that looks cool, let's put it in our game too!" without really thinking that much about why they would actually be there.Gameplay-wise, the game is a mixed bag. The exploration can be pretty fun, especially with mods like DC Interiors (which opens up a bunch of the boarded up buildings that Bethesda was too lazy to furnish), but the shooting is fairly subpar, and you can tell that the engine wasn't really built for shooting games at that stage of its development. Of course, you can always use VATS if you'd rather watch the game play itself instead, since it's effectively been turned into an easy button that lets you have 5 turns to blow an enemy to pieces and then gives the enemy one. The whole stat system is a joke, and between the rate you get perks, the perks added by DLCs, and the bobbleheads scattered throughout the world, it's almost impossible to not end up with 10 in every SPECIAL stat and 100 in every skill by the time you finish the game. Because it's basically impossible to specialize in any particular ability due to inevitably having to specialize in all of them, and the fact that the game doesn't really give you any major choices that have actual consequences, it can be difficult to feel like you're actually roleplaying in Fallout 3. But that's fine, because it's pretty much impossible with the dialogue anyways. The dialogue options are, as best as I can describe them, schizophrenically written. You can blow up an entire settlement and laugh it off, then five minutes later meet a group of people you believe to be cannibals and have no dialogue option to say anything other than something negative towards them. At one point early in the game you meet a ghoul bartender, and your only options are two choices of mocking him and the last option, "Let me think about it for a moment, my good man.", which is so cringey that I can only assume that if Bethesda's animators had any talent it would be accompanied by an animation of the player character tipping an imaginary top hat and taking a puff from a wooden pipe. Most of the intelligence choices are just repeating what someone just said to you back to them in a summarized form written in an overly wordy way, and a lot of the speech checks go beyond ridiculousness in terms of convincing people or things to do things they would never realistically do in a single sentence. The game has a karma system, but I don't know if it's even possible to keep a negative karma level because of how much of it you get dumped onto you just for things like killing ghouls or raiders (which are impossible to allign with because Fallout 3 has no faction system), but it doesn't really matter because it's not even that much fun to play evil. There are no real meaningful evil choices, just a bunch of "for the laughs" things. There are one or two noteworthy evil moments and then the rest of it is just "ahaha i shoot you in the face" options in dialogue that just aren't really fulfilling, and some of them are just plain nonsensical and make no sense for the player to do, like the one at the end of the Broken Steel DLC. The game also has two factions that hunt you down depending on whether your karma is too high or low, but while the evil karma version is a group of lawbringers who are hunting you down because you're a known criminal, the good varient just gets Talon Company, a mercenary unit that Bethesda just made up and gave no backstory aside from "they're bad guys and so they want to kill good guys because they're really bad people!" and set them loose on you.The DLC is about what you would expect so far. Operation Anchorage is essentially just a 3 hour crappy military corridor FPS with a few good rewards, Mothership Zeta is a crappy space corridor shooter with a few good rewards, and Broken Steel is only worth playing because of the fact that it basically forces you to after the end of the base game. The Pitt and Point Lookout are basically the only ones that I would consider "good", with the former being a brief but interesting quest line and a relatively fun collectathon with some good rewards and the latter being the only dlc to give a more open experience in a new map with new side quests and things to explore. If it wasn't for the fact that the GOTY edition costs the same as buying regular fallout 3 + point lookout + the pitt I'd just tell you to buy those, but oh well.Fallout 3 is what I would consider a "popcorn RPG". It's the kind of game where you can spend 100 hours just exploring the wasteland and looting buildings and doing side quests and then remember that there's a boring main storyline for you to do, but it's not a game where you have to make choices or develop a character or anything associated with more in-depth RPGs, and while to an extent I feel that way about all of Bethesda's post-Morrowind RPGs, Fallout 3 in particular exemplifies the concept. If you're new to the Fallout series you may love it, or if you've played them all you can probably still just forget that it's a Fallout game and have fun exploring, but it's both a terrible RPG and a terrible Fallout game. It's extremely unstable on its own, so either modding it to high heaven or playing it through New Vegas in the A Tale of Two Wastelands mod (which requires both games and all of their DLC) is basically required. If you have time to kill and just want to relax in the wasteland for a little while, there's no reason not to buy Fallout 3 if it's on sale and you've got nothing else to play, but there just isn't anything exceptional that would prompt me to actively recommend the game. Hopefully Bethesda will have learned from New Vegas when we get to play Fallout 4.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Fallout 3, the game itself, is fantastic. But do not buy it. The installation is plagued with compatibility issues, necessitating you to go reading through third party guides just to find out how to properly install the game you paid for. Then, in game, there are other issues you have to constantly be aware of or else your game will crash. For example, did you know you cannot save over old save files? If you do, and load your game, it will freeze and crash every single time. There is no in game warning for this, just as there is no warning on the game page that this game is incompatible for most computers made after 2007 (as I've said, you have to read through third party guides and install third party mods just to play the vanilla version of the game).I do not know how it's legal to sell a broken product with no official warning given to potential customers. They use weasel langauge and say that the game is not 'Optimized' for Windows 7 and beyond instead of outright saying it will not work, which is the issue. Hopefully some people decide to read the reviews about the game on Steam and realize just how much of a headache they'll be going through just to install and play the normal, unmodded version of the game. And don't forget - never, ever save over an old save file (a bug the programmers never warn you about nor one they give you option to disabled) or else you can say goodbye to hours of gameplay. Fallout 3 - the game itself is great. Installation is a massive problem (for no reason, since it's still possible to install with third party mods not officially created or endorsed by Bethesda, the game creators), and there are too many game ruining bugs. Seeing as how it's been years since this game was released, these issues are obviously never going to be addressed by the company - I suppose it's just easier to slap an extremely vague warning (hidden in the middle of the sale page) and just keep letting unaware customers continue buying a game they don't support than it is to have some integrity and intiative and fix the game. If you must play this game, find circular means - Bethesda obviously does not care about their customers consuming experience. Given their treatment of customers, I will not buy (nor recommend anyone else to buy) any other games from Bethesda, Fallout 4 included. They are still charging a hefty price for a broken game (giving no warning to customers about the broken software), which can only be played with software created by dedicated fans who receive a sum total of zero dollars for making Bethesda's product workable for them. What a despicable company.

number of helpful: 33 of 61 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Although I'm a dear fan to the Fallout series, I cannot bring myself to recommend this game to ANYONE until they read what I'll say about the game. And if, but only if, you can read through all the faults of the game and still want it, then I would recommend it.The story for Fallout3 is something that starts out interesting. You begin as a small child to explore the world and quickly progress through your life until your father decides to hop on out of your life. This will lead you to begin your search through the wasteland in hopes of finding your father and question why he left. Sadly this fresh new idea will leave you scratching your head by the end of the game wondering why over and over again. More than once you find yourself 'ambushed' and cutscened away unable to do anything. Othertimes you'll find yourself facing a decision where you cannot, CANNOT, choose the most reasonable option just because. Although the main story is full of these moments, I often found myself in side-quests almost slackjawed in awe at some of the situations the game placed me in. So while the main story is lackluster, there are some interesting side-quests within the game that can make up for the main story.Combat. Oh lord, the combat for this game. You have literally two options to pick from either you A.) Shoot thousands of rounds at an enemy until they die or B.) Use VATS to instantly vaporize your opponent with no problems. And although many might argue with my description of the combat, clearly these people have never played melee runs or min-maxed their talent points properly to become completely broken. Overall it's combat falls flat just like the TES Bethesda games which require you to simply click your Mouse 1 button enough times. Sadly dialogue with other characters often falls flat and you'll find yourself in a stale world where I truly felt ALONE despite being around ten or so characters.I really cannot say anything bad about the soundtrack, most of the game consisted of real world songs which were all fantastic for their time and fit in with the atmosphere that Fallout 3 has to offer.Overall the game suffers from a poor story with terrible gameplay mechanics, where the side-quests and looting seem to be the only redeeming features of the game.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Out of any company that could've gotten the rights to the Fallout franchise it had to be Bethesda, the company notorious for dumbing down the Scrolls series, Fallout was once an intricate RPG that focused on character progression, decision making that actually had an impact on the world around you, deep interaction with NPC's and using tactics to overcome tough disadvantages.Fallout 3 is nothing more than an action game in an open world, with barely any RPG elements at all besides for upgrading your players stats everytime you level up, which have no consequence as to how your game plays out seeing as it's so damn easy in any case, as you basically role play as Superman which allows you to put little regard in thought when it comes to building your character.The decision making, which is an extremely massive part in every true RPG's soul, has been narrowed down to "Good guy/Bad guy" decisions rather than offering you multiple options, each which have a consequential impact minor or big that make you feel more involved with the world. The plot, another important aspect of RPG, is as generic and un-inspired as they come, a 12 year old could've written this.In Fallout 3 there is NEVER any sense of danger, ever, you can traverse from one end of the map to the other with ease, unlike the older games in which travelling was a major risk and each encounter felt like it could be your last. I really hope they're using a better team for Fallout 4 because if it's anything like this dumbed down generic open world FPS it's going to stink, if you really want to play a modern Fallout, I'd suggest you play New Vegas, they attempt to fix most of the issues in this mess otherwise you're better off playing Fallout 1 and 2.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												While I am not entirely sure about Windows 7 32bit and Windows Vista 32 bit, but I can tell you this game does run on Windows 7 64bit and Vista 64 bit.  1.  Go to the "Documents\My Games\Fallout3" directlory in your user account.2. Open the file "FALLOUT.INI" file using a text editor (preferably WordPad).  3.  On the Keyboard press Ctrl+F and look fo the line "bUseThreadedAI=0" (without quotes) and replace it with "bUseThreadedAI=1"4.  ***IMMEDIATELY BELOW THE LINE IN STEP 3*** add the following WITHOUT quotes "iNumHWThreads=n" and REPLACE "n" with the number of cores your CPU has.5.  Exit wordpad and save changes when prompted to.6.  In your steam library, Right-click on Fallout 3 and browse the local files of the game.7.  Right click on "Fallout3.exe" and got to the "Compatibility" Tab and check "Run progream as an administrator", "Disable display scaling on high DPI", and "Run this program in compatibility mode" and select Which ever version of Windows XP your OS lets you select.8.  Do the same thing you did in Step 7 to "FalloutLauncher.exe"And there you have it :-)

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												One of my most favorite games. First of all lets get this out of the way. The game is old, and the graphics aren't the best. But Bethesda doesn't care about graphics in their games. They care about the world and the story, and how free you are. You walk around post nuclear Washington DC. Being the good guy, bad guy, dude who doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing care, or whatever you can come up with.  The game never ceases to remind you of how ♥♥♥♥ed everything is. And some of the most interesting quests in rpgs come from this game. There are very few repetitive quests, unless you find the game mechanics repetitive (talking, walking, shooting.)  Another elephant I want to get out of the way; there is no aim-down-sights or sprint, and the game is not very immersive (due to bugs mostly.) But thanks to being on the pc, you don't have to worry about most bugs (game breaking ones, ones that make you reload to the last save because you are stuck in space), due to mods! ADS, sprinting, and bug fixes out the♥♥♥♥♥(for modding tutorials, I suggest gopher on youtube.) Basically after playing this game again just using about 2 or 3 mods, I realized what a jewel fallout 3 is, it gets you attached to things very easily, but mostly things like Megaton, robots, that black lady who gives you stimpacks, Hobo McDirtFace, even♥♥♥♥♥♥like teddy bears (if you have hoarding problems this game doesn't help.) But one thing you don't get attached to is your dad. I mean the story is engrossing but you don't really see much of him. Liam Neeson voices him but he only has about 30 or so lines because the amount of times you see is slim. You look for your dad half the game and you would suggest Bethesda to do something with the talent they had. All in all, great game, mods make it better. I tried to make this review trying not to be a parrot, but some things I think are shared opinions.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is a 2008/09 post-apocalyptic role-playing game that takes place in desolate wasteland of Washington DC. You play as the Lone Wanderer, who travels on a journey to find your Father (voiced by Liam Neeson) in the wasteland. Leaving Vault 101 takes personal risks and responsibility. Would you do the same?Fallout 3 starts in the year, 2277, 200 years after the Resource War (United States versus China in a fight for remaining sources on Earth) ended suddenly due to atomic weaponry inflicting against the United States and the rest of the world. Washington DC takes the most damage due to its strategic and political significance. The question remains: What was your Father’s intention to leave Vault 101? The main story is good though some people argued that the plot is decent. In my perspective, the plot is typical and good. It’s not the best or have a strong presentation, but it’s good overall. The real reason for playing Fallout 3 has to be exploration and doing major side quests. Exploring the unknown world of post-apocalyptic Washington DC feels so amazing and worrisome at the same time. These two emotions is what makes the game feel so great. The setting is unpredictable. You may find an abandoned settlement that has a mysterious past,  reading journal entries on what caused a location to fall apart, or some batsh*t crazy thing comes to you when you almost finish investigating an area. The gameplay is primarily first-person or third-person shooter that place strong emphasis on your gameplay type. You can go guns blazing, get a companion and do some killing, conduct stealth and light skirmishes, or just explore alone in the Capital Wasteland. What makes Fallout 3’s gameplay a bit special is the V.A.T.S (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) where you “paused” the game while targeting an enemy’s legs, arms, equipped weapon, and the head. The feature is pretty nice and does help you in dire situations. However, it’s a bit unfortunate that V.A.T.S makes the game paused and not real-time. The stealth mechanic is a mixed bag. You can practically invest a lot of points towards the Stealth skill to make your stealth “level” to what suits you. If your Stealth skill is low then the enemy will “automatically” notice you even when the enemy is not facing you and you are crouch-walking towards an unsuspected enemy. What frustrates me the most was that there is no iron sight or aiming down your equipped weapon. Aiming is mostly useless and “hip-fire” the equipped weapon seems to be what’s best. Is there criticisms for Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition? Fallout 3 is definitely not perfect. There are a lot of technical issues and bugs that Bethesda Games Studios neglected. Many PC users now have Windows 7, 8/8.1, and Windows 10 and a high majority will most likely have an major technical issue that can or cannot be fixed. The games does crash to desktop in modern PC architecture due to no support of multi-core processing (when the game came out, it was dual-core). The solution is there to fix it, but it does not fully bandage the problem. The NPCs look stale, but mods do help make it better. The most critical aspect of the game is the karma system. In a post-apocalyptic setting, any person would know that there’s no (or little) black-or-white scenarios. The karma system is a good concept, but heavily flawed since conducting bad “actions” like stealing or pickpocketing is treated like a horrid sin.The review sounds critical but why does it gives a thumbs up? The answer is simple: It is fun. I remembered when I got the Fallout 3 Collector’s Edition back in October 2008 (where you get the concept art book, featurette DVD, the vault boy bobblehead, and a lunchbox (yes, an actual lunchbox). Fallout 3 crash to desktop so often that I’ve lost count. For some reason, I didn’t too angry about it (even though I should have). Fallout 3 was the first video game that I actually got so immersive to. The setting draws you in and exploration is so much fun. Fallout 3 is one of a very few games that gameplay matters over graphics and “minor” flaws. Does the sequels like Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 4 improved over Fallout 3? Certainly. Fallout 3’s default price is at $19.99 (for Game of the Year Edition). I’ve strongly recommend (for those who haven’t play Fallout 3) to get it on a steep discount of -75% ($5 USD or regional equivalent) since the game faces technical issues on today’s PC systems. Fallout 3 is certainly not top-tier game (when looking at it today), but the game was a marvelous achievement for a first-person shooter to be in an open-world setting.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												You are born in the vault, and you'll die in the vault. That is until you go out into the Wasteland, to die out there instead. And instead of dying by the hands of old age, or some incurable disease, you will die by the hands of Deathclaws and Super Mutants, or maybe you'll be too busy reloading to stop time and take a stimpack.This game is like a ghoul, old but still alive. The fact that it is on Steam (and playable with a quick patching) shows this. I, for one stopped playing Fallout 3 for ages, and then when buying it on Steam I somehow played for over 70 hours, without even realising it.There are so many ways to play this game, some can choose to be good, evil, neutral or even differing between them. Almost every quest has an optional (or even a few optional) choices, to make the decisions and outcomes different depending on who plays it. What ever karma you play as, it always come back to bite you on the rear, even being good can get on someone's bad side. Although being the 'Lone Wanderer' you will never be alone (unless you're in Point Lookout), you will always have Dogmeat following you around, or whatever various companions to fight for you. If fighting for yourself is your thing, Three Dog will always be there to talk about your travels and to play some tunes through the radio. While fighting a Super Mutant, I'm Tickled Pink will play, when scavenging through the Super Duper Mart, Butcher Pete will play, when travelling through the underground metro system, Let's Go Sunning will play and at whatever other inappropriate moment, music will play. Three Dog's voice will become your last source of comfort in a world torn apart from war, in a world made ugly, in a world filled with pain, Three Dog will be there for you.This game will never lose my interest, nor will I ever forget about it. Fallout 3 will always have a place on my consoles (And PC) and in my heart. Throughout the years I will revisit it and fall in love with it all over again, because games, games never change.

content:
Posted: April 24
												Instead of reviewing Fallout 3 itself I'll just list the DLC and why they're great and/or not so great. Operation Anchorage:You find a group of Brotherhood Outcasts attempting to enter a simulation of Operation Anchorage, which was the deciding battle in the war with the Americans and the Chinese. They send you in there and allow you access to the armory before anyone else if you succeed. All and all, great DLC, adds some tactical strategy to the game which can be ignored if you really want to, great loot (although a bit broken, but nothing a mod can't fix) and a lovely story to play. The Pitt: A very dark and gritty industrial city plagued by a disease, and the raider boss has the only cure. You are sent in to infiltrate as a slave and work your way up to meet Ashur, the raider boss that rules the Pitt. What you do from there on out is entirely up to you. Great story, amazing weapons and armor, lots of new places to explore and I must say the aesthetics are very good. It's real eye candy for those who like a post-apocalyptic industrial setting. Broken Steel:Pretty good dlc, adds a decent story line and some good loot. Not as wild as most other DLCs but it fixes some problems people had with the main game (nobody needs to die at the end, can continue playing afterwards). It's quite challenging and pretty badass but not the greatest. Point Lookout:This DLC tries a LOT of things. Yet fails to make ANY of them work out well. The following will contain some spoilers but trust me, you're not missing out. It starts off with you taking the ferry of a nice man to search for treasure in a new area. Once you're there you see what seems like a deformed man with an axe appearing from the mist in the distance as you dock at a pier with a huge ferris wheel. Then I thought this would be a horror-carnival-mist setting. But no, the axe hillbilly is just a random throw-away enemy with hundreds of them in the land, with equally weird misshapen hillbilly friends. There's nothing to do at the pier either, no elaboration on anything encountered so far. So we're told to go to a mansion in the distance. It seemed like a nice place, really fancy, withstood the apocalypse fairly well. Once you enter you encounter Tribals attempting to kill a ghoul who lives in the mansion, and a smart one at that judging by the turrets, cameras, tamed dogs and speakers all over the mansion. Cool I thought, civilisation vs tribes maybe? Nope. Once you're send to infiltrate the tribes you find out they're stupid drooling addicts that had part of their brain removed. Joining them involves the only interesting part of the entire DLC so I won't spoil that. But afterwards you're send to find the leader. And you go to the cave. And it's just a regular guy. Talking to a hologram brain. Apparently the brain was a scientist that has been battling the ghoul from the mansion for centuries. Soon after you find this out you go to the final confrontation, which doesn't even matter because you need to kill one of the two people anyway. So your choice is kill just this guy or both these guys. Remember the hillbillies? No backstory. No funny quotes. Nothing. The tribe? Just scammed idiots. The mansion? Nothing special. The pier and ferris wheel? Used once in the story but not even in an interesting way. This DLC tries SO MUCH. But it fails to deliver even one of them. If anything, get this DLC just to imagine what could have been, it'd be more interesting than the DLC itself. Mothership Zeta:By far the best Fallout DLC in any fallout game so far. Ever seen those aliens in New Vegas with the Wild Wasteland perk? Or Fallout 4's alien? Imagine getting abducted by them. Then exploring their ship. Then becoming the captain of said mothership. Finding lots of alien weapons, sweet robot enemies, fellow abductees like a samurai who was frozen when he was abducted from feudal Japan, and seeing the horrors of Zetan experimentation. It's great I tell you. A must-have for this game. All together, you should have the Game of the Year edition already, and played it already, and why are you still reading go buy this damn game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												While I am not entirely sure about Windows 7 32bit and Windows Vista 32 bit, but I can tell you this game does run on Windows 7 64bit and Vista 64 bit.  1.  Go to the "Documents\My Games\Fallout3" directlory in your user account.2. Open the file "FALLOUT.INI" file using a text editor (preferably WordPad).  3.  On the Keyboard press Ctrl+F and look fo the line "bUseThreadedAI=0" (without quotes) and replace it with "bUseThreadedAI=1"4.  ***IMMEDIATELY BELOW THE LINE IN STEP 3*** add the following WITHOUT quotes "iNumHWThreads=n" and REPLACE "n" with the number of cores your CPU has.5.  Exit wordpad and save changes when prompted to.6.  In your steam library, Right-click on Fallout 3 and browse the local files of the game.7.  Right click on "Fallout3.exe" and got to the "Compatibility" Tab and check "Run progream as an administrator", "Disable display scaling on high DPI", and "Run this program in compatibility mode" and select Which ever version of Windows XP your OS lets you select.8.  Do the same thing you did in Step 7 to "FalloutLauncher.exe"And there you have it :-)

The real reason for playing Fallout 3 has to be exploration and doing major side quests. Exploring the unknown world of post-apocalyptic Washington DC feels so amazing and worrisome at the same time. These two emotions is what makes the game feel so great. The setting is unpredictable. You may find an abandoned settlement that has a mysterious past,  reading journal entries on what caused a location to fall apart, or some batsh*t crazy thing comes to you when you almost finish investigating an area. The gameplay is primarily first-person or third-person shooter that place strong emphasis on your gameplay type. You can go guns blazing, get a companion and do some killing, conduct stealth and light skirmishes, or just explore alone in the Capital Wasteland. What makes Fallout 3’s gameplay a bit special is the V.A.T.S (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) where you “paused” the game while targeting an enemy’s legs, arms, equipped weapon, and the head. The feature is pretty nice and does help you in dire situations. However, it’s a bit unfortunate that V.A.T.S makes the game paused and not real-time. The stealth mechanic is a mixed bag. You can practically invest a lot of points towards the Stealth skill to make your stealth “level” to what suits you. If your Stealth skill is low then the enemy will “automatically” notice you even when the enemy is not facing you and you are crouch-walking towards an unsuspected enemy. What frustrates me the most was that there is no iron sight or aiming down your equipped weapon. Aiming is mostly useless and “hip-fire” the equipped weapon seems to be what’s best. Is there criticisms for Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition? Fallout 3 is definitely not perfect. There are a lot of technical issues and bugs that Bethesda Games Studios neglected. Many PC users now have Windows 7, 8/8.1, and Windows 10 and a high majority will most likely have an major technical issue that can or cannot be fixed. The games does crash to desktop in modern PC architecture due to no support of multi-core processing (when the game came out, it was dual-core). The solution is there to fix it, but it does not fully bandage the problem. The NPCs look stale, but mods do help make it better. The most critical aspect of the game is the karma system. In a post-apocalyptic setting, any person would know that there’s no (or little) black-or-white scenarios. The karma system is a good concept, but heavily flawed since conducting bad “actions” like stealing or pickpocketing is treated like a horrid sin.The review sounds critical but why does it gives a thumbs up? The answer is simple: It is fun. I remembered when I got the Fallout 3 Collector’s Edition back in October 2008 (where you get the concept art book, featurette DVD, the vault boy bobblehead, and a lunchbox (yes, an actual lunchbox). Fallout 3 crash to desktop so often that I’ve lost count. For some reason, I didn’t too angry about it (even though I should have). Fallout 3 was the first video game that I actually got so immersive to. The setting draws you in and exploration is so much fun. Fallout 3 is one of a very few games that gameplay matters over graphics and “minor” flaws. Does the sequels like Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 4 improved over Fallout 3? Certainly. Fallout 3’s default price is at $19.99 (for Game of the Year Edition). I’ve strongly recommend (for those who haven’t play Fallout 3) to get it on a steep discount of -75% ($5 USD or regional equivalent) since the game faces technical issues on today’s PC systems. Fallout 3 is certainly not top-tier game (when looking at it today), but the game was a marvelous achievement for a first-person shooter to be in an open-world setting.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Fallout 3 is a wonderful change into 3-D. I found some of the character animations a little stiff, but nothing too bad. I enjoyed a lot of the comedy within the game, with all the 50's goodness on a perfect America. A lot of the decisions didn't make a difference in most of the dialogue options, Which is a let down, but when it did I was happy that my choice actually mattered. The shooting in this game is down right broken without leveling up your skills, unless you use V.A.T.S for most of your combat. After I got my small-gun skill to about 90 the combat was a lot more enjoyable. I found most of the wasteland, just boring to look at with nothing interesting happening other than some enemies here or there, but maybe that's the point. I think some weather or something would have been nice. The story starts off rather slow and uninteresting, but gets a lot better nearing the end of the game. The music didn't standout for me, unlike The Elderscrolls series (This isn't talking about the music on the radio, Which I didn't even know you could listen to on your pip-boy until after I finished the game). Over-all I really did enjoy the game and would recommend this game to anyone a fan of The Elderscrolls series or post-apocalyptic games. I do want to add this game crashes A LOT, but I was able to get through the game just fine without being set back a whole lot, thanks to it's auto-saving.4/5 - Wonderful

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												It's been years since I first played this game, back on Xbox 360. Back then, I loved it, and I enjoyed coming back to the DC wasteland and find new locations to explore. More importantly, it's the game that introduced me to what is now one of my favorite franchises, and I have a healthy dose of nostalgia for it.But holy hell, the passage of time hasn't been kind to Fallout 3. I would not recommend playing it today unless you are ready to sit down and mod it for a few hours just to get it to run.Graphically, I think it actually kind of holds up, and the capital wasteland still has a certain beauty and charm that the Mojave desert and the Commonwealth didn't quite manage to capture. Characters look like potatoes but don't completely distract from the experience. Musically, it's quite good. The new direction for the ambient music is great, if not as dark and chilling as the Fallout1 and 2 soundtracks. The radio's a brilliant element and GNR and Enclave Radio both have a solid, if unsubtle ("Do you get it this game is about the APOCALYPSE ?!") choice of themes.Technically, it's a mess. Glitchy as hell, difficult to run on modern hardware and operating systems, yet surprisingly stable once you actually get it to run. This is why I said the years haven't been kind to Fallout 3. In terms of gameplay, it's the second most shallow entry in the series behind Fallout 4, and the gunplay and gun selection is downright terrible by modern standards. Heck, even back then, the lack of ironsights made it a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥to play and the spread of some weapons is unfrigginbelievable, even with a gun skill of 100. You'll spend most of your time shooting things and the combat is terrible, so...yeah.But the cherry on top of the cake is the absolutely atrocious writing of the main quest and most sidequests. Thanks Emil. Back when I first played the game, I kind of tuned out the story because it was so boring, with a lot of rude and uninteresting characters who make stupid decisions all the time. Oh, and of course there's next to no choice in this game, because that's absolutely not something Fallout is known for, right ?And yet, despite all my criticisms, I still bought the game and played through the whole story again. Is it nostalgia ? Is it the dumb fun of exploring the ruins of a blasted wasteland ? Probably both. Regardless, Fallout 3 is still worth playing through at least once, for shitz and giggles if nothing else.

Fallout 3, My oh my. I've been meaning to do this review for quite some time, never got around to finishing until now.Your in a post-apocalyptic world filled with radiation monsters and every minute is key for survival.PROS+Almost Too much to do.And when I say there is too much to do. I mean there is soooo much to do you'll have to put things in a hat to decide what to do first.+ModdingThis game can be modded to infinity making heaps of replayability and even with some really unique mods.+VATSI've heard of a lot criticism when it comes to VATS but I actually really enjoyed (mostly because I have terrible aim.) I thought it brought a lot of strategy then your typical FPS.+DLC!If you get the GOTY edition you get 5 DLC all with there original story-line and even MORE stuff to do!CONS-SlowNow I get that this game is set to be in a wasteland and that it's meant to represent the emptiness in that but seriously, without Quick-travel I don't think I could have completed it. (Atleast Oblivion/Skyrim had horses)-Dat EndingNo spoilers here but that ending was less fufilling than a happy meal at Mcdonalds-OptimizationNot really a con but this game doesn't play nice with Windows 7. there is an easy way around it though.FInal Notes and Score-This game has been out for so long and been praised i'm surprised if you still haven't played this game. GO GET IT.-I haven't played it but most people would agree that New Vegas is much better than Fallout 3.-This game has a total of 73 Hours with the Main Story and Extras and a whopping 107 Hours if your completionist. Is that something worth your money? Yes.Final Score: 8.5/10

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												From elsewhere:Having heard this game was just "Oblivion with guns" I waited for over a year to finally get it, as Oblivion, though an ambitious project, failed to excite me much beyond being able to go anywhere I wanted (until 2 hours later). I didn't have much hope for this game, but I really want to like it regardless; having been a fan of the original Fallout games since their release over a decade ago. With this love of the series, I tired (I really _really_ tired) to like this game. Like Oblivion, I spent a lot of time on it (70+ hours on my initial play through, less on other characters), dissected it, and tried all I could. Did it stack up? In a few insignificant ways yes, but mostly no.What does this game do right? Quite a bit that I found quite good, Traveling around the wastes (for a while) and making Steal/Sneak-Traps/Explosives into one skill and the Repair is actually useful now. But with these positives come big negatives from the character development angle.For starters:Charisma and Speech. Utterly useless. Yes, it's nice you can reach a compromise between Hightower and the Ghouls, and yeah, you can talk to Autumn at the end (of the pre DLC game) and convince him to leave without needing to exchange fire, but beyond that, there aren't many opportunities to use diplomacy. Further more, there are little experience rewards for playing diplomatic, aside from poor returns from quests and disarming mines and picking the occasional lock.Bad dialogue options, voice acting, not one memorable character, and forgettable plot. From a writing perspective, this game is extremely lackluster. Yes, there are more options available in speech, but most options are interchangeable and/or have no real effect anyway. It would have been a nice touch if you could talk your father out of trying to make you kill the radroach, but alas, like many other points in the game and DLC, many possibilities for a varied play through are utterly ignored. Coupled with all this they dumbed down one of the best aspects of RPGs with an Intelligence skill: playing a role of someone with limited cranial capacity (perhaps they were too lazy to write more dialogue trees? avoid controversy with Palin?). Role playing games should all offer this as it allows for the player to actually role play. Sneak is a very gimped skill that doesn't work like it should as the AI has an uncanny ability to randomly discover you even if you're in a dark room, crouched-walking, wearing light clothing, and avoiding doing anything that would generate any noise. Many times I end up having to just run around, taking shots like a bullet sponge, and dealing with X object while under fire. Stealth only seems to have a use in combat as it increase damage on the initial hit, but other than that, this skill like many others is just a waste. The game, in effect, favors combat, and luckily, at least for unarmed/melee/Energy/Small Guns it is quite balanced. This would be fine if the shooting mechanics were good, however, like Oblivion, combat is greatly stunted.The dream of being able to be a lone wanderer of the wastes, sniping from great distances was shattered. Other than the rifle "Ol' Painless" almost all of the guns are painfully inaccurate, but at least targeting parts of the body actually affects the enemy (if you can make contact). On top of this, the shooting as a whole feels utterly unresponsive. Bullets will often not go in the direction you intend, and often hit random invisible walls. Further more, the damage done by a lot of guns (at least in the beginning) are so lackluster that it feels like throwing a gun would do more harm. After experiencing these huge flaws, I only then understood why VATS was included in the game: to bring at least some certainty to combat.So the guns suck, but what about melee and my beloved unarmed skill? The use of these combat traits are so shallow, that playing with that induces mind-numbing boredom. Had they implemented a parry/disarming system, something, anything beyond a ineffectual block and attack buttons this aspect of combat could have made this otherwise "bleh" game decent. So the combat is terrible and unrewarding. In addition to that, the enemy A.I. is just plain terrible. They always rush forward, never seeking cover, or taking careful aim. I lost count of how many times an enemy blew him/herself up with a rocket launcher (especially since it is so easy to exploit as well).Bad writing, bad role playing, bad combat; what does this game do well? Traveling... but only for a bit. Having visited every location on all the maps, I can easily say that this aspect is just a repeat of Oblivion. Yes there are a lot of places to go, but after you've seen one subway, you've seen them all. So much so, you'll begin to dread entering them simply because you know you've already seen the same trash pile next to the same ticket office with the same "feral ghouls" running around.The DLC summarized:Anchorage; a terribly short and lame, guns-a-blazing, "mod." The only cool thing to come out of it is the stealth suit, but even with it, stealth skill sucks. Simply forgettable, and is a sign of how they simply forgot the option to try to play this DLC in a "less-than-lethal" manner. All you have is a linear map and dumb enemies. You've played this, and it was called (almost) EVERY FPS EVER MADE. Except those had better shooting mechanics (even the sprite based ones that ran off the Wolf 3D/Doom engines). The Pitt; outside of the Trog designs, it's just "bleh." All reward items are just uninteresting. Another thing that is silly about this DLC is that it supposedly had a lot of moral gray-area. Let me spoil it for you: the leader of the Pitt has a baby who is the "key" to curing the aliments of the slaves there. Your choice is to leave the child with its parents, or kill them and take the child to the slaves. Where is the dilemma? Taking a child from a privileged life (after butchering her family) and taking it to unlikable characters, or keep the baby with its unlikable parents? Personally, drilling out the baby's brains to get to a "cure" would be a better way to really challenge your perception of what is a moral decision. Baby's life versus the life of several hundred people as opposed to terrible people who are the parents. Broken Steel; it's nice you can opt to destroy the Brotherhood, but it doesn't lead anywhere. You can't fully join the enclave and have a differently branching storyline. It, like everything about Fallout 3, is just too linear and not completely realized.Point Look Out; other than the accurate depictions of swamp/southern people, everything about this DLC seems half-done.Mothership Zeta; linear mess that introduces more uninteresting items and characters.All in all, this game is a wreak. Hell, it even crashed constantly while playing it (more than Oblivion, which is amazing). Mods can't save this. I want my $50 back.Edit:I wanted to revisit this game to see if my opinion has changed, and it consistently crashes (5 times) during the loading screens making this game unplayable on my current computer (the same I used to play New Vegas and Skyrim with no problem).

content:

												A truly epic adventure--an absolute stellar collaboration of FPS and RPG experiences. The vast open landscape allows unhindered exploration. The game offers a wealth of NPC characters, each having their own distinct personalities opening or limiting choices based on how you interact with them. The story conversations go far beyond simple dialog, offering players deep and rich character development. There's even multiple paths/outcomes depending on the choices you make throughout the game. Multitudes of different monster types and weapons. While the story and side missions are enough to keep anyone busy for hours on end, the DLCs are well integrated and keep the game fresh for many more.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Now why can't the actual capital look like the Capital Wasteland? I was so enthralled with this game, so immersed in it (obsessively so) that when I had the opportunity to work in DC I looked forward to seeing my favorite Fallout 3 haunts unblemished. Granted, there was repair scaffolding encasing the Washington Monument, but it was much more intact than the Fallout 3 counterpart. Every time I went into the subway I would be filled with glee to see that structurally the platform areas are remarkably similar, and that the only things I was missing were Feral Ghouls and derailed subway cars.The environment is open, although not necessarily inviting. It's a world alive, with Mole Rats, Mirelurks, Death Claws, Super Mutants, Ghouls, and your garden variety people. The weapons are varied and eccentric at times. Whether you choose to dispatch your enemy with the mundane: shotgun, assault rifle, or pistol; the overpowered: Mini Gun, Flamer, or Fat Man; or the custom built: Railway Rifle, Bottlecap Mine, or Rock-It Launcher. (My personal fave is the Rock-It Launcher, because nothing says you need a hug more than a high velocity teddy bear to the skull.) The main quest can get kind of stale the 3rd or 4th time through the game, but since there are numerous side quests and a sizable map to explore it takes awhile to get old. I enjoy the Karma system in the game and the gentle reminders that gunning down the innocent and sleeping in someone else's bed while they stand there is somehow detrimental to my Karma in the Wastes. I also enjoy the leveling system, choosing where to allocate my skill points and pondering over perks like Puppies and Bloody Mess. Fallout 3 is an incredible game. It can be as fast or slow of a game as you make it. You can rush through, playing only the main quest, and miss out on fascinating things like the Nuka Cola tour and finding the Oasis of the Wastes. With all of the DLC that was added there is so much to explore, examine, and decimate. Fallout 3 is my "go to" game. My fallback when I'm bored of everything else that I have. I've played through the main storyline about 3 times so far and I find new areas to explore and side quests that I haven't done a number of times. The DLC  is engaging and, with the exception of one, I find them all great fun. Sometimes I play to be the good gal, sometimes I play the bad girl. There are so many ways to craft your character through gameplay, that you can have a different person every time. The story draws you in, like a choose your own adventure book, and you decide how it ends. Megaton or Tenpenny? See you out there in the Wasteland, lone wanderer. I'll be the one scrounging up toy cars, teddy bears, and bent tin cans because it's dangerous out here. You never know who's going to need a hug.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												Fallout 3 was revolutionary in it's time. Daring to move away from the past installment's sky-view strategy look and gameplay, Fallout 3 moves up into the era of the first person shooter. "War, War never changes." It has been 200 years since the bombs fell. In the year 2077, following the battle for the last remaining natural resources, involving China, the USA, and the USSR, thousands of nuclear missiles landed throughout the world. Those who could afford it locked themselves away in underground vaults, which would not open until the radiation subsided. You have left Vault 101, your home since you were born, in search of your father. You are the Lone Wanderer, venturing the wastes and ruins of Washington DC, now named The Capital Wasteland. A heavy atmosphere looms as the story progresses, pushing you further into something more then just finding your father and unknown past. How do you battle the horrors of the wastes? Do you rush in with the Super Sledge, slither past and pick them off from afar, or do you hold your ground in power armor with the mighty Gatling Laser? Fallout 3 allows you to play it how you want, when you want. Rush into the thick of things or mosey along with the hundreds of side quests avaliable? From helping ghouls find a home to fighting The Antagonizer alongside The Mechanist and his army of Protectretron Robots to uncovering the secrets of your past, Fallout 3 is one of the true RPGs ever made. For an added bonus: compare screenshots of your journey through the ruins of D.C. with real life photos of D.C. today and see how similar they look. Hopefully the world doesn't have to fight over resources within the next 100 years.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												Please don't look at the time I've allegedly spend playing this game, since Steam, for some reason, does not register it at all. "Fallout 3" is one of those games, that I can recommend without any doubts. I know that there are fans of Fallout 1&2 out there, who do not like the changes within game mechanics, but I would say that it's perfectly normal - when something that we really enjoy change a lot, we usually react badly. I did not play any previous "Fallout", so I judge this as a standalone game. And what a great game it is. Pros:+ music + open world with tons of locations, secrets, references, memorable characters and pretty much everything else that you would like to see in the game like this+ plot - some people say that it's the worse part of the game, but for me plot was good enough+ player's stats that can unlock new dialogue options (not only charisma, but strength or perception), that actually make a difference (for example allows us to avoid fight)+ perks are awesome. You can use your experience points to raise one of your stats or just add new skills (not only combat related. You can unlock perk that increase the gore effect, allows you to easily influence other gender or children, add new dialogue options and that's only the beginning)+ pretty good morality system, that influence the way that some characters in the game treat us (and if potential companions will be interested in joining forces with us)+ there are always at least two ways to solve each quest (and quite often more)+ humor - dark and grotesque, it fits this game very well+ moddable (it's easy and there are quite a lot "Fallout 3" mods out there)+ lore, atmosphere and atmosphere once again. Choosing your hair, mustache, perks, quests, dialogues, creatures - everything fit perfectly into the Fallout world.Cons:- DLC are not interesting at all. Beside possibility of gaining 30 level, there's not much to them. You can't bring your companions on extra adventures. What is worse, they can be very challenging and sometimes you don't have a chance to properly prepare yourself. Some people may find them enjoyable, for me they were annoying and definitely too long.- no sprint option- map can be very disorienting - if you're playing for the first time and don't really know what you're doing, you may get easily frustrated, trying to follow map markers and ending up nowhere- there's not to much difference to buildings or rooms layouts. It's pretty easy to get lost in bigger locations.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.GL HF ;D

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Mmmm Fallout 3....Where to start. Ok so I bought this game on PS3 and Xbox 360 the year it came out which was 2008. Played the hell out of both of them. Then they started releasing DLC and it got even better. Fast forward about a year or so to when I got my first gaming PC. Bought the game again, this time Game of the Year Edition. Was blown away again from 60fps and no lag at all. The game revolves around a teenage kid (you) who is searching for their father in the wide open wasteland of DC. There are over 100 locations without DLC and even more with it. The game should take you 40-50 hours first playthrough if you are just a casual player. However if you're a completionist like myself, then you'll probably be playing for around 100 or so hours. There are tons of things to do in this game with and without mods/dlc. Thats the joy of it, each playthrough will be different. On one character you might focus more on melee weapons while you might focus on guns on another. This is one of the only games that I'd truly rate a 10/10. I read some reviews and some people were saying "DAE WINDOWS 7/8 DOESNT WORK" I laugh at these people because they are either not tech savvy at all or just being ridiculous. I have had windows 7 for 3+ years and windows 8 since release an I have not had a single problem at all. The game has only crashed a handfull of times in ovver 5 years. Its kind of sad how people are being lied to with the reviews. This game runs perfectly fine. This game is well worth the money even today. This game still competes with Skyrim and is one of the most Amazing games I have ever purchased.So overall this game deserves a 10/10 and is a "Must Play"

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Fallout 3 is one of my alltime favorite Games. Top 5 definitely.While New Vegas is technically better, it's athmosphere is not nearly as stunning as Fallout 3's.  Mainly because it (NV) takes place in a boring desert and the amazing world-after-nuclear-war-feeling of Fallout 3 is almost completely gone.Also the story isn't nearly as good imho...After one of the most amazing intros ever, Fallout 3 comes up with a good story (not as bad as it's often said) and one hell of a wasteland to explore. As always in  Bethesda RPG the story leaves you with a lot of world still to explore on your own. DLC ,apart from the ridiculous Operation Anchorage (aka CoD for the very poor), are very good as well. And while it runs well on (todays) mediocre hardware, it doesn't look too bad. Even without mods. Of which i would strongly advise however at least the simple "mtui". It makes fonts in dialog options smaller (designed for the old non-hd xbox) so that you have 5 or 6 instead of 3 answering options (in ridiculously big letters) visible without scrolling. It's  "installed" by simply copying one file into the data-folder.And the one which gets rid of the horrible and now defunct "games for windows live".Lightning mods, Texture packs, balance-changing and more-npc mods are also available.The place to go, with free registration needed for bigger files, is http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/It's even worth 19€,$ or whatever, but when it is on sale there is simply no excuse for not buying it :)PS: Sadly Fallout 3 is incredibly tricky to get to work under Win7/10. If you own both Fallout 3 and New Veags, you may try the Tales of two wastelands - mod wich makes Fallout 3 run in the Fallout New Vegas Engine, which is a LOT less problematic on newer Windows'

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												After playing this game many years later than when it came out, I have to say that I enjoyed Fallout 3 quite a bit, including the DLC. The game itself has a pretty nice story and is actually challenging at first when you have nothing and don't know the controls too well. The massiveness of the open-world and the explroation really contribute to the game's wonder. Like the Fallout series are marked by, there are multiple ways to complete quests and there are quests everywhere. Once oyu get to a certain level you can even get explorer perk which allows you to see all the locations on the map. Go find everything and enjoy the game.Another thing is that you can mod the game and replay the game in a differnet style in a similar sense to skyrim. You can mod the things you dont like or the bugs and even other major things. I played as a goody-two-shoes in my first playthrough and I intend to play as a villian in my second one. The replayability isn't as great as some games, but with mods and a different play style, one can enjoy the game once again. Overall, a good game people should own.Rating: 8.9/10

												If you asked me what my favourite game series is, I would answer Fallout. So far I have not tried Fallout 4 yet, have to say I love Fallout 3 as well as Fallout: New Vegas.The most impressive thing is that Fallout 3 is a continuation of life: you can easily spend a half of a day by organising your inventory, speaking with strangers and making your relationships. Being very realistic, you can do whatever you want and cannot allow yourself in real life on the other hand. I also like to walk everywhere without completing any tasks, just for my pleasure, collecting the dresses, hats, guns and unique items.Listing pros may take forever. The only contra is that the game needs a huge amount of free time.

content:
Posted: January 11
Quickly :  Score 18/20   Gameplay 17/20   Lifespan 19/20   Scenario 15/20   Soundtrack 18/20   Graphics 15/20  Score isn't the mathematical average, but more of a general appreciation mark for the gameExtra blabla :Bethesda's very own attempt to produce a follow up to FO2. Well we're far from FO2's depth. But yeah that's still a great game, the fact that i discovered it when i was young prob makes a difference, and influences my judgement about it ! Gave me some amazing memories .Scenario is good, but we're far from the previous game's standards ... Pretty primitive and generic plot, with okay characters.When it comes to the game's world, it's rich content-wise , that's undeniable and overall it has a decent amount of details.Meh you know what ? Just imagine Oblivion in a Post-Apo setting, with automatic weapons, add some more crudeness to it,  rough language with the possibility to dismember ppl and here ya go , you sort of have Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Okay, well Fallout 4 came out yesterday and I pre-ordered it on xbox one, bad me, I know. But good me because I hear the PC port sucks, really bad. So I figure some folks bought Fallout 4 and want to try Fallout 3, because they want to get the bad taste out of their mouths or love it and want to play the game that started the fps version of it all. Well this review is for beginners of the Fallout franchise because I'm what you'd call a verteran, I've played all the games except those brotherhood of steel spin offs that suck, but they aren't considered games. By the way ths is spoiler free so enjoy. I wake up in a vault on my 2nd playthrough on PC, since I was good last time I want to be evil. Now the vault is a whole can of worms that are actually the evil that are known as spoilers so I'll just tell you some things I did for fun in the vault. I took off all my clothes and danced on a table at my birthday party after insulting a bully's mother. I got a BB gun and shot my dad until he fell unconcious and then took a picture with him, still unconcious. I shot a bunch of security guards, killed the overseer, and laughed in a girl's face after killing her dad. I then arose from the vault as a twelve year old boy would arise in the morning freaking out on the release day of Fallout 4. I went to a nearby settlement and improved my vault suit, making it 101 armor? I made a promise to some lousy sherrif to disarm a nuke in town square. I went into the town bar and promised a guy I would help him activate the nuke and blow up the town after having some fun with it and getting an evil companion in it. I went upstairs in the bar/hotel and killed all of the people sleeping in their beds with my baseball bat. (A lot of them are essential NPC's, yes you can kill almost anyone in Fallout 3 with the exception of your dad and a few others out of an entire world of characters.) I blew up the town after getting some info where to find my dad on the bar owner's computer, who I also killed whilst he was sleeping. I helped a radio broadcaster with his radio dish then proceeded to kill him to gain my evil karma back like I do with all good quests which I only do for the experience, I can't talk about anything else now because it's not spoiler friendly so I'll talk about a couple of side quests you can do in the game. Become a member of a tree cult and talk to a giant tree, that's actually a mutant from the second game (Fallout 2) named Harry. After the game if you have broken steel you decisions actually matter as you see what happened when normal players had to end the game. You can help some slaves liberate the lincoln memorial of slavers so they can live in the lincoln memorial. You can help a human hating ghoul assassinate humans. You can help a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ get to Rivet city. You can destroy a giant military base full of american patriot soldiers. You can get a mini nuke launcher and blow up a giant behemoth. (That last one wasn't a quest itself, but it was part of one, and it was really cool.) This game is so immersive, and unlike Fallout 4 (which I love.) You're not playing as the character who lost his son, no, you're playing as you. 10/10 buy this game now.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												If you have Windows 10 you will have to go to the microsoft market place and down load thier 36Mb PC client  http://www.xbox.com/en-US/Live/PC/DownloadClient. Then go to your steam and find your Fallout3 game from your Steam library. Right mouse click the games name in your Library then go to Properties. Then go to Local files. Then click Browse Local files. Go down to the Icon that says Fallout3 with the guys face. Not the Fallout. EXE and not the FalloutLauncher. Right Click on the Fallout3 icon go to Properties go to Compatibility then click Run as Administrator. Your good to go under Windows 10. You do NOT have to pick a Compatibility mode. Jut make sure Run as Administrator is checked you dont need to pick a different OS type to play the game. If you dont have the Microsoft market place PC client installed it wont work at all. Easies fix to get Fallout3 to work under Windows 10 & Pro.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												The best things that I have to say about Fallout 3 all have to do with how they handled the atmosphere, backstory and location. Setting FO3 in DC was a great choice, what better place to set a Fallout story? They really captured the Fallout feeling with this game but it's clear they put a different spin on it. It has more of a hopeful feeling instead of the darker, horror like sound that Mark Morgan brought to the first 2, which I liked a lot but I think I like Inon Zur's work better. Fallout 3 does a great job at fleshing out the world too, some of the best stories you'll see in this game are found in the computer terminal logs and random notes you'll find, they did a great job with those and clearly put a lot of work into them.         The main quest is overall hit or miss but will possibly leave you feeling frustrated if you don't have broken steel dlc. I didn't like it, I think the concept is good even though it's pretty clear they took it from Fallout Tactics, it could've been executed a lot better and it definiately felt forced. The DLC is one of my favorite things about this one, Point Lookout is one of my favorite locations in the series so far, the Pitt and Anchorage are also great. My biggest complaint about this game is how they copy pasted a few of the critical story moments from the first 2 games and shamelessly took credit for it from people who never played the first 2. A good example of this would be how you get exiled from vault 101 or how they had a settlement based around and inside a tanker.        Overall, it's a good game, I know it's controversial among some sections of the Fallout community and I was kind of on the Fallout 3 hate bandwagon for a while but I think there is a lot of things this game does right that makes it unique from the other entries. I think Bethesda can make a great Fallout game, they just need to put more emphasis on the main quest and lore next time.
