												Fallout 3 is a apocalyptic world with a great story and an awesome variety of mods. There is a modding tool called GECK that allows you to mod textures (buildings, objects, etc...), guns (fire rate, ammo, health, textures, etc...), armor, etc... This game is awesome but do not play this game if you are not into story driven games. 10/10 and well worth the $6.69 USD I paidP.S. content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Fallout 3....       The question is not whether you should buy the game, the question is why you're still reading this review                                         and not buying the game right now.        Welcome to Washington DC, home of completely normal human beings.  Visit destroyed landmarks, flourishing cities, an underground town run by children, an aessload of metro stations, caves infested with mutated crabs, and a hotel converted into a slaver camp.  Here, you can meet all kinds on unsavory figures, from giant, angry, green men who hate militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor, to a group of militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor who hate giant, angry, green men.  You can also wield unique weapons, such as the Firelance, a strange incindiary Alien pistol, to a modified vaccum cleaner that can fire ANYTHING. ANYTHING!!!  Oh yeah, please don't hate the ghouls. Why would you hate the ghouls? TREAT THEM AS EQUALS, DAMMIT!!!Holy craep, I can't even give this game a rating, because whatever the max is, it's just multitplied by ten.100/10 : 1,000/100 : 10,000/1,000

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Fallout 3's easily my favorite installment in the series, hands down. Fallout 2 and New Vegas were fantastic as well, but Fallout 3 had a great mix of the old and the new; it gave an open-world adventure akin to Bethesda's Elder Scrolls, but without compromising the complex nature of the Fallout games. The game may be old, but it aged fantastically IMO, and it's worth a buy.And to those who are having issues with Fallout 3 on Windows 10; I have Windows 10, and I had issues booting this game up, but there's plenty of guides that'll prove to be a godsend on newer systems. Here's what you need to do to get the game running on Windows 10.https://steamcommunity.com/app/22370/discussions/0/541907675756259732/http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?Use the guide and mod in the link to begin your Wasteland Adventure. Be sure to comment to see if it's working for you.TL;DR - This game is fantastic, and it's worth a buy for new Fallout fans. Be sure to get it running, though!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												On Xbox 360 I have 100's if not 1000's of hours I got this to remeber my young teen years. My father is a Jedi Knight, two Gods of Legend, and one of the most Boss orgainizatoinless agents to ever live. I remind myself this in every battle and suddenly I understand why i can take a missle to the face and be smacked by a Behemoth (A 15 foot tall Radioactive muscle of Death) and only suffer some blured vision. As well as be in several explosions without a single mark upon my body. Ever time i play this game i rember the smells of youth that are not around anymore as if they were still here because this game takes me back. This is and RPG where everything is wasteland and you leave your mark on the world you can turn on the radio th hear Three Dog tell of your glorious deeds or less that nice activeties as if he was there himself to see. A game were when all is lost you must leave your mark on the world. And at the end of your main objective a slide show starts retelling your deeds across the wastes (Good or Bad) for you to see as well as the effects that would come long after your dead and gone for you to reflect on every decission you made. Will the Lone Wanderer be the Last Great Hope For Mankind and save who you can or the Reincarnation of Death bringing about the second apocalypse and engulf the world in ashes again for your own amusement because you can. The choice is always yours any time any where upon anyone. 10/10 would relive again.

												On Xbox 360 I have 100's if not 1000's of hours I got this to remeber my young teen years. My father is a Jedi Knight, two Gods of Legend, and one of the most Boss orgainizatoinless agents to ever live. I remind myself this in every battle and suddenly I understand why i can take a missle to the face and be smacked by a Behemoth (A 15 foot tall Radioactive muscle of Death) and only suffer some blured vision. As well as be in several explosions without a single mark upon my body. Ever time i play this game i rember the smells of youth that are not around anymore as if they were still here because this game takes me back. This is and RPG where everything is wasteland and you leave your mark on the world you can turn on the radio th hear Three Dog tell of your glorious deeds or less that nice activeties as if he was there himself to see. A game were when all is lost you must leave your mark on the world. And at the end of your main objective a slide show starts retelling your deeds across the wastes (Good or Bad) for you to see as well as the effects that would come long after your dead and gone for you to reflect on every decission you made. Will the Lone Wanderer be the Last Great Hope For Mankind and save who you can or the Reincarnation of Death bringing about the second apocalypse and engulf the world in ashes again for your own amusement because you can. The choice is always yours any time any where upon anyone. 10/10 would relive again.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												Accidentally detonated an atom bomb in the first town killing dozens of people and injuring many within the area.Lost Karma.Still had max Positive Karma rank.-Note: Read the notice, the game is not optimized for windows 7 or later. Unless you are prepared to spend some time figuring out what to do to make it work then don't buy it. I spent around an hour and finally find the right fix with the fallout_default.ini file.Outside of the optimization problem the game has been very fun. I haven't played too much but so far my impressions have been good. There is a lot to do and the open world is interesting. Side quests are plentiful, weapons and ammo can be found at a normal rate though you may find yourself running out. The best part is, if you have a problem there is probably a mod to fix it.I highly recommend it if you are willing to take the time to get it running.There is the occasional crash but if you remember to quicksave a lot it shouldnt bother you.overall I would say this game is an 7/10 due to the problems with os and crashes

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.GL HF ;D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Mmmm Fallout 3....Where to start. Ok so I bought this game on PS3 and Xbox 360 the year it came out which was 2008. Played the hell out of both of them. Then they started releasing DLC and it got even better. Fast forward about a year or so to when I got my first gaming PC. Bought the game again, this time Game of the Year Edition. Was blown away again from 60fps and no lag at all. The game revolves around a teenage kid (you) who is searching for their father in the wide open wasteland of DC. There are over 100 locations without DLC and even more with it. The game should take you 40-50 hours first playthrough if you are just a casual player. However if you're a completionist like myself, then you'll probably be playing for around 100 or so hours. There are tons of things to do in this game with and without mods/dlc. Thats the joy of it, each playthrough will be different. On one character you might focus more on melee weapons while you might focus on guns on another. This is one of the only games that I'd truly rate a 10/10. I read some reviews and some people were saying "DAE WINDOWS 7/8 DOESNT WORK" I laugh at these people because they are either not tech savvy at all or just being ridiculous. I have had windows 7 for 3+ years and windows 8 since release an I have not had a single problem at all. The game has only crashed a handfull of times in ovver 5 years. Its kind of sad how people are being lied to with the reviews. This game runs perfectly fine. This game is well worth the money even today. This game still competes with Skyrim and is one of the most Amazing games I have ever purchased.So overall this game deserves a 10/10 and is a "Must Play"

content:
Posted: April 9
Product received for free
												OS: Windows 7 UltimateRAM: 24 GBVID-Card: Nvidia GTX-850 TiProcessor: Intel i7 K-875 2.93KHzGraphics: 9/10Gameplay/Character Development: 10/10DLC: 10/10MOD Community: 10/10Audio: 10/10*Sighs wistfully* My first Fallout game, originally played on console (Xbox 360) and so loved that I got it on Steam, complete with the "Game of the Year" (GOTY) edition for the bonus and additional DLC. I also love the fact that Liam Neeson voices your father at the start of the game.I rather loved this game. The whole thing was really great and amongst my favorites. This is "not optimized for Windows 7 and later", but it did, in fact, work on my computer. At my time of writing this, it failed the last time I tried to start it up and, using satellite-based internet, I'll let you know if it still works properly within a month (if you see no change, assume it worked fine and I simply forgot.)Graphics: 9/10My only real disappointment with the graphics of Fallout is how dreary/sad they are, but that's still necessary as it IS a post-apocalyptic game, assuming readying for and the execution of nuclear war around WWI or WWII. I wouldn't have scored it down except that some of the graphics are recurring enough to be repetitive.Gameplay/Character Growth: 10/10I simply adored the chracater growth/development system. You have base stats that affect all your skills, and you gain perks as you continue on that grant you special bonuses, benefits, skills or what have you. In many respects, it's like a less complex version of D&D games or Skyrim and the like. There's a great deal to grow in various directions. Big or small guns, stealth or tank, smart/techy or just crash through things you could otherwise finesse your way around? Etc.DLC: 10/10All the DLC in this game is actually quite fun and nice, introducing a fair bit of information and adding elements, weapons and armors that weren't in the original. In point of fact, Fallout 4 DLC has most of this DLC as IT'S version, simply altered like the same person in a new outfit. The DLC of this game adds several hours of enjoyment.  Its difficult to say much without giving details and spoilers. But all of this is worth that.MOD's: 10/10There are a huge number of mods for this game. Change body types, clothes types, add romantic interaction, sexual interaction, new weapons, homes, shops, equipment, armors, clothes, children, etc. Nothing wierd with the kids mod. It just adds what is generally missing in most RPG games - Kids.Audio: 10/10There are several audio components you can adjust naturally, on top of the MOD's you could use.There are in-game radio stations, most of the music is from the similar era (40's) as when society fell.If you're on a newer computer, I'd suggest getting this on sale or attempting it with a download or something in the off chance your PC won't play it. If you need to, figure out how to run a virtual machine on your computer, or perhaps partition your system and load one with an older operating system. It's really worth it.-Paladeus

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Finished this a few days with 50-60 mods (mostly minor tweaks or aethetic changes), and I must say this game holds well even in 2013.  It took me some time to get into it, as I bought it in july and finished it in december, but once you do get the hang of the game, it's amazing.  Having played Skyrim and Oblivion previously, I will tell you Fallout is the superior game of both of them.  The setting, set in post apocalyptic D.C., is very immersive.  There's very few RPG's that are set in sci-fi or modern places, so this is definitely a gem to anyone who loves RPG but feels worn from fantasy themes.  However, like everything, nothing goes without some gripes.  As much I like guns in an RPG, the vanilla guns seem very lackluster.  I actually had to install weapon mods to add some more customizability.  Number 2 is the game is NOT optimized for quad core CPU's, something most computers have these days.  I can't think of the code from memory, but I had to put in some lines in my FALLOUT.INI to force the game to only use 2 of my cores or else the game would crash every 20 - 30 min. Number 3, is the vanilla character models, animations, and faces are terrible even for its time of release.  If you played Oblivion, those fugly faces are back so mods are essential if you want a decent looking character.   Number 4 --- too many super mutants -- enough said.  Now if you've gotten this far in this review, I will still say that the positives outweigh the negatives because I'm just trying to give everyone a good heads up, and if you managed to enjoy Oblivion or Skyrim, you can ignore half of these 'gripes'.  Everything else is good.  Overall it's a 9/10, so it's worth your money especially when it's $5-10.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Fallout 3 is definitely one of the best game i've ever played, I must have spent over 400 + hours on that game and I'm still not bored of it, there is just so much stuff to do that you end up playing over and over again. There is a large variety of guns, melee weapons, objects to collect, quests, creatures, NPCs, clothes etc.. There is also a lot of areas to explore in which most of the time feels new and fresh, you can even have a house that you can add stuff and themes in. But what makes this game really amazing is the ability to mod it, there is just so much awesome mods to add to this game, and its all free! The game itself takes about 60h minimum if you want to do everything in the game, and another 30h + with the DLCs. The story is also really interesting. And of course like other Bethesda games, you can customize your character to your liking, such as choosing his or her name, gender, appearances etc.. The game also has replay value since you can choose what kind of person you are. You can be a hero that saves lives and kills Super Mutants, or be a psycho killer that blows up towns and kill for caps, your choice! There is also a leveling system with special perks for your character and skills developement, which i thing is kind of a must have these days, especially in an RPG. The only downsides that I would give to this game are the weird bugs and glitches and the numerous crashes that you will encounter, and the kind of crappy animations, in which of course can be fixed with mods. The DLC were not that great in my opinion, don't get me wrong they're still worth it, but they're just not as interesting as they could have been. And that also occurs with the companions that can follow the character, exept for a small backstories, they dont have any side quests and they are not that interesting.Goods: + Lots of loot like weapons and objects, to sell or to put in your house. + Lots of customization for your character and your home. + Level up system with special perks and skill development. + Lots of quests and areas to explore. Interesting story. + Over 60 hours of gameplay with a bonus of 30 hours with the DLCs.+ Can save whenever you want and load the game at exactly where you last saved. + The ability of moding the game, which allows you to add whatever you want in the game really.+ Lots of interesting NPCs to interact within which most feels unique and different. + Insane replay value due to mods. + Lots of creature and enemies to kill and that feels unique and different.Bads:- Not so interesting but still worth it DLCs (in my opinion).- Lots of bug, glitches and crashes (especially when playing with mods).- Companions that are not really interesting (in my opinion).- Crappy and unnatural animations (but can be better with mods).Overall, I would really recommend this game to everyone that wants a good RPG with guns, gore and babes, and that want to go on a long adventure that will most likely, never end. Definitely worth the 19.99$ for the GOTY (Game of the Year) edition with all the DLCs included.Final Verdict:8/10 (not moded).Great Game!10/10 (with the good mods). Legendary!Recommended with a Badass seal of approval!!!!

												One of the best games ever created in gaming history and one of my favorite games I have ever played. I can't express how much I love this game. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												Easily my favorite game of all time. Yes, the compatibilty issues with Windows 7/8 is a problem but once you get past that, this game is an absolute thrill ride. First, presentation is amazing here, never more have I just wanted to look out at the scenic view of the wasteland when you first leave that vault, as your eyes adjust to the light...and you see..chaos..deterioration. Gunplay is great, addictive, and will keep you going till the end. Side quests are located all around the map, some marked, others not, hundreds of hours of gameplay. Ever since day one, I loved the karma system, this idea of being good, evil, or somewhere in between always intruiged me and because of that I have had many playthroughs of the game. Doing a good run, then getting curious and doing all the evil, devious things, then started a neutral playthrough, then doing another good run, because I forgot all the quests, rewards, and the overall atmospheric changes you can have on the wastes. Which, I also loved, because you can actually make a difference in this wasteland. If you get bored with the playthroughs, there's also a thriving modding community out there with plenty of awesome mods to check out. You know, some say New Vegas is an overall better game, with its factions, added gameplay, better mechanics, but there is one thing Fallout 3 will always have over New Vegas: That Dark Wasteland Post Apocalyptic feel, something New Vegas didn't really show.10/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												The Fallout Franchise raised the bar for all the Post-apocalyptic games to come.A lot of games make a huge deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation.You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your post-apocalyptic journey through the Washington DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing and allso replaying and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.Oh Yeah!? This is prabably the only game that gives a player the freedom to put a live grandes in someones pocket.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Why is Fallout 3 among the best games ever made in a nut shell? It lets you live out a fascinating story in a familiar but ruined world. It paints and charts the life of an imaginary you and lets you act in a way that makes you feel personally invested in the outcome of its story. The characters all feel alive and important. Game play wise it is solid and easily understood enough to carry the story to the end with epic detail, impact, and flare. ProsEverything about it.ConsThis game could only have been better by adding more. More monsters, npcs, stats, and maps. It could have lived on MMO style and possibly gone multi-player. The PC version is buggy and does suffer from crashing at times. It hasn't hit me personally much, and I save often.  Really, it should be updated to Window 10 for the crazy number of copies sold.Bottom line: If you don't own Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition and you like games, movies, or stories, find a way to play it immediately.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This game is truly amazing and I am greatly saddened by the fact that it's user reviews are brought down to only "very positive", just because people are too indolent to try and solve simple problems. Disregard every negative review as they are ALL complaints about easy-to-fix problems that I will explain in greater detail at the end of this review.Fallout 3 has managed to set standards in both the FPS and RPG genres, and is possibly my favourite game of all time. Very few games come anywhere close to F3 in lore, atmosphere, combat, story, and overall gameplay, and none are on par in all of those elements combined.Lore - the fallout franchise as a whole has some of the most developed and interesting lore that I've experienced from a video game. Though, managing to incorperate it without requiring the player to have played previous games is something that F3 has done incredibly well.Atmosphere - Being set in a post-apocalyptic US, 200 years after nuclear war with China, F3 has done a fantastic job at making a nearly desolate nuclear wasteland something worth exploring. That combined with with themes from a 50's, anti-communist, nuclear, technologically advanced America makes F3 something truly unique and incredibly enjoyable to dwell in and explore.Combat - F3's combat was truly revolutionary for its time. The mechanic found in V.A.T.S was something never seen before and many mechanics in current games get their inspiration from it. Nothing compares to an intense gunfight whilst you have mid-20th century swing and blues playing from your Pip-Boy.Story - Many have complained that F3's story is too linear, and admittedly the main storyline is fairly linear, but the main quests aren't the only story. There is just as much emphasis on side quests as there is on the main one, and side quests often have a lot of decisions to be made. It's in the rest of the quests that you decide how you want to play and what kind of person you want to be.Gameplay - After leaving the vault, you are constantly progressing. Fighting harder enemies, getting better weapons and armour, and increasing your various skills. But it never gets repetitive. While you still have quests to complete, and there are many, gameplay will never become blasé.The complaints I have with this game are few, and all can be fixed with F3's amazing modding community. So I will include links to the mods that fix all of these problems.No ADS - The ability to aim down your sight is one that seems to be in nearly every FPS, so it is somewhat surprising that F3 doesn't have it. Instead, you get a slight zoom by pressing what would be the ADS key. Luckily there are modders that have fixed this. http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/6938/?Micro stutter - This slight stutter is one that has plagued both the Fallout and Elder Scrolls games for a long time. A fix can be found here http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/8886/?Sprinting - It can be annoying when you need to traverse a great distance but you're stuck with that slow vanilla running. It seems odd that you wouldn't be able to sprint, but of course, we have the modding community to fix this. http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1854/?Now for the problems that keep all the negative reviewers from enjoying the game.If you press play on the first window and it closes without launching the game, more likely than not, you do not have Games for Windows Live installed. This is required to run F3.Games for Windows Live: http://download.gfwl.xboxlive.com/content/gfwl-public/redists/production/xliveredist.msiAnother problem that people have is that the game will occasionally freeze. As you have seen on the store page for Fallout 3, it is not optimized for Windows 7 and 8. I've been using the Fallout Script Extender(FOSE) for a while and I've experienced no freezes.FOSE: http://fose.silverlock.org/This may help too.Better Game Performance: http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/13520/?Overall, Fallout 3 is absolutely fantastic and is one of the greatest experiences I've had with a video game. 95/100

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												This review comes at a bit of a strange time as I first played Fallout 3 years ago. Then I tried to get it to work with my current rig and it wouldn't despite numerous attempts at fixing it. I eventually gave up and moved on to playing Fallout Vegas. I did like Vegas (and still haven't completed it) but found I had strong memories of Fallout 3 and kept judging Vegas by its predecessor. Then recently a miracle happened and I found a fix that got 3 working again. I have never been able to put my finger on it but Vegas had something missing from it which Fallout 3 had. I think its a combination of things really. For a start I found the whole setting and atmosphere of Fallout 3 to be way more apocalyptic than Vegas. Thats probably down to the twisted wreckage of old highways that dot the horizon and vast skeletal shells of long dead cities. It really makes you feel that something extremely bad happened to the world (which of course did). The music varies and sometimes can be hauntingly eerie.There are a ton of side missions and of course the main story. All that before you even touch the DLC's. The game has many good storylines with some that force you to decide what kind of wastelander you are going to be,With our world supposedly on the verge of its next extinction event and heightened tensions between some super powers its never been a better time to play fallout and visit the maybe world of tomorrow.Fallout 4 is on its way. It looks great so far but I expect it will be compared to the earlier games such as Fallout 3.A most definite 10 / 10 classic title that should be in every serious gamers library.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												The hallowed memories of yesteryears games makes the Fallout tradition a challenging project to have undertaken. Bethesda has not released a perfect game, but there is no doubt in my mind that this is indeed a worthy heir to the Fallout lineage. What it has lost by leaving the 3rd person isometric view it has gained back 100 fold by an amazingly detailed world, storylines that go far beyond simple lines of dialog, and many different paths for the player to choose. There is in fact far more content than any single playthrough needs to experience, promising greater replayability.A masterpiece.

												Ridiculous Amounts of FunI purchased this game on a whim. After playing FO3:GOTY on my PS3, I was curious to see what it would be like to play on the PC. I was not disappointed. I had some trouble running the game at first, as this is not optimized for Win10, but after some fiddling around I was able to play with great stability. The only thing I didn't really care for was the lengthy intro. This game is a great way to kill time, and sit back. If your specs are good this game will look amazing. If your like me, and prefer preformance, this will look even better. The combat system is simple, no different than FNV. V.A.T.S. is OP if your stats are right, the weapons and armor are balanced, along with the items. And the soundtrack is nothing to scoff at. There are many ways to play the story. You can play as a theif by stealing everything in sight (say bye-bye to your karma!), you can play as a hero, a monster, and much more. Score:-Gameplay: 8/10-Sound: 7/10-Combat: 10/10-Graphics: 9/10-DLC: 8/10-Overall Score: 8/10On to the technical stuff. All I own is a Surface Pro 2, and some accessories for it. So of course gameplay isn't going to be stellar. I am posting these as a reference for anyone who would like to see what my specs are compared to theirs. content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Since Fallout 4 is nearing it's release date I'll release a review for Fallout 3. Now before I start I'll end the common debate most people have when they want to start playing the Fallout series... DO I PURCHASE FALLOUT NEW VEGAS OR FALLOUT 3? Well since I have both I'll write down the pros and the cons of both games so bear with me for now.Fallout 3 Pros+ Very story rich, tells you about the Lone Wanderer and how he/she was born and raised.+ Is a very beautiful game in my personal opinion.+ Very nice radio that will keep you entertained while travelling the Washington wasteland.+ Multiple endings so you can keep playing this game over and over.+ THREE DOG AND DOGMEAT.+ Very big atmosphere that's entirely yours to explore.+ VATS is a wonderful gameplay mechanic that is introduced in Fallout 3.+ Karma meter which makes you feel like you're an actual person instead of just a mindless killer.Fallout 3 Cons- No iron sight aiming.- Not optimized for Windows 7 or later. (This doesn't mean that it's unplayable on Windows 7 it's just that you have to modify the game files and that's really time consuming. Took me about 7 hours to fix Fallout 3 for my Windows 7 computer.)- Somewhat small level cap (20, but can be increased with the Broken-Steel DLC)- Very short main story line.- Companions AREN'T invincible.- Doesn't have an indicatior for when weapons are really worn thus making them more likely to jam.Now that I've talked a bit about Fallout 3 I'll talk about the pros and cons of Fallout: New VegasFallout: New Vegas Pros+ Iron sight aiming.+ VATS is a returning feature in Fallout: New Vegas.+ Companions are invincible.+ Hardcore mode is an option for all you hardcore fans out there.+ Runs fine on Windows 7 and later (managed to run it on my terrible computer at a stable 60 FPS.)+ A better radio than Fallout 3 (in my personal opinion.)+ Weapon modification is an option.+ REX.+ You're in Las Vegas, what more do I need to say?+ Some fun gambling to do in The Strip if that's your thing.+ Increasing level cap if you have DLC installed. (Increases by 5 for each DLC, 30 is the base level cap.)+ Very big and beautiful world, but not as big as Fallout 3.+ The Kings.+ No karma requirements to recruit companions.+ Reputation for factions.Fallout: New Vegas- Tons of invisible walls over the Mojave Wasteland.- No back story AT ALL about our player character: The Courier.- Very limited story endings.- A lot of walking must be done unless you have found some places to fast travel to. - TONS of bugs.- A.I isn't as good as in Fallout 3.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now for the review of Fallout 3: You start off as a baby that is newly born. You then have a time skip to you as a toddler, and another to when you're 10, and 15. Finally when you're 18 the game really starts. This game is beautiful the moment you step out of Vault 101 and see the sunlight for the first time. It's not too far into the game when you meet Dogmeat, a fan favourite companion loved by all. During this time you are already free to do as you please and explore the Washington wastelands. This game is entirely based by your actions so it's amazing that you get to choose how the game will end. Will you be a villian feared all across the wasteland? Or will you be the guardian angel of the wasteland? If you want to find out... BUY THIS GAME! (Ps. took me about an hour to write, enjoy)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I first played Fallout 3 in 2010, on an xbox 360, I was blown away and an obsession was born in me.The games story compared to New Vegas, isn't the best, but still amazing, I loved every second of it.I played for 100+ hours and then a friend gave me his GOTY with all the DLC, I thought I was going to die. The DLC easily adds 100's of hours to the game, simply because Broken Steel, allows you to continue after the end of the base game.The sidequests, and backstories, for everything are wonderfully done. And the in-game radio stations are just great, playing all the songs that just complete the atmosphere of the game.Other than a few compatibility issues I ran into since I'm running Windows 8.1, (I had to install GFWL for it to work) I just installed 18 mods that overhaul the textures in-game, and it's just beautiful. Even though the hype train is rather crowded, I'm on it.I'd give it a hard 9.5/9.5Keep on fighting the good fight.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												[This review does contain spoilers. I mean, this game is 7 years old after all.]You probably know all about this game. It came out a pretty long time ago, 2008 to be exact. Even though this is the GOTY version, I won't be reviewing the DLCs.So, let's start with a bit of history you probably already know. Fallout is an action RPG. Fallout takes place after a nuclear war between 'Murka, China and the Soviet Union, which started and ended on the same day. The nuclear war turned the entire world into a wasteland. Fallout from the beginning wasn't a Bethesda game. It was originally a series from Interplay and Black Isle Studios, planned as a successor to the game Wasteland.Fallout 1 and 2 are considered classics and were critically-acclaimed. Interplay later published the two major spin-offs, the favorable Fallout Tactics, and the unfavorable Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel. Then we got Warfare and Van Buren, but let's not speak about those.Bethesda later bought the series and developed Fallout 3. They later acted as publishers for the next game, New Vegas, which was developed by Obsidian Entertainment.Most gameplay would be impossible without the Pip-Boy (also present in the previous games) which is a device worn on the player's forearm, which displays the inventory, the quest log, stats, the map, item properties, a radio and even a Geiger counter which can be viewed in the upper right corner. The standard color of the Pip-Boy is Green, but you can change it to your liking. The color of the Pip-Boy also affects the HUD which displays health, action points, and a compass. Fallout 3 also has perks, which were in previous Fallout games. Vault Boy is the mascot and appears on most things, such as when picking up an item, when you're poisoned or when picking a perk.The starting place is Vault 101, where the player was born. It is a safe haven from the nuclear wasteland, where people can live in peace and prosperity. Vault 101 is one of the only vaults left standing since most vaults were desimated by vicious experiments done by the Vault Overseers and personnel. Such as Vault 87, where citizens were transformed into hideous, deformed mutants. The game takes place in the areas in and around Washington D.C. DLCs also take you to Alaska, Maryland, air force bases, and even a mother♥♥♥♥ing spaceship.Bethesda♥♥♥♥♥♥on the lore quite a bit in this game, but it's not really much of a bother when it comes to enjoyment. One faction has been the center of this complaint, the Enclave. The Enclave are the remnants of the US government, and are usually considered the ''bad guys''. They were supposedly eradicated in Fallout 2. The faction was only present on the West Coast, but somehow the Enclave appears on the East Coast....?How does this possibly work out? How does mere remnants of a faction travel across one of the world's largest landmasses, without succumbing to the dangers of the Wasteland? They aren't even supposed to exist in the first place. They are quite powerful in Fallout 3 aswell, even proving a challenge for the other faction, the much more established Brotherhood of Steel, which are usually counted as the ''good guys''. They're all for freedom, liberty, you know the deal. That's another faulty trait in Fallout 3, it's extremely black-and-white morally. There's a bad side and a good side, and even though the game makes a meek attempt to change this slightly at the end of the game (the option to infect the water with FEV), it still hovers over the game like a gray cloud of blandness.The appearance of the Enclave on the East Coast is just roughly and slovenly explained in one of the DLCs, Broken Steel. It was just like Bethesda slapped a book in your face and said: ''This is how it is. Deal with it''. It just doesn't make sense. Many appearances of non-East Coast tech either remain unexplained or badly explained. It makes me believe that Bethesda didn't even inquire with loremasters at Interplay or Black Isle. Even after researching the lore, I have found cracks in the lore that lack any explaination or meaning.Fallout 3 is saturated with plotholes and inconsistencies. Where do people get their food for instance? There seems to be food in abundance, but I can count the number of farms or crops in Fallout 3 on one hand. Surely the food from before the war would've run out a good 200 years after the war? Oh, and the Super Mutants can keep the mighty Brotherhood stalled, but can't defeat a village of young unarmored adults protected by a small wooden barricade.The "sacrifice" of your father in the purifier is such a forced plot element, and ofcourse the main bad guy survives with his magic drugs (available to no one else!), which he really shouldn't have access to considering that he's from a shattered faction with no influence whatsoever, that had its technology blown up in the previous game.The story is the run-of-the-mill story that has been given to you in Fallout and Fallout 2. They're basically mashed together. Those stories were about saving your home from the bad guys. Fallout actually evolved the story from acquiring a water chip for the vault to defeating a deformed lump of flesh who had created the most fearsome army of the Wasteland. That's basically what Fallout 3 is, with modification. Your dad escapes the vault, you follow him, he tells you about his plan to help the people, you help him, the bad guys come, you need to defeat them etc. It's a pretty boring and plain story, and a lot of the situations that happen in Fallout 3 are very predictable and don't provide the shock value that Bethesda seemingly tried to implement. The side quests can be a bliss at times though. Tranquility Lane was a load of fun and one of the best quests in the game.The side quests are unique enough and not the glorified radiant quests usually found in games like Skyrim. Some of the side quests have a large effect on the world, The Power of the Atom being the most notable. That quest can change the world 1-2 hours in, if you do it the right way. The biggest problem with the quests are that they are usually very linear, more choices and alternate paths in Fallout 3's quests would do it some good.The combat is basic shooter combat (Oblivion with guns) besides from the system V.A.T.S, which pretty much aims for you. V.A.T.S makes combat too easy way too often. It worked in the earlier games, but coupled with Gamebryo it's♥♥♥♥♥♥Basically everyone outside the cities are empty shells. Main Quest characters and some people in the cities are the only NPCs I cared for. Atleast each city/town has one interesting character. For example Harkness in Rivet City, Confessor Cromwell in Megaton and Mayor MacCready in Little Lamplight. Sure, wandering the wasteland can have some interesting encounters and easter eggs, but otherwise you probably will meet uninteresting people, if you meet anyone at all. And let's not forget the uninspired, tacky writing and the horrible voice acting.Probably the most interesting character in the game is Three Dog. That man has brought me a lot of happiness when wandering the wastes. He's the disc jockey of the Wasteland's most popular radio station. He became a fan favorite, and is still my favorite Fallout 3 character. His jokes and speeches are radiant, but the list of lines from him is quite a long one. I enjoyed listening to that station a lot. The radio in Fallout 3 is very well done and Bethesda did a good job. The songs are great and they fit in with the atmosphere. I listened to both Enclave Radio and GNR.The game uses the Gamebryo engine, the same engine used in Oblivion. The game uses the Havok physics engine.So, Fallout 3 is an enjoyable game with large flaws. Still, it is counted among one of the best games of all time. Probably not. It's a good game, but I'd recommend New Vegas.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Fallout 3. This is a game that will, most of the time, suck you in with its amazing atmosphere and environments. I say most of the time because, just like the Steam notice says there, it's not optimized for Windows 7. Now I have Windows 7, and I fully played through all the content in this game, and what I believe they're trying to say with that is that this game has a bunch of performance issues. Fallout 3 loves to crash. A lot. As in, it made me press the quicksave button all the time so I'd make sure I wouldn't lose as much progressas I potentially could. However, I did play through everything, and I loved it. In fact, this is the second time that I've played through everything in Fallout 3. I just love the game so much that even the regular crash couldn't stop me.The very first part of the game is so well done, very immersive and eases you into the game proper nicely. Don't expect amazing shooting mechanics, while it does have FPS mechanics (you'll never used third person camera because of how bad it is for combat) you don't play it for the shooting. You play it instead for the RPG elements, the storytelling, and the impeccable atmosphere the Wasteland offers you. It's grim, it's gory, it's gritty, it is a complete hellhole on a destroyed post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. Many of the landmarks that characterize D.C in the real world are very well replicated here in its ruined and wrecked glory. The Fallout universe itself is a joy to be in, with its 50's/futuristic quirks, power armors, aliens, big guns that really go BOOM, and freaky mutations. The game did give me quite a few jumpscares when I was caught unawares by some of the wildlife. The V.A.T.S system is awesome as you pick your favorite body part and shoot, complete with guts and gore flying everywhere as your enemies die. Good stuff.The inevitable question when it comes to this game is: "Is it better than New Vegas or is it the other way around?" I would say that even though I slightly prefer New Vegas, both are worth playing anyway because it shows both Bethesda and Obsidian's strong (and weak) points. And both are good games in their own right.Bethesda made Fallout 3. And what makes Bethesda great are both its sidequests (which are always more interesting than the main story itself) and its attention to detail in its environments. They love to litter the landscape with information, each containing a small story or information explaining why that skeleton's standing in that bathroom, for example. And sometimes it doesn't, all it shows you, all it needs, is the scenery itself that tells the story for you. This makes exploration really engaging and fun because things rarely feel they're copypasted (except the subway tunnels but there's only so much you can do to make a ruined subway tunnel stand out, though some do stand out anyway).The quests themselves have multiple solutions and most of the time offer choice, like a good RPG should, and trust me, you can do some extreme stuff in these which will literally change the landscape, but then again, these choices and this engaging writing are severely lacking in the main quest itself, which is clichéd and ultimately really linear. I prefer Obsidian's writing overall, so New Vegas wins out on Fallout 3 for me there. Fallout 3 though, like any good sandbox RPG should do, which New Vegas does not, is allow you to keep playing after the actual ending. In NV's defense though, there are so many endings that it would be hell to program into, but still, it's something worth keeping an eye out for.Fallout 3's the oldest game of the two, so it will, gameplay-wise, lack a few features NV adds in later on.Like any modern Bethesda RPG, Fallout 3 adds much needed mod support which makes the PC version by far the best, allowing you to fix many of its faults, and become an even better experience than it already is. Though I'd recommend just sticking to performance mods the first time around, as some of these mods can change the game dramatically.The DLC for the game itself is a bit hit and miss in my opinion. DLCs like Broken Steel which let you keep playing the game after its conclusion, or Point Lookout and The Pitt, which add areas of their own with stuff to do are great, but Anchorage and Zeta, though unique, don't add to the game all that much, and you wouldn't feel like something's missing if these never came out.All in all, I totally recommend this game, lots of RPG goodness and with mod support, can have you keep coming for more.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												For starters, let's say I didn't hate playing FO3. I've beaten it few times, did the majority of quests and even played all the DLC's. I even had fun doing that. Do I recommend playing it? Maybe. Is it a terrible game? No. There, I said it. Moving on. Here's my main gripe: FO3 is what happens when you take a fantastically written post-apocalyptic game series and hand the rights over to a company whose writers appear to be 12-year-olds.Imagine a world where every city, every store and every household is an entity separate from the surrounding world. Nothing has an effect on anything else. There's a town a miles down the road with a problem with Raiders? Yeah, that doesn't really affect this storekeeper couple. Heaps of radscorpions make life a living hell for a bunch of settlers living in a run-down village? Yeah, that has no bearing on this other community a stone's throw away, their only problem pertains to fixing their fertility robot. Oh, and getting their hands on a vacuum tube located 20 miles away because reasons.When you have dozens of locations with seemingly no connection to one another or the main plot, you end up with a huge sandbox that barely resembles the intricate interconnected plots of the first two games. That's Fallout 3's setting in a nutshell. Real world doesn't work like that. If your counter-argument is "this is a game, not the real world lol" you're completely missing the point. Fallout 1 and 2 came out years before FO3 and yet they still managed to accomplish a sense of reality - albeit a very far-fetched and sometimes tongue-in-cheek one.Take Fallout 2, where you have a complicated, interconnected political web between New Reno, Redding, Vault City and NCR. Take Fallout: New Vegas where everything rotates around the ongoing conflict between NCR and Caesar's Legion. Everyone has a say in this, everybody is affected. Your choices affect the outcome and the ongoing power structure. That's how you write a game. And that's where FO3 falls flat on its face.The main plot is bland. I felt like I had no reason to follow the PC's dad. Instead I ran around, doing quests here and there, fetching this and killing that, getting little satisfaction from the caps and experience I accumulated. It wasn't really rewarding. None of it. Just a mindless, momentary distraction on the road to the grave.Oh, and the metro tunnels suck.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2013
												A Bethesda RPG set 200 years into a post apocalyptic future. It's tempting to just call this game "Oblivion with space guns" but there is more to it than that. You can create custom weapons from schematics and the hacking, lockpicking and XP elements all help to separate it from it's kin - no more grinding skills to level up!Whether these changes make the game more enjoyable than Bethesdas' fantasy RPG's is up to you. The level cap of 20 definately makes it a shorter game than either Morrowind, Oblivion or Skyrim.The GOTY edition is good value for money as fallout 3 on it's own is a tad short; I completed the main plot and reached max level after only 60 hours of gameplay; and although there was lots of content still to explore I had little incentive to do so. The GOTY edition content boosted the level cap to 30, serving to extend that lifespan somewhat. However, I had reached that cap after completing just two of the 5 DLC packs. Fallout 3 is very stylish and, on the whole, I found the game to be fun and immersive with a huge, detailed world and a great plot. I want to add that the radio feature is excellent too, and is largely responsible for me loving a new genré of music.So if you want an RPG that excludes the usual swords and elves, you can't go far wrong with this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												It's like Borderlands, if Borderlands were better and a single player experience and actually built up some semblance of an atmosphere that wasn't all just ''sand sand sand epic memes''. You explore the wastelands and, while there's a main storyline (search for your father), the side quests are honestly where its at. Unlike Borderlands typical ''go to area X, kill things and come back'', Fallout 3 has storylines to each side quest that range from the intruiging to the surprising. The areas were the side quests take you are also areas you'd expect to be part of the main storyline, since they're very detailed and numerous. Seriously, if you only play the main storyline you'd miss well over half of the game, and that's not an exaggeration.The way in which you find out about quests makes the whole experience feel more realistic. You don't go to a bulletin board and pick quests, rather, you might run into a citizen with a request, pick up a strange radio signal in a particular area, find a note while exploring a new locale, or just happen to stumble upon a fight taking place. It all immerses you into the world and gives it a realistic feeling of exploration and loneliness. Some of the quests also present you with multiple ways to finish them, which means that you get a real sense of added importance to your choices. It got to the point where I was juggling dialogue choices and planning what to do to proceed, as I didn't wanna have one party come to an unfavorable outcome while the other struck gold.The battle system gives options: you can realistically go through the whole game using only VATS, an RPG-ish system whereby you attack enemies with your equipped weapon; you select a body part of theirs and are shown the odds the attack will hit. Or you can play this entierely as a first person (or third person) shooter. Personally, I found no issue with the shooting, but apparently this is a point of contention as some say its like an attempt at a FPS in an engine that wasn't made for that. I'll say this: it isn't broken and there's nothing inherently wrong with it.A word of warning; this game isn't optimized for Windows 7 (Vista as well, I think), so you might have issues running it. I simply had to change the ini file to allow multi-cores, and the crashes stopped. But others have had a much tougher time at it, so give it a pirate first.But issues aside, a solid 9/10 with hours of exploration. I'm 70 hours in and not even halfway through the main game cause I've been exploring and doing sidequests.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												The road so far......wasn't kind to me. It was full of loss and misery. Full of hopeless people and lost souls that stepped on this doomed wasteland.Yet, it wasn't only damnation that followed my steps. I found my father, my love Amata, a faithful companions... only to loose them the next second.If this was the road so far, what will follow it? I know you can't talk, my good, old, friend, dogmeat. Despite that, I know you can listen, you are the only one who does that. So, thank you, buddy.________________________After 95 hours I finally finished this unique game. It was a long journey that, sadly, or not, came to the conclusion.I have mixed feeling because I can not, but to notice, the flaws of this game.The combat is far from perfection. Constant invisible walls interfere in the shooting so that stealth and sniper headshot from a far is not an option. It is frustrating at times, but the VATS does a perfect job to overcome the combat flaws. It balances it.Writing of the main story. It's not good. It's average. It does the job to send you to a different locations and introduce the world, but that's it. I do like the small stories, though, which this world is packed to it's fullest and the enormous attention to detail. But the main plot... At the end, the feeling is that the bone was thrown and if we search enogh we can find it. In any case, sadly, it's not there. A mere feel of a presence of something epic is not what we want.Don't take me the wrong way. I like this game. It's good. Not perfect but good enough. There isn't any very good highlights but the mixture and huge diversity make this game a unique experience worth to check...if you push by yourself and force to go throw the tedious start that keept me aways the 2 past attempts to play Fallout 3.First 20 levels are a joy to play. You keep discovering new things and some quite memorable moments. A very simple details engage with a perfection to this unworthy world: A text based story about Grognak that you play on a terminal; Tranquility Lane; Princess who is secretly in love with the leader of Little Lamplight; Brother who got two naughty nightwear; A old man who I saved from suicide attempts.Despite the average writing of the main plot where it shines is in the clues of the past. There is no history in Fallout 3. Though, it creates an understanding of the past by the logs, terminals and documents. And it does the job like non other game up this date. The contradictive information, the vision of people of the those past events - at times I felt like archaeologist.There are a huge depth that you can completely ignore and focus on the aspects you like. Do whatever. The world is there. What do you gonna do in it?________________________It happened before and it will happen again.So many killed, so much destroyed... and yet it's not enough, it is never enough. Because war... war never changes.It is time, we need to go my friend. Our journey has just started.


Into the sunset. The last moment of my gameplay. 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: KyrDerz

content:
Posted: January 12, 2012
												This is some good♥♥♥♥♥♥ any and all Fallout is a very good thing (even BoS, that's some serious stuff). Lacks the complexity or depth of Fallout 1, 2 & New Vegas but shakes the formula up with an interesting change of setting. What holds this back from a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I-N-G God-like status, is that Fallout 3 often plays it safe in terms of what elements have been used from previous games. Despite the change in location, the fundamentals of this story have already been covered in the past two games, the fact you have a daddy in this game doesn't change jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ But when it shines, it really shines. Some very memorable moments in this game, one thing I do think it has the edge over the other games in the series. There really isn't anything like discovering Tranquility Lane in this series, or any game in general. Cool♥♥♥♥♥♥ 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Please note that some users have issues getting the game to run on Windows 7 and up, there are fixes available thanks to the community though.Ah Fallout 3, such a great game (I owned a copy 5 years ago that just used Games For Windows Live). Definitely one of those games that you will never forget, and worth every penny.Story takes place with you being born, from there you name your character and predict how you'll look in the future when you're older. Your mother dies due to complications when giving birth. The first half hour or so is you growing up over many years where you select your S.P.E.C.I.A.L abilities, get your pip-boy and BB gun, take the G.O.A.T test, and then eventually leave the vault you grew up in for 19 or so years to explore the wasteland and demolished Washington D.C. There are many great people you will meet along the way, but you will also make plenty of enemies. You truly feel in control with this game, there's nothing you can't do. Wanna blow up a town with a nuke? Go ahead! Wanna disarm the nuke and save the town? Go ahead! Wanna explore the entire world from top to bottom? Go right on ahead, nothing stops you. There's so many great things about Fallout 3 that you really should experience if you haven't already. Plus what's a better way to get ready for Fallout 4 than by killing ghouls and mutants in D.C?I rate this game a 9.5/10 . It has it's bugs and other little issues, but it is definitely worth every penny.Oh and since we're on the PC...you can mod the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game to your hearts content.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Fallout 3, is one of the Fallouts, and it's a amazing Fallout at that as is the series, but Fallout 3 is 1st in my top list of games at the moment, Fallout 3 is better than alot of games today, and thats quite amazing considering that this game was released in 2008 and its 2014 when I'm writing this review, that's six years, and technology in the gaming industy has vastly increased since then and it's is still better than alot of games that are released today, so thats something to consider. I've played Fallout NV Game Of The Year, and of course Fallout 3 Game Of The Year, so which is better? Before I start my long winded rant keep in mind ultimately you decided wheter you get the game don't let me influence wheter you do or not, this is here merely as some experiances and information I have had.In my opionion I think Fallout 3 has the better story by far and I'm sure many people would agree with me, its twisted, well thought out, and exstremely emotional and one of the best, well the best I've played. The wasteland is very lonely when expolring the wasteland even with followers, this can be taken in two ways.The radio and the people is very envolving you will practically remember everyone you speak and sometimes you'll learn some life lessons, I know I have, like selflessness, sacrafice, and love. The radio really portrays the setting alot, and the radio changes depending on what you've done in the wastes which is really special and unqiue to the Fallout series, and its very interesting and makes you reflect on your previous actions which is a good things, when traveling the wastes and speaking to people and going to different enviroments and exploring different factions, you really notice the struggle and impact of Fallout, how desperate peolpe are and what lengths people are willing to go to survive, like taking lifes, causing trouble and stealing and drinking from irratiated water. And it's very realistic perception of how people are today, how people are, if they see someone do something they think its right, and how the enviroment has adapted, people living in the swerers and sleeping out side on sheets of cardboard. So a 10/10 on that point.And I like the different approaches you can take in Fallout and use your range of skills to change the outcome of a situation which is very good, you can use them for good or evil, and people will always hold it against you be it good or bad and people will mention it when you see them, and there will be certain things you can and can't acess depending on your repuation with certain factions.So to round up, 10/10 gameYou should play this prior to NV100000% Awesome game a must get to everyone.Add me if you have any queries. Hope this helps.Benji :)(It says 0hrs, I've player 300+ hours on most fallouts on a different pc)

												I find this game enjoyable and not too far from Oblivion. I purchased this when on sale and would recommend the same. The pros of this game: easier to get into role playing mood than Oblivion; weapons and guns are unexpectedly fun to use; atmosphere and mapping/world are good. Cons: similar to Oblivion -- the game engine still needs some work including the sneaking system, AI, movement mechanics, and character animations; the menu system isn't far off from Oblivion's and I would have liked to seen some better organization; can get boring.All in all, I think it's a great game but it could have been better with some core game changes.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												One of my all time favorite RPG's. I've put hundreds of hours into the console version, and have experienced all this beloved game has to offer. A few aspects of the game are a bit dated; the character animation is mostly what bothers me. But NOTHING compares to the atmosphere this game has created. The gritty post apocalyptic wasteland of a landscape is harsh and intimidating, with suprises around every darkened corner. Fused perfectly into the unforgiving state of post nuclear Washington DC is a 50's retro theme that gives this hostile enviroment an uplifting flare that comes off as increadibly eerie in the once thriving ghost town of a city. Combine these two aspects with the massive amounts of historical references throughout the DC area and what you get is the most unique, well thought out masterpiece of a journey in a place where i constantly feel the need to come back to. Crazy they call me, sure i'm crazy. Crazy in love with this game.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Fallout 3 is an Open World, Post-apocalyptic, FPS RPG that I love to bits. Some may argue that Fallout 4 is better than this, but I have to disagree. I enjoyed this game more than I did Fallout 4, mostly because this game feels more like the RPG that the Fallout franchise is supposed to be, rather than something more alnog the lines of a Fallout setting, but a game that feels like a Borderlands game.In Fallout 3, you escape from a vault, a nuke shelter. But, not any vault; this is Vault 101. You are out to find your dad, who went missing without reason, in a wasteland once called Earth. It is a great setting, and great story. However, my only complaint about this game is it's lack of color. The game is mostly gray, with vauge hints of colors here and there, but the game was just a little too pale. Well, that is a bit of a lie, for there are some colors that are clearly visible all through out the game, but compared to Fallout 4, this game is a bit pale. But, beside that, Fallout 3 has some great features, and is a long game, with hours of content.  one of my favorite features in Fallout 3 is VATS, which is where you can target certain enemies, in certain places, for more damage.The main story doesn't take that long; it took me 10 hours to beat the main story line. But, there are a LOT of side quests, that actually have a backstory, unlike games like Skyrim.This game contains all the DLC for $15 less, so you already know that this is a good deal. The DLC themselves only activate after you beat the game. Well, that too is a lie. Only the Broken Steel DLC is activated after you beat the game. They are basically add-ons to the main story of the Fallout 3. And, the are really fun. but, they are also REALLY difficult. For example, one DLC mission has you go into a sewer, and that sewer is crawling with Deathclaws. And when I say crawling, I mean CRAWLING! Some DLC add on to the main plot of the story, and others are just plain fun to play. For example, one sends you into space to fight aliens, and another one sends you back in time. But, for Fallout 3 fans, this game definitly is the one to get over Fallout 3, mostly because you can save money by getting this one, rather than buying all the DLC's and vanilla Fallout 3. There are soo many new armors, weapons, and places featured in the DLC's, that make the game soo replay able. And if the replay ablity isn't enough for you guys, there are five DLC to play, each one unique from the rest. And they add sooo much more gameplay and hours spent playing the game, than just playing though the main story line, like I did. And if all the above don't sell you, in the DLC, you can controll a Deathclaw. Need I say more?Overall, I REALLY like Fallout 3. It is my favorite game, even surpassing Skyrim. And, yes, I would recommend this over Fallout 4, for this game is better than the 4th, in my opinion. It just feels more like an RPG, which is what the Fallout franchise  is supposed to be. I recommend this game to everybody, whose parents will let them play it. Because war... War never changes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												To start off...Fallout is the game that you'll spend a lot of time playing while doing nothing but walk, talk, shoot and bash them with something or even punch it out with your own hands. For player who are similar to open world RPG (Skyrim, GTA) this is the game for you.The story set in the world after the nuclear war in the future and the protagonist was born and living safely underground after the war has ended. The father set out on a journey to recover the land and it is our job to find and help make it a better (or worse) place.The perk of playing this game is like any other open world series is that you can do anything and by 'anything' I mean everything. You can be the Good, the Bad or you can balance it out in your journey into the wasteland. There will be choices along the way which will make you say "Seriously? Do I really have to pick?" and then save at that point before making a decision and watch where your choices lead you.The outcome of the game is pretty much influent by how you play the game from the start to finish. There will be a lot of side quests which you can totally ignore them and still getting to the ending. (but they are worth it!)The combat system are not too chabby but not that great either. Since the game consists on the story more than the gameplay. Also, the difficulty of this game depends your your skills choice and how you manage it when when you level up. There will be many status like poison and radiation (it was a nuclear post-apocalyptic and all) .The AI or the enemies on this game are pretty easy to read (since they are only coming straight at you), but most of them are the hardhitters (mostly the non-human enemies) and they could totally whoop your butt into your last save in just a couple of hits (remember to save often!).The most important thing in this game is the soundtrack. It somehow became the best thing you can hear in the game while slaughter some radiated monsters. Also, the graphic might not be that great compare to these days' standard but there is nothing you can't fix with a little modding which can be found in many other reviews or community discussions.There are some downside of this game that many people are talking about like, can't play with windows 7 or higher but there are solutions. All you need to do is open up a browser (or two if you want) and type for "fallout 3 fix" or something similar to "Fallout 3 window 7/8 fix" and your problem will be gone in just a few mins. Other than OS problem the game doesn't have a cloud save which will be a problem because you will play this game for a long long time and you don't want to start over if your PC/Laptop just broken or you're changing them to a better one. But on the bright side, the game have save files for everytime you save during the game in your documents folder. I recommend you to make a backup once in a while or you will be just like me who have start all over again for 3 times already and it's pretty frustrating.All in all, Just buy it when it's on sales and play and I promise you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												1.6 hours doesn't say much, but I've picked this up (again) on PC (after playing 100s of hours on console) just for the modding scene. Sure, this is a hunk of a buggy mess, but that's because this was designed to run on WIndows Vista (and we know how much more steaming that is). Luckily, generous souls created freely availiable patches and resources to keep crashing and bugs to a minimum (which is surprising to hear from a Bethesda game). If you are interested more in map design, this is the game for you. If you are more interested in character and story, I'm pretty sure you should check Fallout: New Vegas. Don't worry, because both games take place in different places in a post-apocalyptic environment, the plot of one game will not reach the ears of the other coast in time to spoil the plot of the other game. TL;DR both games have an unrelated plot as they take place in different settings of the same universe.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												A great man once said: "All is fair in love and war, and Bethesda characters have dopey faces"Or was that just me? Anyways, this game has an interesting setting and great idea of idea execution and world building. Some things can fall flat at times (such as the terrible dialouge at the birthday party), but half of the time the humor and writing shine outwardly like a Supermodel at the International Hobo Convention of New York. Gameplay can get repitive and the long hikes through irradiated wastelands (Which usually end with you backtracking four miles while running from a horrific mutated monstrousity) can be boring, unlike say Skyrim. The exploration in this game is kind of boring because of the lack of locations and dynamic events that happen in the world. If you can get past that and you love the setting as I do, this game is a diamond in the rough for all FPS RPG fans.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2012
												This game is both my #1 favorite RPG and open-world game. In Fallout 3, you are a resident of a vault; a nuclear bunker sheltering people from the harsh Washington DC wasteland above. When your father leaves the vault for reasons unknown, you curiously follow, giving you the entirety of post-apocalyptic DC to explore. Discover the iconic landmarks like the Washington Monument and White House, or the civilizations that formed after the great war. It is NOT for children. Many adult themes are present, including slavery, prostitution, and drug addiction. Will you be experienced with computers or a savvy pickpocket? Will you use your skills for a righteous or wicked purpose? The choice is yours in Fallout 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												     This is without a doubt one of the most incredible games I've had the pleasure of playing. Its also one of the few games I can say I've ever deveoped an addiction to (seriously this game was like crack to me when I started playing it, the first week of me owning it saw maybe 18-20 hours of sleep).  The first time I played it was two years ago on the PS3, and replaying it again on the PC is so much better, mostly due to smoother gameplay and fewer bugs (special thanks to user BenWah for his amazing guide to not only making this game run properly, but the amazing mod community at the Nexus forums that he links in his discussion board posts for this game. Check it out and your experience with this game will be vastly improved/possible).      As far as the meat of the game goes, the story is centered around the quest for your character, the lone wanderer of Vault 101, to find his/her father who mysteriously leaves the Vault and stirs an uproar amongst the Vault-dwellers and the corrupt security forces that govern them. Along the journey you discover a greater purpose for delving into the wastes of Washington, D.C. as you unravel the conflict surrounding warring factions that inhabit the wastes vying for supremacy, whom you will ultimatley decide the fate of.      For those who played either The Elder Scrolls Oblivion or Skyrim, or have run through a story of Fallout: New Vegas, the game mechanics should be simple to familiarize yourselves with. For those new to Bethesda's brand of open-world RPG's, there are light survival elements (weapon maintenace, healthcare concerns, ability to sleep for resting bonuses to stats), a rather sparse but useful crafting system, and a wide variety of stealth and combat options that can be used to fit your own play style (heavier armor slows you down, leaves less room in your weight-based inventory, and impedes stealth abilities, but makes you much harder to kill and vice versa, things like that).      The Karma system does an interesting job of steering which companions you can recruit based on Karmic levels, and steers the outcome of future interactions based on choices made in conversation and dealings with other people. While they usually boil down to black, white, or grey choices, they have an amusing impact on conversations and how the denizens of the wastes react to your presence.An interesting mechanic  that I haven't seen outside of the last two Fallout games is the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System, or V.A.T.S. Costing a regenerating supply of action points to use, it stops time and breaks down the major sections of a targets body and lists your chances to hit each part with your currently equipped weapon. This is especially convenient due to the fact that there is a zoom aim, but no ironsight aiming with anything but scoped weapons (there are mods that correct this issue, but the orginal game is ironsight free) which can feel a lttle disconcerting in the middle of combat for those who are used to the tight gunplay of shooter based games such as Call of Duty, Battlefield, etc.    What is perhaps the most incredible feature of this game, for me at least, is the vast, rich world that from the very first moment you leave Vault 101 you have complete freedom to explore at your own risk. The series beefy lore is expanded and integrated into the game in numerous ways, and is thoroughly fleashed out in documents, audio logs, and items that you can find scattered amongst the ruins of the wastes (if you're into that sort of thing). In almost every settlement there are secrets to uncover and quests to acquire from a desloate bandit hovel to the crumbling ruins of downtown D.C., which can quckly fill your menu into an extensive to-do list. The world itself would be interesting enough to pick through were it devoid of life, but an enourmous and entertaining variety of characters keeps the experience even more engaging, whether you're recovering the last remaining Stradivarius from one of the several Vaults available to explore in the world, assisting the electoral campaigns of the residents of the isolated Republic of Dave, or deciding the fate of the patron deity of a cult of wasteland tree worshipers.     The game has als ohad plenty of post-release support, with five DLC packs that expand the already lengthy base game with several hours of even more questing and exploration. Each pack takes you beyond the Wasteland to decide the fate of a slave colony in Pittsburgh, travel to Maryland to explore a mind bending and dangerous swamp, enter a VR simulation to re-live the events of a key moment in the Fallout mythos: the liberation of Anchorage, Alaska, take the fight against the Enclave further north to Addams Airforce Base to finish them off once and for all, and even miles above the surface of the wasteland to join other abductees in a despearte bid to escape an alien spacecraft. Each pack adds several new perks and weapons that even further enhance the game, and each one can be started at any point of progress through the main story (except for Broken Steel, which requires you to finish the main story before it can be started). Coupled with the incredible support of its dedicated modding community, there are almost limitless variations and user created mission packs to explore and waffle around with at your leisure.     As I mentioned before, the game is among the best I've ever played, and obviously there's something to it given its lauded reputation as one of the finest games of the last generation. If I had to rate this game in terms of a sandwich, it would be a Reuben; a seemingly odd combination of elements that are already pretty great on their own, but when put together, create a wonderful and satisfying product that leaves you hungering for more (and kind of lamenting the fact that you powered through the damn thing in the first place).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Why Fallout 3 is better than New Vegas...Opening:What could be a better start to an RPG than being born? New Vegas uses a tired cliche about being shot in the head and asks the players to suspend their disbelief by telling them, like many RPGs before them, that they have lost part of their memory. With Fallout 3, there is no need for that suspension of disbelief, you know your history, you remember being born, you remember the big events of your childhood.Story: Your father leaves under mysterious circumstances and doesn't realize the danger this puts you in so you have to effect your own escape from your vault. Once you are out, are you going to track down the father who just up and left you without a word? Will you realize that he has a way to purify the water for everyone in the D.C area? Will you help him or stand in his way? These are all big questions you have to answer in Fallout 3. In New Vegas you are asked to decide between competing political factions as to who gets control of the Hoover dam.Locations: Sure, New Vegas has real cities that you can go and visit. You can go find Primm and see the roller coaster, you can find goodsprings and see the saloon, but Fallout 3 has one city built around an unexploded nuke, one city built on an abandoned aircraft carrier, and an underground city populated only by children.The only place where New Vegas is better is the DLC Dead Money and Old World Blues otherwise, Fallout 3 wins hands down.
