content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game is good, if you're into putting hours on lengthy playthroughs in an RPG with lots of depth, then get this game. However, if you're going to get this game expecting it to be like the infamous Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (but with guns), then you should reconsider because this game is FAR from that kind of title. Firstly, this game is a walking simulator; unlike Skyrim which has all kinds of things to do while you're in a quest, you're going to be lost in lengthy walks from point A to point B while continously looking in the map while whispering to yourself: "Am I there yet?", but not to worry, once you get to your destination, you'll be able to use fast travel -- "but isn't that like Skyrim?" yes, but in Skyrim, you have LOTS of things to do while you're travelling from Point A to Point B, you might run into some bandit camps, some bears or some caves, but in here, you'll just look at a few landmarks and fight some enemies and that's it. Secondly, what I like about this game is the development of your character is very rewarding and the keen sense of survival is a need in this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Note that I only have 10 hours playtime on Steam, but I played the game much longer on Xbox 360.This game isn't optimized on Windows 7, as Steam mentions, but there's an easy fix to Fallout 3's configuration file taht you can find online. This fixes the inconsistent crashes of the game.Now that I've ENLIGHTENED you of that, Fallout 3 is an amazing RPG. If you don't like sandbox games, don't worry, there's a great quest with markers so you don't have to wander around for things. If linear storylines aren't your thing, you can wander the vast American Wasteland, pillaging shanty towns with an evil cohort, or helping the unfortunate as a lone altruist. The game's graphics, as some mentioned, aren't state-of-the-art to 2013's standards. However, one needs to realize that this game is from 2008 and using anti-aliasing will fix jagged textures. There are plenty of visual mods for the game outside of Steam as well (no Steam Workshop support for the game).The optional VATS combat system makes the game turned based in a sense. This is perfect if you aren't a great shooter, or you want to relax more while you play.There aren't any vehicles to drive in the game, but I don't think that's much of a missing feature because the atmosphere isn't meant for driving around the Washington, D.C. metro area. The Quick Travel function in your map saves you from the fear of having to walk across the Wasteland, so no worries!There are many trainable skills in the game that will keep you busy, ranging from Equipment Repair, Medical, Hacking, and of course, Marksmanship (not exact names, but in layman's terms). If you've played Runescape or the Elder Scrolls, the skills system is very reminiscent. In addition to this, the Perks system allows you to pick a special trait each time you level your character up.I give Fallout 3: GOTY Edition a legitimate 100% rating because I find no faults in it, hence my length review.

Read this, and trust his download. I downloaded the Windows Live he had, and installed it. The game runs perfectly now. I've clocked in a few hours already, and i've had no issues; other than minor visual glitches. Which is expected in a rather old, yet huge game.Otherwise, this game is awesome. I truly suggest buying it; no matter what platform.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												Fallout 3 is a masterpiece.  You get so much freedom. You get to do whatever you want, go wherever you want to go. Do you want to kill everything that moves? You can do that. Do you want to be a more peaceful player? You can do that too. There is so much to explore. There is so many things to discover. Finding and completing quests in the capital wasteland is immense fun. Defeating enemies and collecting their loot never gets old. The story is great. Something I will never forget. From the moment you begin the game through to the end, you will enjoy every second. The soundtrack in Fallout 3 is great. You will get these songs stuck in your head. With top notch talent such as Liam Neeson and Malcolm McDowell, the voice acting is phenomenal. What Bethesda has created here is a perfect video game. But don’t stop at what they give you. There is a very strong mod community that adds even more to the game. Bethesda put so much hard work in to Fallout 3. It would be a true shame if you didn’t experience it.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I picked up and played Fallout 3 years after it was released, really, due to late discovery of gaming and *this* game. I wasn't really sure if I'd like it or not, due to the kinda intimidating heavy duty steel armor dude on the cover. I wasn't sure this game was for me. I've never been so happy to be proven wrong, and finding out that Fallout 3 is so much more than the power armor on the cover. LOL! You don't even have to wear it if you don't want to either. And that's the crux of Fallout 3  for me. Choices. Endless choices! I love this game to death. It has stood the test of time. It's just as awesome to play now like it was the first times I played it. I can play new titles, but I always come back for more Fallout 3.

												I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an open world game with a great storyline to it and the ability to go off from the main quests and do any of the side quests. With Broken Steel, the level cap is raised to 30 and the game continues past the ending of the standard game (which ends the game, no continuing) so a must buy.The world is full of characters you will come to love or hate and the way you deal with most of these can be from talking your way out of a problem to killing everyone in sight! The different perks you can choose as you advance through levels can change how you tackle problems and can have different outcomes.Although the store page says that the game is not optimised for Windows 7 and later it runs fine on Windows 8.1 after changing a line in the code (a quick google search of "fallout 3 randomly crashing" will lead you to a link which tells you what to add and where to find the file)Overall, Fallout 3 is a fun game with a good story and the freedom to explore anywhere in the game world and the DLC's only add to that experience. 9 out of 10 (because there are a few bugs but nothing seriously serious)Would highly recommend!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												1.6 hours doesn't say much, but I've picked this up (again) on PC (after playing 100s of hours on console) just for the modding scene. Sure, this is a hunk of a buggy mess, but that's because this was designed to run on WIndows Vista (and we know how much more steaming that is). Luckily, generous souls created freely availiable patches and resources to keep crashing and bugs to a minimum (which is surprising to hear from a Bethesda game). If you are interested more in map design, this is the game for you. If you are more interested in character and story, I'm pretty sure you should check Fallout: New Vegas. Don't worry, because both games take place in different places in a post-apocalyptic environment, the plot of one game will not reach the ears of the other coast in time to spoil the plot of the other game. TL;DR both games have an unrelated plot as they take place in different settings of the same universe.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												I was born March 24, 2259, in an old hospital. My mother passed away when I was born. My dad always told me she was the most beautiful woman in the wastes. Sometimes, when Fawkes isn't around, I sit down with Dogmeat and play old tapes on my Pip-Boy where my mom talks a lot. Sure, it's the same few tapes, and I've remembered every word she says, but no matter how much I listen to the tapes, I never can imagine how it would sound for her to say "I love you". It's been hard since my dad died too. I watched him sacrifice himself for the greater good of mankind. Wherever my mom and dad are right now, I just hope they're proud of me. I didn't blow up Megaton, or Kill any human or ghoul from Tenpenny, and I even blew up two Enclave bases full of thousands of people. Though they might hate me because I eat human flesh for the glory of Satan...911/10 I'll mezz you and send you to Paradise Falls if you don't play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												[Review written 15,06,2015] [After Fallout NV]Minor disclaimer before the review; I have actually played around 30hrs of this game upon time of review, however steam doesn't count it as I run the game through FOSE launcher for windows 7 stability reasons. Fallout 3 is one of the most atmospheric games I’ve played. Fallout 3 unlike its Mojave counterpart describes a world of hardship and fear with a large emphasis on villainy and morality. Much like the people of the wastes the player too must choose how to play, either in self-serving villainy or selfless heroism. Choses can be made via dialogue options or real-time decision making. Combat in Fallout 3 is an excellent cross between fps and real-time strategy, as the player is able to battle using their own accuracy and skill or by entering VATS which pauses the game and allow the player to make precise shots at certain enemy weak points. Graphically Fallout 3 was a masterpiece of its time, however today Fallout 3 is showing its age as some ground and wall textures are looking quite muddy. The one gripe I would have to say about Fallout 3 is that it doesn’t give you an awful lot of direction in the beginning of the game which could turn off some first timers to the series. All in all Fallout 3 is still to this day one of the greatest RPG’s ever created with its enthralling atmosphere and solid combat system. I give fallout 3 a 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												     If you never played a Fallout game before, try the original Fallout before picking this up.  Whether you enjoyed the first or not, and whether you tried the second as well, then see how long you can last playing this mess of a game.     I'll admit, when I first picked it up, I enjoyed it immeadiately, and binged it for hours.  It is quite a bit of fun, if not stupid fun.  As you play on, you begin to realize how loosely the story and world of the game is held together.  The plot is nonsensical, the characters are cliche as hell, there are strictly two sides (black and white of course) to the story, the weapons are uninspired and bland, and they, to say it in a juvenile fashion, feel like sticks with♥♥♥♥♥♥on the ends of them.  Not to mention the game's enviornment is spotty and dull.  That green tint can get ♥♥♥♥ing old quick, and oftentimes, you will have no idea where you are until you take a gander at the map.  It's like Bethesdashit just made a basic desert world on a piece of paper, tacked it to the wall, and threw a ♥♥♥♥-ton of darts at it to denote where they would put places, events, towns, and so-on.  No rhyme or reason as to where anything is.        This game also suffers from the same problem that a lot of Bethesdacrap games have, such as very poorly made animations, weapons that feel like cardboard sticks or airsoft guns, ugly as sin character models, a strong lack of voice actors to compensate for the vast amount of "unique" characters in the game, no vareity in clothing, and broke leveling mechanics.  Di I say the story makes no sense when you look at the big picture?  It's as if a pre-teen fanfic writer smoked some pot and wanted to make a Fallout story.       Despite these shortcomings, I rate the game a 4/10 for having a small amount of replayability, a vision that shines through the cracks of caked-on♥♥♥♥♥♥ and a very nostalgic and memorable soundtrack (not the terrible and generic OST created for the game, I'm talking about anything that plays on Galaxy News Radio, and not Three-dog's annoying vocal-chord vibrations he calls a voice).       Once you trudge through the wasteland, play every DLC (if you didn't max out your character's level by the end of the game) minus Mothership Zeta for something different, and then high-tail your♥♥♥♥♥to the Mojave in Fallout New Vegas, which in my opnion, is the true Fallout 3.  Do NOT skip this game if you intend to jump into New Vegas!  If you play this first, you will enjoy it a tad, and it will allow you to enjoy New Vegas a lot more due to the problems it fixes and the soul it has to offer.  If you play New Vegas first, you will not enjoy Fallout 3 at all, making both games seem kind of dull and leaving a bad taste in your mouth.  Just pray that Bethesdick collaborates with the guys behind New Vegas on the next Fallout.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Fallout 3 - ah the red headed stepchild in fallout series. The elders scrolls: Fallout is a cliche name but so spot on. Also this is the reason while community is so torn about this game. Fans wanted it to be in line with it's predecessor, Bethesda didn't deliver, only used the IP.Still love it or hate it, Fallout 3 is a good game - IF you like exploration and loot hoarding. But it's a bad RPG - be it cliche story, odd combat or very streamlined stats behind. It does deliver the Fallout series feeling of the nuclear wasteland with buried civilization wonders. You explore the old Vaults and wonder what happened here?The DLCs aren't really groundbreaking, more loot, more monsters, more mini quests and locations. Mods are crucial part of this game, especially now when it aged and cause problem on newer PCs and operating systems.Also they do enchance both combat and too casual mechanics that made game too streamlined and easy. Can't really help with poor and old graphic or with poor role-playing side. Anything else you'll find at nexus mods.Despite this being a different approach to fallout series I do recoomend it to everyone, especially with all DLCs and various mods that help to customize it to your likings.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												After spending hours in this game and many more to come, I can easily say this is one of the best gaming experiences I ever had. You play as a child, living in the vault with your father. But one day your father leaves and you leave the vault looking for him in the big wasteland of Washington DC. On your journey you can decide how your character will react, do or what weapons he uses. The world is amazing, almost breathtaking for a wasteland. Not to mention the soundtrack aswell as the character you will meet with be stuck forever with you. The DLC for the game is also great and enjoyable, a little bit too short unlike New Vegas but still very fun. This game is simply Legendary and a must have in my opinion, also a plus is that you can mod it so be sure to check Fallout 3 Nexus for mods.P.S: Get Dogmeat.P.P.S: Don't mind the low game time, I'm using a special launcher for modding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												One of the best RPG's of all time, just like the rest of the Fallout series. It is also the first modern Fallout title. Oddly Fallout 3 is critically acclaimed across the board as you can see with a 91 metacritic score, as well as overwhelmingly highly regarded by most RPG lovers, but is WOEFULLY underrated and under-apreciated by quite a few of the older fans of the Fallout franchise. It makes no sense to me, because I love all of the Fallouts and don't see this heavily exaggerated "lore-bashing" that apparently Fallout 3 has/does. In fact, I as well as most people feel Bethesda Game Studios did a terrific job setting the tone of the old Fallouts and staying in line with the lore with Fallout 3. Regardless, you're doing yourself a disservice if you're an avid RPG fan and not playing Fallout 3 or the rest of the Fallout franchise. They're all terrific RPG's that all offer an equally unique, darkly funny, retro-futuristic, bleak and twisted tone. Each quest can be completed in multiple ways. Fallout 3 is a great RPG, and you should definitely play it, as well as Fallout: NV, Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Fallout Tactics ain't half bad either. Fallout 3 is a 10/10 easily for me. Great RPG, that is part of a great RPG franchise. Go play it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I FINALLY found a fix that works, so I am editing my review accordingly. (Win 7, 64 bit)1. If editing the FALLOUT.INI file as indicated on other steam forums does not work, then2. locate the FALLOUT3.EXE file, and right click  and select Properties, then compatibility. Change the compatibility mode to run program  as Windows XP, Service Pack 3.3. If that STILL does not work then again open the Compatibility tab on the FALLOUT3.exe and ALSO check the boxes for -Disable Visual ThemesAND-Disable Desktop Composition.then click APPLY#3 is the one that fixed it for me!!  Hope this helps!

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
I Don't Want To Set The World On Fire, I Just Want To Start A Flame In Your Pants - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]The jump from 2D to 3D can often times be a defining moment for a game series. The evolution of game mechanics and sometimes even the shift in genre can make or break its impact on old fans and new audiences alike. Some only play 3D Zelda games, some only play 2D Mario. Megaman Legends was something of an underrated flop, despite how much I loved it. That's just how it goes. And let's not even bring up Sonic. Sometimes the love for a particular franchise, a specific character or story, can't transcend the type of game. Some people are shallow♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥like that, only caring about their favorite game because of how it is on the outside. It's what's on the inside that counts. Just because your favorite series suddenly has different mechanics, you're gonna leave it for the next pretty game? How could you.Surprisingly, all these beloved childhood characters aren't the only ones with blood feuds going on in the fanbase. Sure, they're the ones that are deemed "acceptable" to argue about. For the most part. Except Sonic, arguing about Sonic just disappoints your parents.Fallout is another massive franchise with a split fanbase. Fallout 1 and 2 were highly acclaimed tactical CRPG's, with dedicated followings. However, after being acquired by Bethesda, Fallout 3 took the series in a new direction.Fallout 3 is an action-RPG, feeling more like an FPS at times than a strategy RPG. Some say Fallout 3 ruined Fallout, making it essentially an Elder Scrolls with guns. Some say Bethesda is what saved Fallout from falling into obscurity.While both are valid looks on what became of Fallout, I personally feel like they're both rather narrow-minded looks on the issue. Fallout 3 still manages to capture so much of the essence of Fallout, even if it's not a carbon copy of Fallout 1 or 2.Much like past Fallout games, there's a huge emphasis on character building. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system is back, along with all of the other classic Fallout skills and traits. Over the course of the game you'll be leveling up and allocating skill points to different skills to improve your ability to sneak around, wield different kinds of weapons, or even stuff like persuasion or bartering. There are no bad skills to focus on, as the game is balanced enough to allow any skill set to be viable. Bonus traits are also granted with each level and give you a selection of unique perks to choose from, boosting your combat ability against certain enemy types, giving bonuses to different skills, or even allowing you to choose special dialogue options or use special skills in certain scenarios.Fallout's karma system is back as well, allowing your character to be as unique as possible.My character was Captain Sugartits, unstable mass murderer and crazed drug and sex addict. Captain isn't a title or anything, it's just a part of her name. You know how people can have two first names, like Mary Anne or something? Yeah, Captain Sugartits. Her father chose the name himself.Her major skills were Sneaking, Lockpicking, and Science. She started out mild-mannered enough, but her thirst for science, blood, hard drugs, and violent lesbian sex drove her to massacre entire settlements. However, she gave like a hundred bottles of purified water to a homeless man overcome with radiation poisoning. So she was the murderous saint of the wasteland. She would enter any settlement and steal whatever wasn't bolted down, but the second someone talked to her with any sort of attitude she'd shoot up the town. She was quite unstable.Fallout 3 manages to capture the spirit of the original Fallout in a beautiful way. Exploration and discovery is not spurred on by curiosity, or by demand. No one tells you to go explore. Fallout 3 has a massive, open world to explore. There are side-quests everywhere, secrets and surprises tucked all over the wasteland. But it doesn't hold you by the hand and guide you to each of these. No, exploration is driven by necessity. You're helpless and weak once you leave your Vault, and the means to defend yourself isn't free. You'll need to forage for weapons and ammo, forage for food and medicine, and forage for any other items of value to sell for whatever necessities you can't find from foraging. And it never ends. Even after you've found a powerful weapon, you'll need money or parts to repair it as its condition wears down. And what you're fighting will only escalate in strength, from mutated insects to corrupt leftover government weirdos. The struggle never ends. The struggle is real.The karma system actually factors right into this as well. Before the Cap snapped and went on her rampage across the wasteland, staying armed and ready to fight was incredibly difficult. The only way I was able to arm myself to the teeth was from stealing everything, robbing and murdering whoever I could, and doing quite a bit of less-than kosher deeds. It really solidifies the idea of the world that you're in. It's hard to be good. There's not enough to go around, and it's a constant struggle to exist.Fallout 3 is a masterpiece of smart game design, and still one of the best open-ended RPG's out there. Getting lost in the world of Fallout 3 is a blast. And most of all, it still feels like Fallout. The same style and charm is still there. Except you can't kill kids anymore, no matter how annoying the little ♥♥♥♥♥ are.Not that I'D want to, I'm just saying. For realism's sake. If a deranged murderer hopped up on drugs and lesbians got talked down to by a little brat, don't you think she'd mini-nuke the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them? I'm just saying.When it really comes down to which Fallout style I prefer though, classic 1 and 2 or the Bethesda-style in 3, I prefer both because they're both fun. Stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing you nerds.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Please note that some users have issues getting the game to run on Windows 7 and up, there are fixes available thanks to the community though.Ah Fallout 3, such a great game (I owned a copy 5 years ago that just used Games For Windows Live). Definitely one of those games that you will never forget, and worth every penny.Story takes place with you being born, from there you name your character and predict how you'll look in the future when you're older. Your mother dies due to complications when giving birth. The first half hour or so is you growing up over many years where you select your S.P.E.C.I.A.L abilities, get your pip-boy and BB gun, take the G.O.A.T test, and then eventually leave the vault you grew up in for 19 or so years to explore the wasteland and demolished Washington D.C. There are many great people you will meet along the way, but you will also make plenty of enemies. You truly feel in control with this game, there's nothing you can't do. Wanna blow up a town with a nuke? Go ahead! Wanna disarm the nuke and save the town? Go ahead! Wanna explore the entire world from top to bottom? Go right on ahead, nothing stops you. There's so many great things about Fallout 3 that you really should experience if you haven't already. Plus what's a better way to get ready for Fallout 4 than by killing ghouls and mutants in D.C?I rate this game a 9.5/10 . It has it's bugs and other little issues, but it is definitely worth every penny.Oh and since we're on the PC...you can mod the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game to your hearts content.

												I played this game both on PC and PS3, and with a total of about 70 hours, i can tell MHO about this masterpiece of the old-gen games.In this game, the first of the saga developed by Bethesda (The original Fallout 3 was named Van Bouren by the original SH) you can basically do anything, from choosing the fate of a dweller, to changing the entire world, like destroying a city, or changing the president in a city.But the game isn't "just" that, it's basically a GDR mixed with FPS things.The Lone Wanderer can have lots of weapons, like blades, baseball bats, laser and plasma rifles, sniper rifles and more, and their unique variant.As weapons, lots of clothes/armors.So, Fallout 3 rests an unbeaten masterpiece of the old-gen games, with a addictive story, lots of side quests and choices to do, and a background lore that criticize the american warlike government aspiring at the oil supremacy. (Yeah, in 2077 oil wells They were completely dried up, so it started another war, against China)Anyone should play this game, really.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												The road so far......wasn't kind to me. It was full of loss and misery. Full of hopeless people and lost souls that stepped on this doomed wasteland.Yet, it wasn't only damnation that followed my steps. I found my father, my love Amata, a faithful companions... only to loose them the next second.If this was the road so far, what will follow it? I know you can't talk, my good, old, friend, dogmeat. Despite that, I know you can listen, you are the only one who does that. So, thank you, buddy.________________________After 95 hours I finally finished this unique game. It was a long journey that, sadly, or not, came to the conclusion.I have mixed feeling because I can not, but to notice, the flaws of this game.The combat is far from perfection. Constant invisible walls interfere in the shooting so that stealth and sniper headshot from a far is not an option. It is frustrating at times, but the VATS does a perfect job to overcome the combat flaws. It balances it.Writing of the main story. It's not good. It's average. It does the job to send you to a different locations and introduce the world, but that's it. I do like the small stories, though, which this world is packed to it's fullest and the enormous attention to detail. But the main plot... At the end, the feeling is that the bone was thrown and if we search enogh we can find it. In any case, sadly, it's not there. A mere feel of a presence of something epic is not what we want.Don't take me the wrong way. I like this game. It's good. Not perfect but good enough. There isn't any very good highlights but the mixture and huge diversity make this game a unique experience worth to check...if you push by yourself and force to go throw the tedious start that keept me aways the 2 past attempts to play Fallout 3.First 20 levels are a joy to play. You keep discovering new things and some quite memorable moments. A very simple details engage with a perfection to this unworthy world: A text based story about Grognak that you play on a terminal; Tranquility Lane; Princess who is secretly in love with the leader of Little Lamplight; Brother who got two naughty nightwear; A old man who I saved from suicide attempts.Despite the average writing of the main plot where it shines is in the clues of the past. There is no history in Fallout 3. Though, it creates an understanding of the past by the logs, terminals and documents. And it does the job like non other game up this date. The contradictive information, the vision of people of the those past events - at times I felt like archaeologist.There are a huge depth that you can completely ignore and focus on the aspects you like. Do whatever. The world is there. What do you gonna do in it?________________________It happened before and it will happen again.So many killed, so much destroyed... and yet it's not enough, it is never enough. Because war... war never changes.It is time, we need to go my friend. Our journey has just started.


Into the sunset. The last moment of my gameplay. 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: KyrDerz

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I FINALLY found a fix that works, so I am editing my review accordingly. (Win 7, 64 bit)1. If editing the FALLOUT.INI file as indicated on other steam forums does not work, then2. locate the FALLOUT3.EXE file, and right click  and select Properties, then compatibility. Change the compatibility mode to run program  as Windows XP, Service Pack 3.3. If that STILL does not work then again open the Compatibility tab on the FALLOUT3.exe and ALSO check the boxes for -Disable Visual ThemesAND-Disable Desktop Composition.then click APPLY#3 is the one that fixed it for me!!  Hope this helps!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												***IMPORTANT: if you want to play this game on Windows 7 and newer versions of windows, you'll likely need to download the Unooffical fallout 3 patch. Otherwise you'll find out very quickly that the game crashes all the time, making it unplayable. Just go to Nexus mod website (just use google) to download this mod, it's pretty much mandatory. Don't spend hours on the internet looking for ways to fix the issue, this mod will fix it all and it's very simple. And while you're there, get some of the other top mods that will greatly enhance your playing experience.***It's an absolutely brilliant game, when playing this game you HAVE to do all the major sidequests to experience and appreciate it fully. Don't rusth through it, take your time. The graphics may look a little old nowadays, but you can enhance them greatly with mods aswell. The main story is very good, the lore of the game is fantastic and the gameplay is also excellent (although, again mods will enhance this).I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games with an open world sandbox environment, but most importantly: I recommend this game for people who enjoy a great and emersive story. It's different than the Elder Scrolls but in many ways just as epic and emersive. If you like post-Apocalyptic settings like 'The Walking Dead' I'm sure you'll love scrounging through the metro stations and sewers of the DC area, encountering countless feral ghouls (zombies), Super Mutants and other mutated freaks! Extremely high replayability value aswell.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												-----TL;DR-----Buyer beware, Fallout GOTY edition WILL NOT work out of the box. Unless you know how to download, add, and/or modify files (to improve stability and performance). Then purchase at your own risk.If you do purhase the game, then for the love of god, TURN OFF AUTOSAVES! Turn all of them off and learn to manually save or it WILL corrupt your save files. So unless you want to wave goodbye to your 100 plus hours worth of gameplay, then do it!-----Review-----Fallout 3, good lord, this game was the pinnacle of it's genre when released. After all these years, oh how the mighty have fallen. Sure, the gameplay and story have faired pretty well and mods abound to enhance the experiance. But from a software standpoint, Fallout 3 has seen better days.I can't even begin to tell you the amount of time I have lost thanks in part to a fualty save system that was never really fixed as well as copious amounts of crashes and freezes thanks in part to a lack of compatability and/or optimization for newer systems. This isn't even taking into account the amount of time lost from trying to get the game to run.Now don't get me wrong, this game ran well for a while and I was able to put 20 hours into the game. Until, my save files become currupted. Yeah, technically, I could start again. But after losing so much, I just can't bring myself to continue this game.Now, I just feel angry and drained. All that wasted time just getting the damn game running and for what?! Just to get curbed stomped?! Why the hell is this abandoned product still allowed to be sold then? In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game in it's current decrepit state.(Note: Having to launch the game through FOSE or Fallout Script Extender did not allow for Steam to record total playtime clocked)

												This is my favourite game of all time. I have hundreds of hundreds of hours on this game from both console and when I had it installed as a non Steam game and I will have hundreds of hours more having just reinstalled it through Steam after losing my old version in a new Windows install.This game is pretty broken without some tweaking, but once tweaked it is well worth the effort and I found the DLCs to be enjoyable and a good value. There are a ton of guides and hidden gems to find which will teach you about the best way to tweak the game and install mods and after spending many (or few) boring hours reading and collecting your mods you will see for yourself that it is well, well worth it.This game is better now than it has ever been and a few hours invested in setting it up (I know this sounds horrible*) will really pay off.*You don't have to spend this long if you don't want to but to become really well informed on how to tweak and mod Fallout in an efficient and stable way then it will take this long but it IS worth it as it will completely transform the game in nearly any way you want.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Note that I only have 10 hours playtime on Steam, but I played the game much longer on Xbox 360.This game isn't optimized on Windows 7, as Steam mentions, but there's an easy fix to Fallout 3's configuration file taht you can find online. This fixes the inconsistent crashes of the game.Now that I've ENLIGHTENED you of that, Fallout 3 is an amazing RPG. If you don't like sandbox games, don't worry, there's a great quest with markers so you don't have to wander around for things. If linear storylines aren't your thing, you can wander the vast American Wasteland, pillaging shanty towns with an evil cohort, or helping the unfortunate as a lone altruist. The game's graphics, as some mentioned, aren't state-of-the-art to 2013's standards. However, one needs to realize that this game is from 2008 and using anti-aliasing will fix jagged textures. There are plenty of visual mods for the game outside of Steam as well (no Steam Workshop support for the game).The optional VATS combat system makes the game turned based in a sense. This is perfect if you aren't a great shooter, or you want to relax more while you play.There aren't any vehicles to drive in the game, but I don't think that's much of a missing feature because the atmosphere isn't meant for driving around the Washington, D.C. metro area. The Quick Travel function in your map saves you from the fear of having to walk across the Wasteland, so no worries!There are many trainable skills in the game that will keep you busy, ranging from Equipment Repair, Medical, Hacking, and of course, Marksmanship (not exact names, but in layman's terms). If you've played Runescape or the Elder Scrolls, the skills system is very reminiscent. In addition to this, the Perks system allows you to pick a special trait each time you level your character up.I give Fallout 3: GOTY Edition a legitimate 100% rating because I find no faults in it, hence my length review.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This game, unlike the ElderScrolls Series, is not always for the casual player, even on very easy some enemies and places can be a nighmare of difficulty  if you dont have the right gear, or enough stimpacks of course, but saying that, I very much prefer this game to skyrim, possibly even Oblivion or Morrowind in the ElderScrolls series, and im very much anticipating Fallout 4 in the next year or two, People's faces and voices are much better in the fallout games than in the ElderScroll games, and you cant forget about 3dog, very good music, humor, quests, interesting things for people who love Washington D.C. as well and want to explore the radioactive wreckage of the capital, and the surrounding wastelands of course, It was interesting seeing the RobCo HQ, more vaults, and the Capital Itself, Very well made DLC, from aliens, to virtual reality, to slavers in pittsburgh, I would recommend this as a starter for Fallout games, even though it is the 3rd one, it is not very connected to the others, as it is from Bethesda, who did not make the first 2 games, although, the first 2 games excel in story and gameplay as well, and I recommend them as well, in the end its your choice, but if you have 20 bucks to spare, spend them on something that can provide limitless hours of entertainment, hundreds of locations, a good few laughs, good music, a Legendary Father, a few tear jerking moments, Horrifying Moral choices, and of course GARY! So yes, you should play this game, and talk about it, sing the songs outloud if you want, just have fun. Note, do not play this game just because you think, look, skyrim with guns, its alot more than that, and Warfare is slightly weak in this game, this is more for those Nerdy, Lore loving people out there, not the ones that claim to be real gamers, the ones who spend hundreds of hours finding every little secret, seeing every site, doing every mission, loading and reloading games to fix mistakes and prevent deaths, those people, those people are the real gamers, and the people who will enjoy this game the most.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the amount of hours played here: I had never owned it on Steam previously, but I have honestly put 200+ hours into this in my lifetime. I played Fallout 3 when it came out on a whim, not being overly familiar with the rest of the Fallout franchise, and it was the best decision I ever made, to stick to it even though at first I was not so sure if I liked it or not. Then, as I advanced properly into the Capital Wasteland and the story unfolded itself, it became my second favourite video game of all time (alongside BioShock 1/2). Though the engine may be old in today's standards, it does not discount anything at all; the grimy Wasteland has become a sort of home to me, every single character I have encountered is likeable, even the baddies that go around killing♥♥♥♥♥♥ even the beloved cannibal-incestuous families of Andale that make you human-meat pies if you promise to stay quiet about their ways. This game shows you a portrayal of a world where the 50s never left it though technology went on, and accurately shows the progression of human survival after we succeeded at killing the world via nuclear warfare. There are so many heartwrenching moments, and just as many hilarious ones--all companions are likable, and every quest the Lone Wanderer undertakes is meaningful. Even the side quests serve good purposes, and I never tire of exploring the Wasteland though I may have scoured it from corner to corner by now. Like I've said, the Fallout world has become a very familiar place to me now, somewhere that is so replayable and full of vitality, ironically in a radiation-riddled landscape. I prefer it to Fallout: New Vegas only out of the story content, feeling the latter to be superior only by a hair. This was the first step of Bethesda's revival of the franchise, after all, and will remain forever in my heart as the best of the two. Please play this if you haven't, so that you can get a feel for the Fallout universe before Fallout 4 comes out. HYPE(my icon is actually of my Lone Wanderer, Eden, funnily enough)

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Fallout 3. My gosh, this game is near to perfection. This game is my favorite RPG at the moment, I mean, every RPG fan needs to play this game. NEEDS TO. Especially GOTY Edition, it's only $20 such a good deal. Lets sum up the story.You and your Dad lived in a vault, your Dad (played by Liam Neeson) leaves the vault, to find a water purifier called the 'G.E.C.K.' You also leave the vault, in search of your father. Now, let me tell you the pros and the cons of this game +DLCPros+Unlike Oblivion, Fo3 is a very immersive game+Lots of interesting characters as you progress through the game. +Most of the DLC (Except Mothership Zeta) is actually pretty good, my personal favorite is The Pitt+Lots of weapons and guns, lasers, and plasma rifles are awesome, and the Fat Man+The Soundtrack in this game is superb, I love the oldies music in this game.+ Interesting antagonist (The Enclave)+ The Power Armor (Whether BOS or Enclave) is freaking sweet+ Most of the Companions are interesting,and fun to use+ Lots of places to explore+ THe Perk System is great, makes the game more fun+ V.A.T.S. just makes this game morew fun than ever+ You can put a lot of hours into this game, and not get bored (I know at the moment it says i put 52 hours, but i put much more on the ps3.)Cons- Comanions die if they lose all of their health, luckily for the dog comapnion there's a perk to have him have another dog, but you can't get that perk until much later in the game.- The ending without the Broken Steel DLC, Sucks, once you complete the story, without the dlc, it doesnt let you go back- The DLC Mothership Zeta was a HUGE disappointment for me, you're not missing out if you dont play it. (except for the new guns)- Poorly optimized for Windows 7 and up, and Bethesda refused to patch it, you can get an unofficial patch that will fix this problem.So... Despite some of the Minor flaws this game has, it is still a fantastic RPG that must be played by anyone that calls themselves an RPG fanFinal Verdit: 9.5/10 MUST BUY

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really love this game and recommend it any day. Period.If you're turned away by the age (8 years old, as of this review...my god I feel old), realise that there are always mods to do anything you felt was missing, or that you thought the game needed to compete with newer roleplaying games. Although the modding community is absolutely incredible, I recommend completing one playthrough without mods. Just to get the intended experience at least once. Now, as for what the game offers...I'll do this in a simple way that I've seen pretty often on here, so you should know it.PROS:+ Atmosphere is perfect. There's something about the look and feel of the wasteland that just makes you feel really immersed+ Soundtrack is very good, using classic songs from the 50s-60s era, which is a nice bit of irony. Cheery music, destroyed world+ Character building and connections are done extremely well in this game, which a few exceptions. I personally cared about many of the characters throughout my travels of the Capital Wasteland+ SO MUCH TO EXPLORE! There are just over a hundred (if my memory is correct) marked locations in the base game world, but so many more hidden in all of the nooks and crannies of DC. And often you'll find yourself learning more about what happened to people in those locations, which really helps establish the open world+ The player has many choices to make, some make subtle changes, while others completely change everything. Choose wisely+ Lots of variety and freedom. The quest design is done so that the player can take so many different paths to achieve something, which definitely adds to the roleplaying experience+ Incredible amounts of replayability. Tying in with the last two points, this game has so many things to do, it is impossible to see everything in just one playthrough+ Variety in weapons and armour. Want to deck yourself out in full power armour? Sure. Just want to chill out in pyjamas? You've got it. What about running around in a duster coat and a clown mask? I don't see why not. And as for weapons...there are dozens of weapons at your disposal, most of which have unique variants for you to collect+ So much to do! There are hundreds of quests to be completed, dozens of unique weapons and armour to be found, hundreds of locations to explore and learn about, and so much more. This game is filled to the brim with content+ If you want more, the Fallout 3 Nexus has thousands of mods for you to tweak your game with, allowing for even more replayabilityCONS:- Gunplay is horrible. You do get used to it after a while, but it still has a slight cringe factor- Some of the voice acting is a little weak. Given the scale of the game, I do give it a bit of a pass on it- Pretty annoying to actually start up. It took me a few hours of tinkering with files and downloading patches before it worked, but now it runs fantastic and I don't believe that it has crashed on me yet

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												UPDATE: So after having not played this game for almost a year now, and having since upgraded to Windows 10 since the original posting of this review, I thought it would be a good idea to see if Fallout 3 is still broken. After downloading the game and its DLC, installing all of it, and then spending about 2 hours modding the heck out of it, I can safely say that Fallout 3 is running (at least for now) absoulutely flawlessly on my Windows 10 machine! I cannot overstate how awesome this is! This is by far and away one of my favorite games of all time, and I am SO happy that it is working on the newest hardware! What are you waiting for?! BUY THIS GAME ALREADY!Fallout 3 is one of the best video games of all time.  Fallout 3 is one of my favorite videogames of all time.  Fallout 3 is also extremely broken on anything above Windows XP.  It pains me to say this because I absolutely love this game!  (Ignore my hours played I have spent at least 200+ hours in this game on the Xbox 360 version as well as the PC version) I have had a myriad of issues with the PC version of Fallout 3 ever since I upgraded to Windows 8.  I have tried various things to attempt to fix the constant CTDs I receive when playing this game all to no avail.  If you happen to have a PC that is running Windows XP (I also hear that Windows 7 kinda works as well) then by all means you owe it to yourself to play this amazing game!  For anyone using Windows 8 or the newly released Windows 10, you have been warned.Despite not working on my Windows 8 PC, I feel like I can still recommend this game because of all the fun I've already had.  If Bethesda decides to patch this in the future then I will certainly be redownloading and replaying Fallout 3.TL;DRFallout 3 is prone to constant CTDs when being played on a Windows 8 PC.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Probably one of the best RPG/Sci-Fi/Open World games that you can get. Really great. If you have Windows 7 or later, then just get a patch on Nexus, that will fix it, the game (as far as I remember/know) has problems running on Quad Core Processor. And some more stuff. Just google "Dansgaming - How to mod Fallout 3" there you can get many great ideas, and a very easy tutorial to fix Fallout 3, the first video should be about the patch, if you only want that one.Besides that, I can say that the game has some great moments, you have no idea how satisfying it is to throw a grenade at a bunch of raiders in slow-mo VATS. Just great.The game comes with some great DLC/Expansions to the main game, that is really worth checking out. If you have earlier tried out games such as Fallout 1-2 and New Vegas, or maybe some other games in the same genre, like the other Bethesda games, like Skyrim, this is worth trying out, trust me on that. And also, if you have played it 1-2 times, then try modding it, it can dramatically change your experience and look at the game, the modding community of the Bethesda games a thriving, and there are no short of people that will happily help you get starting modding.All in all, probably the greatest game I have ever played.PS: The reason I haven't so many hours, is because I played a pirated version before (I know, hang me), and when I got it myself, I had problems with the optimization part of Fallout 3 for Windows 7, all fixed now ofc.If you are unsure, then get it on a sale.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
I Don't Want To Set The World On Fire, I Just Want To Start A Flame In Your Pants - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]The jump from 2D to 3D can often times be a defining moment for a game series. The evolution of game mechanics and sometimes even the shift in genre can make or break its impact on old fans and new audiences alike. Some only play 3D Zelda games, some only play 2D Mario. Megaman Legends was something of an underrated flop, despite how much I loved it. That's just how it goes. And let's not even bring up Sonic. Sometimes the love for a particular franchise, a specific character or story, can't transcend the type of game. Some people are shallow♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥like that, only caring about their favorite game because of how it is on the outside. It's what's on the inside that counts. Just because your favorite series suddenly has different mechanics, you're gonna leave it for the next pretty game? How could you.Surprisingly, all these beloved childhood characters aren't the only ones with blood feuds going on in the fanbase. Sure, they're the ones that are deemed "acceptable" to argue about. For the most part. Except Sonic, arguing about Sonic just disappoints your parents.Fallout is another massive franchise with a split fanbase. Fallout 1 and 2 were highly acclaimed tactical CRPG's, with dedicated followings. However, after being acquired by Bethesda, Fallout 3 took the series in a new direction.Fallout 3 is an action-RPG, feeling more like an FPS at times than a strategy RPG. Some say Fallout 3 ruined Fallout, making it essentially an Elder Scrolls with guns. Some say Bethesda is what saved Fallout from falling into obscurity.While both are valid looks on what became of Fallout, I personally feel like they're both rather narrow-minded looks on the issue. Fallout 3 still manages to capture so much of the essence of Fallout, even if it's not a carbon copy of Fallout 1 or 2.Much like past Fallout games, there's a huge emphasis on character building. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system is back, along with all of the other classic Fallout skills and traits. Over the course of the game you'll be leveling up and allocating skill points to different skills to improve your ability to sneak around, wield different kinds of weapons, or even stuff like persuasion or bartering. There are no bad skills to focus on, as the game is balanced enough to allow any skill set to be viable. Bonus traits are also granted with each level and give you a selection of unique perks to choose from, boosting your combat ability against certain enemy types, giving bonuses to different skills, or even allowing you to choose special dialogue options or use special skills in certain scenarios.Fallout's karma system is back as well, allowing your character to be as unique as possible.My character was Captain Sugartits, unstable mass murderer and crazed drug and sex addict. Captain isn't a title or anything, it's just a part of her name. You know how people can have two first names, like Mary Anne or something? Yeah, Captain Sugartits. Her father chose the name himself.Her major skills were Sneaking, Lockpicking, and Science. She started out mild-mannered enough, but her thirst for science, blood, hard drugs, and violent lesbian sex drove her to massacre entire settlements. However, she gave like a hundred bottles of purified water to a homeless man overcome with radiation poisoning. So she was the murderous saint of the wasteland. She would enter any settlement and steal whatever wasn't bolted down, but the second someone talked to her with any sort of attitude she'd shoot up the town. She was quite unstable.Fallout 3 manages to capture the spirit of the original Fallout in a beautiful way. Exploration and discovery is not spurred on by curiosity, or by demand. No one tells you to go explore. Fallout 3 has a massive, open world to explore. There are side-quests everywhere, secrets and surprises tucked all over the wasteland. But it doesn't hold you by the hand and guide you to each of these. No, exploration is driven by necessity. You're helpless and weak once you leave your Vault, and the means to defend yourself isn't free. You'll need to forage for weapons and ammo, forage for food and medicine, and forage for any other items of value to sell for whatever necessities you can't find from foraging. And it never ends. Even after you've found a powerful weapon, you'll need money or parts to repair it as its condition wears down. And what you're fighting will only escalate in strength, from mutated insects to corrupt leftover government weirdos. The struggle never ends. The struggle is real.The karma system actually factors right into this as well. Before the Cap snapped and went on her rampage across the wasteland, staying armed and ready to fight was incredibly difficult. The only way I was able to arm myself to the teeth was from stealing everything, robbing and murdering whoever I could, and doing quite a bit of less-than kosher deeds. It really solidifies the idea of the world that you're in. It's hard to be good. There's not enough to go around, and it's a constant struggle to exist.Fallout 3 is a masterpiece of smart game design, and still one of the best open-ended RPG's out there. Getting lost in the world of Fallout 3 is a blast. And most of all, it still feels like Fallout. The same style and charm is still there. Except you can't kill kids anymore, no matter how annoying the little ♥♥♥♥♥ are.Not that I'D want to, I'm just saying. For realism's sake. If a deranged murderer hopped up on drugs and lesbians got talked down to by a little brat, don't you think she'd mini-nuke the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them? I'm just saying.When it really comes down to which Fallout style I prefer though, classic 1 and 2 or the Bethesda-style in 3, I prefer both because they're both fun. Stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing you nerds.

												I find this game enjoyable and not too far from Oblivion. I purchased this when on sale and would recommend the same. The pros of this game: easier to get into role playing mood than Oblivion; weapons and guns are unexpectedly fun to use; atmosphere and mapping/world are good. Cons: similar to Oblivion -- the game engine still needs some work including the sneaking system, AI, movement mechanics, and character animations; the menu system isn't far off from Oblivion's and I would have liked to seen some better organization; can get boring.All in all, I think it's a great game but it could have been better with some core game changes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Note that I only have 10 hours playtime on Steam, but I played the game much longer on Xbox 360.This game isn't optimized on Windows 7, as Steam mentions, but there's an easy fix to Fallout 3's configuration file taht you can find online. This fixes the inconsistent crashes of the game.Now that I've ENLIGHTENED you of that, Fallout 3 is an amazing RPG. If you don't like sandbox games, don't worry, there's a great quest with markers so you don't have to wander around for things. If linear storylines aren't your thing, you can wander the vast American Wasteland, pillaging shanty towns with an evil cohort, or helping the unfortunate as a lone altruist. The game's graphics, as some mentioned, aren't state-of-the-art to 2013's standards. However, one needs to realize that this game is from 2008 and using anti-aliasing will fix jagged textures. There are plenty of visual mods for the game outside of Steam as well (no Steam Workshop support for the game).The optional VATS combat system makes the game turned based in a sense. This is perfect if you aren't a great shooter, or you want to relax more while you play.There aren't any vehicles to drive in the game, but I don't think that's much of a missing feature because the atmosphere isn't meant for driving around the Washington, D.C. metro area. The Quick Travel function in your map saves you from the fear of having to walk across the Wasteland, so no worries!There are many trainable skills in the game that will keep you busy, ranging from Equipment Repair, Medical, Hacking, and of course, Marksmanship (not exact names, but in layman's terms). If you've played Runescape or the Elder Scrolls, the skills system is very reminiscent. In addition to this, the Perks system allows you to pick a special trait each time you level your character up.I give Fallout 3: GOTY Edition a legitimate 100% rating because I find no faults in it, hence my length review.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Once I got this game to work on my Windows 7 computer, (Not an easy task but I can walk you through it if that's of interest to anyone.) I thoroughly enjoyed this game. It is... vast. Nothing Bethesda does is small. There's so many things to do, it can make your head spin, The main quest and the side quests sometimes blurred together for me but that's ok. I'm sure I missed a lot of stuff so I may play through it again at some point. The story is very in depth and seems plausible. I found myself believing this could happen right now, if nuclear warfare ever became a thing. The end game was really incredulous but also lackluster. I wish the order of events was a touch different. For instance I felt like a badass when I blew up the President and the base but   felt like a complete dope when I was running along side a big dumb robot killing everything for me. I would've loved those events to be switched. I get why it didn't happen that way, but I like feeling powerful by end game. I didn't realize it was over until it told me so and I felt hollow and unaccomplished.One other thing I really didn't like about this game was the voice Acting. I didn't appreciate the recycled voices for different people and would have appreciated original voices. Even if they couldn't afford more actors, a slightly different voice would've been better than literally everyone having each other's voices. All in all though, I loved this game. I cried when my dad died. I squeed when I found Dogmeat. I felt like a badass when I used VATS. There were so many moments that made me feel, that even though the end game was♥♥♥♥♥♥ it didn't matter. This game is worth playing and I can't wait for Fallout 4.

content:

												Due to the fact that I played Fallout 3 after New Vegas and Skyrim, I was really afraid of what I would experience in the game that's 7 years old and commonly hated in the Fallout fandom. As with all other games, I decided to play it COMPLETELY unmodded, in order to experience the very game Bethesda wanted us to play.I played New Vegas and simply loved it. Also, I played Skyrim and even today I consider it to be the best game I have ever played. Hyping myself for Fallout's 4th installment, I decided to buy Fallout 3 and ultimately decided whether it's so bad as many people say. Surprise, surprise - it's not! The beginning is very slow-paced, but it gives a nice touch to the whole story. But right after entering Megaton - boy, was I impressed. That was the very moment when I felt the "Bethesda spirit", because of which I love their games so much. Interesting backstory of the location, quite nice backstories of each character in the "city", a lot of interesting loot, nice dialogues and the big introduction to the essence of the game - BE GOOD OR BE BAD.The morality/consequence system in the game is based on extremities - there are just a few moments when you can stay neutral with your decision. Therefore, most time you decide whether you want to be good or bad. However, sometimes your seemingly good/bad choices can result in the opposite of your intention - that is why a player has to THINK while deciding - it pays off and it's really cool.Due to the common belief that F:NV is a better game than F3, I'd like to contribute a few words to the discussion. As a whole, I consider F:NV to be the better one, but my F3 playthrough was twice longer than any on my F:NV playthroughs. Draw some conclusions. Also, Washington in F3 seems to be much more affected by the atomic explosions than Las Vegas in F:NV. The whole world of F3 seems also to be more miserable and hopeless in contrary to the one of F:NV, which seemingly make it more suitable to the postapocalyptic vision, but I guess it's a matter of taste - personally, I still like more the atmosphere of New Vegas, but I completely understand why some people prefer the one from Fallout 3. The gameplay is rewarding and satisfying - every kill, succesful attempt of persuasion/lockpick/etc. results in earned exp, which just HAS to make you feel good - and it does. You can have your own home that you can upgrade with some Fallout lore technology, you can capture people to make them slaves, you can hunt slavers, you can help or kill almost any person that has his/her's own personality and habits. Oh, btw - habits. I love the habit system, as it makes the world feel ALIVE, and the immersion is the first thing that I'm looking for in RPG games. NPCs have their break-times, eat breakfast/dinner, sleep and have random conversations between each other. So, if you suffer lack of funds, why not steal from the cash register of some folk? You walk into the shop, but he observes your every move. Solution? Just break into the shop during the night time - he will be sleeping, so as long as you maintain to be silent, you're good to go. AWESOME.Now, some bad things. Unlike developers wanted me to, I completed all of the available DLCs BEFORE ending the main story. As for the DLCs - they are mediocre at their least. Some of them are even worse. Somehow, I regret my decision to play them instead of discovering the locations from the main map. Most of the DLCs are linear ("Point Lookout" is the only exception) and - let's face it - just boring. Playing them wasn't a very good idea also because of one more reason - with little more than half of the game's locations discovered, I hit the 30lvl cap and the game became a dull chore - the character progression just stopped - no more perks, no more skills. Therefore, I was forced to install a mod which allowed me to raise the level cap. After 62hrs of gameplay, I raised almost all of my skills to 100 and raised all of my S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats to 9/10. I know that there are some mods that actually fix this problem, but I wanted to play the game itself, not its modded counterpart. Now, the only thing left is to discover the rest of the locations (20-30, maybe) and to finish the Broken Steel DLC (which is available only after finishing the main questline). Now, I probably need a short break before I complete the game in 100%.Also, the optimisation! It's... bad. Skyrim runs much more fluently on my laptop, and it's a game that is 3 years younger. And much bigger. And prettier. At the very start, the game was unplayable with its constant freezes and crashes. This solution fixed it for me, both on my desktop PC (i5, GTX 970) and laptop (i7, GT650M SLI):"Open up the fallout.ini file in: My Documents\My Games\Fallout3 Find the line: bUseThreadedAI=0 change it to: bUseThreadedAI=1 Add another line after it and insert: iNumHWThreads=2 This will limit the game to 2 cores and prevent the engine bug from causing the game to freeze."Hope that you find it helpful!With all of its advantages and disadvantages, Fallout 3 is still a great action RPG.[EDIT]:I've just finished the "Broken Steel" DLC (same as the rest, linear and mediocre). The main good thing about it is that it's short. I visited couple more locations and lost interest in this title. Still, overall it's a great game that provides many hours of satisfactory and rewarding gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This game, unlike the ElderScrolls Series, is not always for the casual player, even on very easy some enemies and places can be a nighmare of difficulty  if you dont have the right gear, or enough stimpacks of course, but saying that, I very much prefer this game to skyrim, possibly even Oblivion or Morrowind in the ElderScrolls series, and im very much anticipating Fallout 4 in the next year or two, People's faces and voices are much better in the fallout games than in the ElderScroll games, and you cant forget about 3dog, very good music, humor, quests, interesting things for people who love Washington D.C. as well and want to explore the radioactive wreckage of the capital, and the surrounding wastelands of course, It was interesting seeing the RobCo HQ, more vaults, and the Capital Itself, Very well made DLC, from aliens, to virtual reality, to slavers in pittsburgh, I would recommend this as a starter for Fallout games, even though it is the 3rd one, it is not very connected to the others, as it is from Bethesda, who did not make the first 2 games, although, the first 2 games excel in story and gameplay as well, and I recommend them as well, in the end its your choice, but if you have 20 bucks to spare, spend them on something that can provide limitless hours of entertainment, hundreds of locations, a good few laughs, good music, a Legendary Father, a few tear jerking moments, Horrifying Moral choices, and of course GARY! So yes, you should play this game, and talk about it, sing the songs outloud if you want, just have fun. Note, do not play this game just because you think, look, skyrim with guns, its alot more than that, and Warfare is slightly weak in this game, this is more for those Nerdy, Lore loving people out there, not the ones that claim to be real gamers, the ones who spend hundreds of hours finding every little secret, seeing every site, doing every mission, loading and reloading games to fix mistakes and prevent deaths, those people, those people are the real gamers, and the people who will enjoy this game the most.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the amount of hours played here: I had never owned it on Steam previously, but I have honestly put 200+ hours into this in my lifetime. I played Fallout 3 when it came out on a whim, not being overly familiar with the rest of the Fallout franchise, and it was the best decision I ever made, to stick to it even though at first I was not so sure if I liked it or not. Then, as I advanced properly into the Capital Wasteland and the story unfolded itself, it became my second favourite video game of all time (alongside BioShock 1/2). Though the engine may be old in today's standards, it does not discount anything at all; the grimy Wasteland has become a sort of home to me, every single character I have encountered is likeable, even the baddies that go around killing♥♥♥♥♥♥ even the beloved cannibal-incestuous families of Andale that make you human-meat pies if you promise to stay quiet about their ways. This game shows you a portrayal of a world where the 50s never left it though technology went on, and accurately shows the progression of human survival after we succeeded at killing the world via nuclear warfare. There are so many heartwrenching moments, and just as many hilarious ones--all companions are likable, and every quest the Lone Wanderer undertakes is meaningful. Even the side quests serve good purposes, and I never tire of exploring the Wasteland though I may have scoured it from corner to corner by now. Like I've said, the Fallout world has become a very familiar place to me now, somewhere that is so replayable and full of vitality, ironically in a radiation-riddled landscape. I prefer it to Fallout: New Vegas only out of the story content, feeling the latter to be superior only by a hair. This was the first step of Bethesda's revival of the franchise, after all, and will remain forever in my heart as the best of the two. Please play this if you haven't, so that you can get a feel for the Fallout universe before Fallout 4 comes out. HYPE(my icon is actually of my Lone Wanderer, Eden, funnily enough)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Fallout 3. My gosh, this game is near to perfection. This game is my favorite RPG at the moment, I mean, every RPG fan needs to play this game. NEEDS TO. Especially GOTY Edition, it's only $20 such a good deal. Lets sum up the story.You and your Dad lived in a vault, your Dad (played by Liam Neeson) leaves the vault, to find a water purifier called the 'G.E.C.K.' You also leave the vault, in search of your father. Now, let me tell you the pros and the cons of this game +DLCPros+Unlike Oblivion, Fo3 is a very immersive game+Lots of interesting characters as you progress through the game. +Most of the DLC (Except Mothership Zeta) is actually pretty good, my personal favorite is The Pitt+Lots of weapons and guns, lasers, and plasma rifles are awesome, and the Fat Man+The Soundtrack in this game is superb, I love the oldies music in this game.+ Interesting antagonist (The Enclave)+ The Power Armor (Whether BOS or Enclave) is freaking sweet+ Most of the Companions are interesting,and fun to use+ Lots of places to explore+ THe Perk System is great, makes the game more fun+ V.A.T.S. just makes this game morew fun than ever+ You can put a lot of hours into this game, and not get bored (I know at the moment it says i put 52 hours, but i put much more on the ps3.)Cons- Comanions die if they lose all of their health, luckily for the dog comapnion there's a perk to have him have another dog, but you can't get that perk until much later in the game.- The ending without the Broken Steel DLC, Sucks, once you complete the story, without the dlc, it doesnt let you go back- The DLC Mothership Zeta was a HUGE disappointment for me, you're not missing out if you dont play it. (except for the new guns)- Poorly optimized for Windows 7 and up, and Bethesda refused to patch it, you can get an unofficial patch that will fix this problem.So... Despite some of the Minor flaws this game has, it is still a fantastic RPG that must be played by anyone that calls themselves an RPG fanFinal Verdit: 9.5/10 MUST BUY

												I played this game both on PC and PS3, and with a total of about 70 hours, i can tell MHO about this masterpiece of the old-gen games.In this game, the first of the saga developed by Bethesda (The original Fallout 3 was named Van Bouren by the original SH) you can basically do anything, from choosing the fate of a dweller, to changing the entire world, like destroying a city, or changing the president in a city.But the game isn't "just" that, it's basically a GDR mixed with FPS things.The Lone Wanderer can have lots of weapons, like blades, baseball bats, laser and plasma rifles, sniper rifles and more, and their unique variant.As weapons, lots of clothes/armors.So, Fallout 3 rests an unbeaten masterpiece of the old-gen games, with a addictive story, lots of side quests and choices to do, and a background lore that criticize the american warlike government aspiring at the oil supremacy. (Yeah, in 2077 oil wells They were completely dried up, so it started another war, against China)Anyone should play this game, really.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game is good, if you're into putting hours on lengthy playthroughs in an RPG with lots of depth, then get this game. However, if you're going to get this game expecting it to be like the infamous Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (but with guns), then you should reconsider because this game is FAR from that kind of title. Firstly, this game is a walking simulator; unlike Skyrim which has all kinds of things to do while you're in a quest, you're going to be lost in lengthy walks from point A to point B while continously looking in the map while whispering to yourself: "Am I there yet?", but not to worry, once you get to your destination, you'll be able to use fast travel -- "but isn't that like Skyrim?" yes, but in Skyrim, you have LOTS of things to do while you're travelling from Point A to Point B, you might run into some bandit camps, some bears or some caves, but in here, you'll just look at a few landmarks and fight some enemies and that's it. Secondly, what I like about this game is the development of your character is very rewarding and the keen sense of survival is a need in this game.
