number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Due to the fact that I played Fallout 3 after New Vegas and Skyrim, I was really afraid of what I would experience in the game that's 7 years old and commonly hated in the Fallout fandom. As with all other games, I decided to play it COMPLETELY unmodded, in order to experience the very game Bethesda wanted us to play.I played New Vegas and simply loved it. Also, I played Skyrim and even today I consider it to be the best game I have ever played. Hyping myself for Fallout's 4th installment, I decided to buy Fallout 3 and ultimately decided whether it's so bad as many people say. Surprise, surprise - it's not! The beginning is very slow-paced, but it gives a nice touch to the whole story. But right after entering Megaton - boy, was I impressed. That was the very moment when I felt the "Bethesda spirit", because of which I love their games so much. Interesting backstory of the location, quite nice backstories of each character in the "city", a lot of interesting loot, nice dialogues and the big introduction to the essence of the game - BE GOOD OR BE BAD.The morality/consequence system in the game is based on extremities - there are just a few moments when you can stay neutral with your decision. Therefore, most time you decide whether you want to be good or bad. However, sometimes your seemingly good/bad choices can result in the opposite of your intention - that is why a player has to THINK while deciding - it pays off and it's really cool.Due to the common belief that F:NV is a better game than F3, I'd like to contribute a few words to the discussion. As a whole, I consider F:NV to be the better one, but my F3 playthrough was twice longer than any on my F:NV playthroughs. Draw some conclusions. Also, Washington in F3 seems to be much more affected by the atomic explosions than Las Vegas in F:NV. The whole world of F3 seems also to be more miserable and hopeless in contrary to the one of F:NV, which seemingly make it more suitable to the postapocalyptic vision, but I guess it's a matter of taste - personally, I still like more the atmosphere of New Vegas, but I completely understand why some people prefer the one from Fallout 3. The gameplay is rewarding and satisfying - every kill, succesful attempt of persuasion/lockpick/etc. results in earned exp, which just HAS to make you feel good - and it does. You can have your own home that you can upgrade with some Fallout lore technology, you can capture people to make them slaves, you can hunt slavers, you can help or kill almost any person that has his/her's own personality and habits. Oh, btw - habits. I love the habit system, as it makes the world feel ALIVE, and the immersion is the first thing that I'm looking for in RPG games. NPCs have their break-times, eat breakfast/dinner, sleep and have random conversations between each other. So, if you suffer lack of funds, why not steal from the cash register of some folk? You walk into the shop, but he observes your every move. Solution? Just break into the shop during the night time - he will be sleeping, so as long as you maintain to be silent, you're good to go. AWESOME.Now, some bad things. Unlike developers wanted me to, I completed all of the available DLCs BEFORE ending the main story. As for the DLCs - they are mediocre at their least. Some of them are even worse. Somehow, I regret my decision to play them instead of discovering the locations from the main map. Most of the DLCs are linear ("Point Lookout" is the only exception) and - let's face it - just boring. Playing them wasn't a very good idea also because of one more reason - with little more than half of the game's locations discovered, I hit the 30lvl cap and the game became a dull chore - the character progression just stopped - no more perks, no more skills. Therefore, I was forced to install a mod which allowed me to raise the level cap. After 62hrs of gameplay, I raised almost all of my skills to 100 and raised all of my S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats to 9/10. I know that there are some mods that actually fix this problem, but I wanted to play the game itself, not its modded counterpart. Now, the only thing left is to discover the rest of the locations (20-30, maybe) and to finish the Broken Steel DLC (which is available only after finishing the main questline). Now, I probably need a short break before I complete the game in 100%.Also, the optimisation! It's... bad. Skyrim runs much more fluently on my laptop, and it's a game that is 3 years younger. And much bigger. And prettier. At the very start, the game was unplayable with its constant freezes and crashes. This solution fixed it for me, both on my desktop PC (i5, GTX 970) and laptop (i7, GT650M SLI):"Open up the fallout.ini file in: My Documents\My Games\Fallout3 Find the line: bUseThreadedAI=0 change it to: bUseThreadedAI=1 Add another line after it and insert: iNumHWThreads=2 This will limit the game to 2 cores and prevent the engine bug from causing the game to freeze."Hope that you find it helpful!With all of its advantages and disadvantages, Fallout 3 is still a great action RPG.[EDIT]:I've just finished the "Broken Steel" DLC (same as the rest, linear and mediocre). The main good thing about it is that it's short. I visited couple more locations and lost interest in this title. Still, overall it's a great game that provides many hours of satisfactory and rewarding gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												WHERE HAS THIS GAME BEEN ALL MY LIFE?!A good friend got this for me, and this...holy crap...this has to be one of my most favourite video game experiences. The game has it's buggy problems, but nothing that hinders game play experience when fixed.Pros:+ Prepare to invest some good time into this game. It's addictive and the open world is filled with quests and decisions to be made. You will have long game sessions in this game.+ The game really lets you embrace being a good/bad person, along with diverse dailogue choices. Karma system is one of the best I've seen and what you do effects the world around you. You can literally kill anyone you want in this game ._.+ The game has a targeting/aiming system called VATS which is really cool and useful against enemies, for a game where aiming normally could use some improvements.+ There's a lot of interesting characters in the game that really makes the game wasteland setting more lively. + This game immerses you. It really feels like you're someone in a hazardous wasteland trying to survive and helping or killing folks. Not just the game itself, but the story also immerses you into the role of your character really well.+ MODS! There's a mod for everything! X_X+ My Dad in Fallout 3 was a better father to me than my IRL Dad lol XD Why isn't he real (╥_╥) "Be careful, sweetie", "That's my girl". Kindest words any father figure has ever told me.Cons:- Getting this game to work on the first try. Prepare yourself for Do-It-Yourself fixes. There's a guide with fixes fortunately that makes the process more smoother.-  No sprinting option is silly, considering the character's speed would test the patience of the most impatient of us. (Luckily there's a mod for this too if you're curious).- Stealth in this game sucks...or it tries, but comes up short. You can't get too close to an enemy (even from behind) or they notice you immediately. Sniping from afar is almost useless because there is no steady aim. Other than skill, sniping requires luck and tolerance.- Third-person view in this game is kinda...awkward. Character movement looks and feels stiff. Camera isn't great in third person either. You can't even see your character's face without it feeling like a struggle to turn the camera. My suggestion: Playing in first person felt much better to me, and that's coming from someone who prefers third person view any day. Your aim is also much more accurate than in third person view.Oh,  and watch out for jump scares in first person view lol.My Rating: 9 out of 10. Just by solving the few cons I mentioned, I would definitely give this game a strong 10/10.

Posted: January 10
												No doubt one of the best games of apocalyptic theme ever made. After an entire life living in the Vault with your dad with a peaceful life under the circumstances of the results that the nuclear war left on the country, some day everything changed. The Vault is opened, your dad escaped, terrible things happen and the blame fall over you two. With no other choice, you have to leave the Vault and look for your missing dad. What I can say is that the game is funny, tense and stressing when it has to be. Killing with the craziest weapons ever made and even dress yourself like a rebel. Cutting, beating, ripping, shooting, blowing, smashing, all the kind of things can be done with basically everyone. You can be a good or a bad guy/girl, depending of your Karma. So take your Fat Man, make bandits, giant insects and mutants fly in pieces, whatever cost to find your dad!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really love this game and recommend it any day. Period.If you're turned away by the age (8 years old, as of this review...my god I feel old), realise that there are always mods to do anything you felt was missing, or that you thought the game needed to compete with newer roleplaying games. Although the modding community is absolutely incredible, I recommend completing one playthrough without mods. Just to get the intended experience at least once. Now, as for what the game offers...I'll do this in a simple way that I've seen pretty often on here, so you should know it.PROS:+ Atmosphere is perfect. There's something about the look and feel of the wasteland that just makes you feel really immersed+ Soundtrack is very good, using classic songs from the 50s-60s era, which is a nice bit of irony. Cheery music, destroyed world+ Character building and connections are done extremely well in this game, which a few exceptions. I personally cared about many of the characters throughout my travels of the Capital Wasteland+ SO MUCH TO EXPLORE! There are just over a hundred (if my memory is correct) marked locations in the base game world, but so many more hidden in all of the nooks and crannies of DC. And often you'll find yourself learning more about what happened to people in those locations, which really helps establish the open world+ The player has many choices to make, some make subtle changes, while others completely change everything. Choose wisely+ Lots of variety and freedom. The quest design is done so that the player can take so many different paths to achieve something, which definitely adds to the roleplaying experience+ Incredible amounts of replayability. Tying in with the last two points, this game has so many things to do, it is impossible to see everything in just one playthrough+ Variety in weapons and armour. Want to deck yourself out in full power armour? Sure. Just want to chill out in pyjamas? You've got it. What about running around in a duster coat and a clown mask? I don't see why not. And as for weapons...there are dozens of weapons at your disposal, most of which have unique variants for you to collect+ So much to do! There are hundreds of quests to be completed, dozens of unique weapons and armour to be found, hundreds of locations to explore and learn about, and so much more. This game is filled to the brim with content+ If you want more, the Fallout 3 Nexus has thousands of mods for you to tweak your game with, allowing for even more replayabilityCONS:- Gunplay is horrible. You do get used to it after a while, but it still has a slight cringe factor- Some of the voice acting is a little weak. Given the scale of the game, I do give it a bit of a pass on it- Pretty annoying to actually start up. It took me a few hours of tinkering with files and downloading patches before it worked, but now it runs fantastic and I don't believe that it has crashed on me yet

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Fallout 3. My gosh, this game is near to perfection. This game is my favorite RPG at the moment, I mean, every RPG fan needs to play this game. NEEDS TO. Especially GOTY Edition, it's only $20 such a good deal. Lets sum up the story.You and your Dad lived in a vault, your Dad (played by Liam Neeson) leaves the vault, to find a water purifier called the 'G.E.C.K.' You also leave the vault, in search of your father. Now, let me tell you the pros and the cons of this game +DLCPros+Unlike Oblivion, Fo3 is a very immersive game+Lots of interesting characters as you progress through the game. +Most of the DLC (Except Mothership Zeta) is actually pretty good, my personal favorite is The Pitt+Lots of weapons and guns, lasers, and plasma rifles are awesome, and the Fat Man+The Soundtrack in this game is superb, I love the oldies music in this game.+ Interesting antagonist (The Enclave)+ The Power Armor (Whether BOS or Enclave) is freaking sweet+ Most of the Companions are interesting,and fun to use+ Lots of places to explore+ THe Perk System is great, makes the game more fun+ V.A.T.S. just makes this game morew fun than ever+ You can put a lot of hours into this game, and not get bored (I know at the moment it says i put 52 hours, but i put much more on the ps3.)Cons- Comanions die if they lose all of their health, luckily for the dog comapnion there's a perk to have him have another dog, but you can't get that perk until much later in the game.- The ending without the Broken Steel DLC, Sucks, once you complete the story, without the dlc, it doesnt let you go back- The DLC Mothership Zeta was a HUGE disappointment for me, you're not missing out if you dont play it. (except for the new guns)- Poorly optimized for Windows 7 and up, and Bethesda refused to patch it, you can get an unofficial patch that will fix this problem.So... Despite some of the Minor flaws this game has, it is still a fantastic RPG that must be played by anyone that calls themselves an RPG fanFinal Verdit: 9.5/10 MUST BUY

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This game, unlike the ElderScrolls Series, is not always for the casual player, even on very easy some enemies and places can be a nighmare of difficulty  if you dont have the right gear, or enough stimpacks of course, but saying that, I very much prefer this game to skyrim, possibly even Oblivion or Morrowind in the ElderScrolls series, and im very much anticipating Fallout 4 in the next year or two, People's faces and voices are much better in the fallout games than in the ElderScroll games, and you cant forget about 3dog, very good music, humor, quests, interesting things for people who love Washington D.C. as well and want to explore the radioactive wreckage of the capital, and the surrounding wastelands of course, It was interesting seeing the RobCo HQ, more vaults, and the Capital Itself, Very well made DLC, from aliens, to virtual reality, to slavers in pittsburgh, I would recommend this as a starter for Fallout games, even though it is the 3rd one, it is not very connected to the others, as it is from Bethesda, who did not make the first 2 games, although, the first 2 games excel in story and gameplay as well, and I recommend them as well, in the end its your choice, but if you have 20 bucks to spare, spend them on something that can provide limitless hours of entertainment, hundreds of locations, a good few laughs, good music, a Legendary Father, a few tear jerking moments, Horrifying Moral choices, and of course GARY! So yes, you should play this game, and talk about it, sing the songs outloud if you want, just have fun. Note, do not play this game just because you think, look, skyrim with guns, its alot more than that, and Warfare is slightly weak in this game, this is more for those Nerdy, Lore loving people out there, not the ones that claim to be real gamers, the ones who spend hundreds of hours finding every little secret, seeing every site, doing every mission, loading and reloading games to fix mistakes and prevent deaths, those people, those people are the real gamers, and the people who will enjoy this game the most.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2013
Living in a Vault your whole life doesn't ever prepare you for the world outside, despite what all of Vault-Tec's instructional material tells their residents. So when the Lone Wanderer was thrust through that four foot-thick steel door with a mission, it's hard to say they were ready for what came next...War, War Never ChangesIt's been two-hundred years since October twenty-third, 2077, the day of the two-hour Great War, when atomic fire consumed man and animal alike - ashes to ashes, alpha to omega. One-hundred and sixteen years since the Vault Dweller left V13 to find a water chip. Thirty-five years since the Chosen One departed from tribal Arroyo to find a cure for their famine. 2277 is when your journey begins, just beyond the door of Vault 101...You are the Lone Wanderer, child of James and Catherine, two residents of the Capital Wasteland in the late twenty-third century. You've lived your whole life in Vault 101 with your father. Educated by a long-dead company of a long-dead nation. You don't even know what it looks like outside. But when your father leaves unexpectedly and the whole Vault turns on you, the Wasteland becomes your new - and only - home.So now you're gonna find out what has been kept from you all your life.- -Hey! Be sure you have Games For Windows Live installed on your PC, otherwise Fallout 3 will not run. Even though GFWL isn't supported anymore, it includes a file that Fallout 3 searches for on start-up. Without this, it will crash before loading fully.Fallout 3, the title of the Fallout franchise that brought it back from the swampy depths of point-and-click and issued the title a new life as a first-person RPG. It takes the original grit and grime and hilarity of Fallout 1 and 2 and tries to implement it into a totally new world, to varying degrees of success, but stands as a proud GOTY from Bethesda Game Studios for no bad reason.Being a Bethesda title, Fallout 3 plays much like any other Bethesda game. Oblivion, Skyrim, and of course New Vegas. Floaty controls with problematic UI layered with comfortable RPG elements and a semi-unique targeting system that makes up for the horrendous gunplay.Again, though, Bethesda excells at worldspace design and creates an attractive landscape to look at, but oddly fails to capture a fun landscape to play in. DC is annoyingly traversed by underground subway tunnels, and the rest of the wasteland is empty and bland. Some landmarks are enjoyable, like the Washington and Lincoln Memorials, while the Capitol Building is unfortunately a simple combat center with no real rewards.Combat is bad. Not as floaty and slow as Oblivion, but nowhere near as responsive and dangerous as New Vegas at lower levels. Guns seem to lag after the fire command is given, melee is low-damage and unresponsive, and unarmed is neglected in all fronts. Enemies become bullet sponges as the player levels up, which causes the already slow combat to drag on. New Vegas' redeeming inclusion of a wide variety of weapons is sorely missed here, too.Fallout 3's story is decent but tired. Unlike other Fallout games, there's little-to-no choice of faction and only one major choice in the outcome of the story. There are some side-quests, of course. They usually are unique and interesting - "You Gotta Shoot 'Em In The Head" being one that comes to mind - but there are not very many. While this all might comparably make Fallout 3 seem the worst of the Fallout line-up, it is still a fun experience to ride through.There are two major factions in the game, the Brotherhood of Steel and the Enclave. Both are branches of west coast goliaths featured in Fallout 1 and 2. The player takes the side of the BoS for almost all of the story, even while given options to betray them. The Enclave hold their same goal of eradication of all 'mutants,' or everybody that isn't one of them. The BoS takes a much more humane approach to the local wastelanders than their western counterparts. Both factions are trying to take control of Project Purity, a water decontamination mission housed in the Jefferson Memorial spearheaded by two local researchers, James and Catherine.The plot revolves around the player's character, the Lone Wanderer, a Vault dweller out of 101 in search of James, their father, who has left without giving reason or getting permission. Aside from the Vault now not wanting a criminal's child, the Lone Wanderer must leave 101 to learn why their father has left. This story collides with the Brotherhood's mission in the wasteland just before the Enclave reveal themselves, and so begins the conflict.Fallout 3 hosts a variety of unique characters, both inconsequential and companion type. The regular NPCs are mostly unfortunate in both writing and voice acting, being either unbelievable or ear-grating, a particular Moira coming to mind. Companions are generally more tolerable, with Dogmeat - a long-standing icon of Fallout - returning. Most companions rely on the game's Karma system, some refusing to serve or leaving the player's service should this level change too much.Karma is the game's way of keeping the player's actions in track, rating them as 'evil,' 'neutral,' or 'good.' This effects companions, some quests, perks, and other elements of gameplay. It is affected by stealing, murdering, donating, and finishing quests.Being a Bethesda RPG, the game gives the player the chance to create their own character. Looks is what is obviously thought of first, but being part of the Fallout series, SPECIAL stats are all customizable and have the largest impacts on the choosable perks, which take the roll of traits and perks from older games, and skills.Perks are bonuses for the player character chosen on level-up while skills are a 0-100 rating of the player character's ability with everything from guns to medicine to bartering. These work in tandem to let the player develop a unique experience for themselves through their characters.I personally didn't like Fallout 3 as much as the original Fallout or Fallout New Vegas, and updating this now I feel I enjoyed Fallout 4 even more. But it's a solid game without the Fallout branding, just somewhat derivative and poor on the shooting aspect. My hours played in comparison to NV and 4 should reflect this.Get it on sale!- -Because this is the full-package GOTY edition, I'll also review the DLC here.Broken SteelBroken Steel allows the player to continue playing after the main story ends, seeing the results of their choice at Project Purity and learning that the Brotherhood of Steel may not be totally made up of just causes. It adds a few more hours of quests and minimally connects to New Vegas and 4.Good if you think you'll be playing the game for a while, or if you have the other DLC and finish fast.Mothership ZetaMothership Zeta is a semi-decent throwback to campy sci-fi films of the 1950s, taking the player aboard an alien spacecraft with a ragtag crew of other abductees in combat with their alien captors.Get Old World Blues for New Vegas over this. It has no aliens, but is better at the same theme.The PittAn adventure to the remains of Pittsburgh, now operated by Ashur and a civilization of slaves, with a plan to rebuild America's infrastructure, but plagued by a mysterious sickness that mutates anybody who stays in the city.A very different feeling from the rest of Fallout 3. Much grittier, but a slow grind otherwise.Point LookoutMetaphysical journey to Point Lookout State Park, Maryland, heavily laden with a mysterious cultist overtone while focusing on a single conflict straight out of James Bond. A swampy, chilling environ lends nicely to the overall feeling of a dreamstate, and history plays into all of the quests bigtime.Probably my favorite DLC for F3, though certainly slower than the others.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												Fallout 3 is a wonderful open world game that only realizes it's full potential when heavily modded.  To get to to run properly on Windows 7 x64 without crashing at startup or upon loading a new game I had to:1. Add the following line to the Havok section of the fallout.ini:iNumThreads=22. Install and run FOSE (http://fose.silverlock.org/download/fose_v1_2_beta2.7z) instead of the Fallout exe, and install the New Vegas Anti Crash plugins( it works for Fallout 3 as well as New Vegas, and the Dl link is http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/53635/?)The GFWL Disabler (http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?) might also help, and enabling the 4GB flag on the game's executable should reduce crashes if using 2K HD retextures like NeilMB. ENBoost could help as well.For modding the game, a good base to start is: http://wiki.step-project.com/User:Kelmych/Fallout3Improved textures, more weapons, more enemies, better lighting, new houses and companions, more interiors, increased difficulty...It will take at least a day to download and set all of those mods up though.

												the first fallout game i played, Fallout 3 incredible main story, awsome side quests, and massive nonlieniar atmosphiric open world make this one of the best games i've ever played. After playing both new vegas and fallout 4, i found that in terms of story, atmosphere ,and side quests, fallout 3 is the clear winner dispite in my opinion not being as overall good as fallout 4 (but still 500x better then new vegas, seriously i have no idea what obsidian was thinking when they implemented ceasars legion or thought that the game had an acceptable main quest.) The only true flaw i find in fallout 3 is the actual writing and dialoge that goes with its incredible story, at times its has that nice simple feel to it that might remind you of dialoge beween saturday morning action cartoons (childish, but at the same time awsome,) other times it just is downright childish and rather lazy (seriously, one of the many ways to kill the main villan is to convince him that he is insane, and he just kills himself, yeah its very hard to pass the speech check, but its still rather silly way to destroy a rather awsome villian.) Overall fallout 3 is a gameing masterpeice, combining rpg elements from the first 2 games with (at the time of its relese) modern fps mechanics to bring a new standard to the fallout franchise, a standard that set the foundation for fallout new vegas and Fallout 4.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												It has been a while since I have actually sat down for a playthrough, however the times that I have were unforgettable moments. This game admittedly has a fairly short campaign once the player is aware of the certain courses that need to be taken; this does not limit replayablility, however. Although the campaign itself is fairly short and straightforward, the gameplay is a whole separate story. With Hub locations across the map, several factions to join, as well as a myriad of perks to choose from as the game progresses, different quest outcomes based on your responses, and a wealth of quests included in the main campaign, side campaigns, quests in add-on packs, as well as the occasional single side mission.  There was never really a dull moment for me in this game. Occasionally the game will minimize with no hope of re-opening, but I am also running on Windows 10, which is a fairly easy scapegoat at this point.  I only have 73 logged hours, but I have so many uncounted hours within my Xbox playthroughs (I happened to acquire that version for free) and I have fallen in love with the game and franchise.  This game will not disappoint.  I give this game 10 Bobbleheads out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												A fantastic RPG from the best makers of RPGs.  Fallout 3 is a masterpiece, and anyone who is a fan of RPGs will love it.*Note: Don't be fooled by my steam hours, I have WAY more console hours.*Gameplay - 8.5/10:The combat is really good, but don't expect it to be like a regular FPS.  It's a lot more tedious and rewarding.  The V.A.T.S. system is great and makes the combat unique from other RPGs and shooters.  It would have gotten a 10/10, but the stupid zoom in feature can get quite irritating.  Since you can't aim down your sight, you just end up looking down your hipfire a little more.  And sometimes it barely even zooms!  The interactions are good, like persuasion and bartering.  Within the gameplay, you will also have to make certain choices.  These choices vary from good to evil, and let me tell you, they can get pretty sickening.Atmosphere - 8/10:Bethesda truly creates a weird, yet richly crafted world.  The whole 50s vibe clashing with the nuclear apocalypse is awesome!  Post-apoctalyptic Washington D.C. looks good, but it is a pain in the neck to get around in.  And the wasteland, while being a fun place to wander, can sometimes feel empty a lot in areas.Class/Leveling System - 9/10:If you are familiar with any pre-Skyrim Bethesda games, you know how the class/leveling system works.  It's very well structered and it truly gives you the freedom to make your own character in the wasteland.  Oh, and the karma is a great system also!Story - 8.5/10:For a Bethesda game, the story is a 10/10, but compared to some other RPGs, it gets an 8.5/10.  This is the best Bethesda game story-wise, and it is quite interesting.  You end up searching down your father after he left the vault that you grew up in, and the story really has meaning.  With the sidequests, I was really impressed.  Each of them had a unique theme and some had twists and turns.  I really felt like I was making a difference with some of these side quests.  The only side quests that sucked was Moira Brown's.  Nobody wants to help make your stupid book, Moira!Verdict:I give Fallout 3 a strong 9/10.  It truly is a great game and is a must own for anyone who enjoys RPGs or post-apocalyptic themes.  Bethesda created a gem of a game with this, and I can't wait for Fallout 4!Also, I have Windows 7.  No problems on my end.  And even if there are for you, there are many ways to fix them.  Just google it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												While FO3 might not retain all the story-like details of its predecesors, it definitely has a feeling that integrates perfectly with the Fallout universe. The desolate ruins of what once was a power center give you a good image of how ravaging the human thirst for blood and destruction can be.Don't be fooled by the old graphics or the bugs the game has - you will love the game. And the modding community took into its caring hands to make of a good game a brilliant one.What can a new player expect? Hours and hours of addicting exploration, looting, shooting, killing, blowing up and generally, the wet dream of the scavanger. You will run around, get lost, shoot raiders, talk to strangers, loot, repair, search chests and desks, gaze at the sky, fear the darkness and forge alliance with the most unlike of the people. You can be the shining light of the Wasteland, a beacon of sanctity and a symbol of all that's hollier out there. OR, you can be the worst of the scum, the embodiment of evil, slaving and killing left and right. You can just go alone, re-enact the Lone Wanderer's path. Or, bring friends and shoot stuff together like a happy fellowship!There are, of course, downsides. There isn't much to the main story - it's has a definite mass effect feeling to it. But who comes to Wasteland to play the main quest? You came for the loot and the fights, for all the stories they can make.There are bugs, of which the worst is the CTD. Something unavoidable... but you can get over it and, with a bit of care, achieve a almost stable game that will let you play for hours.All in all, get this game. It's a classic by now, and the low price screams "get me, get me!"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Coming back to this game after putting 800 hours into fallout 4, i gotta say, this is a much superior game. Yeah, maybe the graphics and the gunplay isn't as good but as following, these are the things i felt excelled in fallout 3. The roleplaying/character development, skill system, the dialogue (in which skill checks play a part in which makes the skill system and character development feel much more...'rich'), the repair system which fits well into the post apocalyptic feel and is one of the things i greatly missed in fallout 4. Being able to actaully visibly see your holstered weapon (another thing i grealy missed). The enemies, i loved the super mutants and the feral ghoul, while in fallout 4, the super mutants felt...goofy and the feral ghouls felt cartoonish. The guns...(looking at you combat rifle, combat shotgun, and assault rifle from fallout 4). The vaults, the characters, the towns, the scary subway tunnels, the atomsphere, and generally, the world.I could go on and on but then i would just be nitpicking at fallout 4. Now i may be biased because of nostalgia but here it is....my evil....evil nostalgic filled opinion.For the people who are thinking about buying this game but have a windows 7 or 10 computer and are worried this game won't work. You just have to disable the built in "games for windows live" (wish bethesda removed this in the first place) by downloading "fallout 3 script extender" (just google it). fallout 3 also has issues with running on processors with 3 or more cores which you can fix by downloading "UPDATED Unofficial Fallout 3 Patch" (again just google it, it fixes over a 1000 bugs in the game so doesn't hurt to get it either way). Now before installing these two, make sure you start up fallout 3 at least once to the start up menu where it will auto assign your settings (low, medium, high, ultra etc.). Make sure you set the resolution setting to your native resolution (it doesn't set it automatically for some reason).Another warning if you're trying to play this game off of a integrated graphics card it will cause some issues. Crashes etc, in which you can probably find a fix on the internet.Hope this helps =)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												     If you never played a Fallout game before, try the original Fallout before picking this up.  Whether you enjoyed the first or not, and whether you tried the second as well, then see how long you can last playing this mess of a game.     I'll admit, when I first picked it up, I enjoyed it immeadiately, and binged it for hours.  It is quite a bit of fun, if not stupid fun.  As you play on, you begin to realize how loosely the story and world of the game is held together.  The plot is nonsensical, the characters are cliche as hell, there are strictly two sides (black and white of course) to the story, the weapons are uninspired and bland, and they, to say it in a juvenile fashion, feel like sticks with♥♥♥♥♥♥on the ends of them.  Not to mention the game's enviornment is spotty and dull.  That green tint can get ♥♥♥♥ing old quick, and oftentimes, you will have no idea where you are until you take a gander at the map.  It's like Bethesdashit just made a basic desert world on a piece of paper, tacked it to the wall, and threw a ♥♥♥♥-ton of darts at it to denote where they would put places, events, towns, and so-on.  No rhyme or reason as to where anything is.        This game also suffers from the same problem that a lot of Bethesdacrap games have, such as very poorly made animations, weapons that feel like cardboard sticks or airsoft guns, ugly as sin character models, a strong lack of voice actors to compensate for the vast amount of "unique" characters in the game, no vareity in clothing, and broke leveling mechanics.  Di I say the story makes no sense when you look at the big picture?  It's as if a pre-teen fanfic writer smoked some pot and wanted to make a Fallout story.       Despite these shortcomings, I rate the game a 4/10 for having a small amount of replayability, a vision that shines through the cracks of caked-on♥♥♥♥♥♥ and a very nostalgic and memorable soundtrack (not the terrible and generic OST created for the game, I'm talking about anything that plays on Galaxy News Radio, and not Three-dog's annoying vocal-chord vibrations he calls a voice).       Once you trudge through the wasteland, play every DLC (if you didn't max out your character's level by the end of the game) minus Mothership Zeta for something different, and then high-tail your♥♥♥♥♥to the Mojave in Fallout New Vegas, which in my opnion, is the true Fallout 3.  Do NOT skip this game if you intend to jump into New Vegas!  If you play this first, you will enjoy it a tad, and it will allow you to enjoy New Vegas a lot more due to the problems it fixes and the soul it has to offer.  If you play New Vegas first, you will not enjoy Fallout 3 at all, making both games seem kind of dull and leaving a bad taste in your mouth.  Just pray that Bethesdick collaborates with the guys behind New Vegas on the next Fallout.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I'm just getting my review out there now—I'm also one of those typical players who hasn't even made any progress since I [left the Vault and became a wanderererere going all over the place]I also decided I would review this game, as I've selected it for the 2016 Steam Awards; in the 'Game within a Game' category. Though, looking past what you might be thinking—the text-based game inside of Hubris Comics—this is obviously a game about harsh survival; in an even harsher, post-apocalyptic world with an amazing backstory to it [I can assume, as I've forementioned that I haven't made any progress with the game's story]It's a personal story for me, the idea of a 'Lone Wanderer'—a hero among the world that's left. It's amazing, and just so facinating to me. And the Karma aspect of the game really enhances the experience for us gamers, and there are way too many games out there nowadays that restrict you into playing a set character profile and stuff [looking at you, Fallout 4]. Sure, there aren't that many options in this game where you can customize your character, but, with the kind of game this is, you don't need to be a loud-mouth, drunk-off-your♥♥♥♥♥kind of guy/girl, or whatever. You can either be a hero or a villain; silent, at that.Anyway, the 'Game within a Game' comes from nowing how to survive out there. Yes, I know it's a game, and you can just reoad your last save if you screw up, but I'm one of te few who NEVER do that, because, as with real life, you can't just turn back time and forget about a bullet lodged in your shoulder, or a sledgehammer right to your skull. I love challenging myself like this: it makes the experience all the more real and authentic. In a war-torn land, you must do absolutely everything you can just to make it past a group of bandits. There are also too many recent games that rob the player of this particular experience—the true survival apect of a game. You might look at Fallout 3 and instantly compare it to something totally outlandish like Call of Duty 'Zombies' being the definition of hardcore, or Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode in Borderlands 2 [which actually is VERY challenging and rewarding], but for a game that has rightly earned a 'Game of the Year' tag, you need to try Fallout 3. It's one of the most authentic games from the last generation. ^w^

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Fallout 3 is definitely a good game, but whether or not you think it's one of the all-time greats will probably depend on whether you play it or New Vegas first. If you played New Vegas first, Fallout 3 will initially be a little bit of a letdown. New Vegas is definitely the better designed game overall. Better game mechanics, more options, more nuanced, and better overall design. Fallout 3 can sometimes feel like a generic FPS, with all of the "closed space, tons of enemies, just keep attacking dozens of times and repeatedly using stimpaks" design that you encounter in about a third of the map. That flaw doesn't really exist very much in New Vegas, so it can initially be offputting when you repeatedly encounter it in Fallout 3.However, if you played Fallout 3 first, you'll probably think it's one of the greatest games ever made. It was the first Fallout game that really showed that "wow" factor and hinted at just how great the franchise could be. Plus, you'll be really impressed by the one thing that Fallout 3 does better than New Vegas: emotion. In New Vegas, you are basically a mythic character, with little back story. You don't have that much in common with the NPC's, who are basically mere mortals while you are pre-destined to be a god. I mean, the game starts off with you shrugging off a point-blank shot to the head. The courier might as well come from a different planet than all of the NPC's. In Fallout 3, however, you really get emotionally pulled into the game. You're just an ordinary person who takes it upon themself to do great things. Your whole backstory is very fleshed out, and pretty heartrending. Karma plays a much bigger role in this game than in New Vegas, and makes the playing experience that much more immersive. Family plays a huge role, as do genuinely good NPC's such as Three Dog. The emotional depth of Fallout 3 is some of the best you will ever encounter in a game. If you played New Vegas first, you won't even realize that emotional depth was missing. If you played Fallout 3 first, you will be disappointed by New Vegas' lack of emotional depth, despite the fact that New Vegas is superior in pretty much every other way.In the end, you'll learn to appreciate each game for what it does best. You'll probably wind up preferring whichever one you played first, but you'll still really enjoy both of them. If you already have New Vegas and not Fallout 3, I definitely reccomend purchasing this, just be aware that you'll have to adjust your expectations a bit and look for different positives in this game than you found in New Vegas.PS.- Be sure to adjust some of the game files after you install the game. Once you do, the game seldomly ever crashes. Until you do that, it crashes every few minutes. See this thread for details, and also look up a fix regarding Games for Windows Live, which drastically affects the performance of Fallout 3: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2814142

												Running it on Windows 10 on ultra graphics very smooth solid 60fps I can achieve higher frames but I choice to use vsync because of screen tearing. And HDR looks sweet. step 1 modify FALLOUT.ini(documents->mygames->fallout3) file if you have more then a dual coreunder general change the following lines of codechange bUseThreadedAI=0 to bUseThreadedAI=1add line of code under generaliNumHWThreads=2step 2 download/install games for live on windows websitestep 3 download/install fallout live disabler from nexus modstep 4 change both launcher and exe compatibility mode to windows xp sp3 and run as adminstratorstep 5 Make sure Drivers are updated thanks to nvidia community that was easy I have a 980GTXm 4gb gpustep 6  play the best game ever made.On a lighter noteNuka Cola Recipe IRL1/3 coca cola1/3 mountain dew1/3 creme sodaenjoy the refreshing drink! because in total I played this on xbox 360 120 Hours and now I will be doing it again this time on my brand new MSI GT72 Maxed out Gaming Laptop until that is they work the bugs out in Fallout 4. I played and beat every bethesda game every sidequest every achievement I might as well work there.I plan in the future 3d printing my own pipboy 3000 its easy the 3d files are online and if you don't have a 3d printer just use 3d hubs it will set you back about 150 bucks.And to make your own nuka cola bottles are easy just print lables onto sticker paper, cut out and take a coca cola bottle(scrap labeling is optional) the mexican cola works good to and fill it full of mountain dew voltage goto radioshack get a resistor(use a led resistor calc online for what ever led you buy) Mine was red blue brown gold, battery holder for a watch battery cr2032, mini switch and uv led (solder it all together) to make your own nuka cola quantum. I can't sell any of this because you know copyrights. lol If you need a good cap to seal it use a twist off cap thats not damaged. theres even designs for the sticker for the lid if you want to protect the sticker use a polypropylene or clear epoxyThanks For ReadingBuy this game if you havent!The Fallout Anthology Package is the way to go. It comes with a mini nuke. There is an empty slot for Fallout 4.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												My stats are slightly confusing as they don't seem to count timing correctly. I must have played about 50-60 hours by now or so which is fair enough to make a review. As reference I finished the game once with a few side quests (about 30-40 hours, and made another build to do a casual powerrun which finished the game in 10-11 hours. Faster is possible obviously but you'd miss the entire idea behind the Fallout games if you did.Compared to New Vegas, Fallout 3 is a lot more straightforward as less speech options really determine how the game flows, however at the same time more survival/radiation build. You get less traces on your map, less evident companions, you're more left to yourself basically. Which is nice too, it's just different from New Vegas.Of course you'll always have Three Dog and a friendly reminder that not everyone wants to set the world on fire which is conforting in its own right.All in all, a very decent RPG game that I can fully advice to anyone.BTW, if you only have a dualcore but you have windows 7, the game will run just fine ;)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												This was my second playthrough. First time was in 2009. All told I think I have about 250+ hours into FO3. The first time through I was about 100 hours in before I finished the main story. This time I finished the main story in about 20 hours. I think it felt better this time to stay on track before going out and exploring the wastes. I mean, I needed to help my dad! Last time I was so distracted and I think I even forgot about helping him. This time I played on hard. It was a lot of fun, and way too easy after level 18 or so.. I still ended up always looting too much and being overloaded. Games with a lot of stuff to loot and keep track of really help me see my obsessive nature. This time I didn't use VATS so much, and I got to experience what a poor shooter the game is. The weapons suck and are always breaking. So early on I put all my skill points into repair skills. I loved having well-maintainted gear, and it made it easier to immediately make use of stuff that was loading me down.The Pitt was the most memorable for me.I felt so conflicted by the quest's ultimate decision. Am I wrong for choosing to side with the ex-brotherhood dude despite him enslaving people? I trusted his ultimate intentions, and his vision seemed more broad than the slave's. I supposed he could possibly have the means to carry out his intentions and that maybe the wastes would benefit. The slave seemed to be acting mostly out of anger, and he lacked information to tell me why I should help him. But.. He was a slave. I naturally wanted to help him.Mothership Zeta was maybe 10% interesting and the rest was just mundane and boring. And why where some of those alien dudes so so so tough? That was crazy.Operation Anchorage was nice because the simulator had blue sky.  The color was nice. The story was easy.Would I recommend a second playthrough?I don't know.. I had fun. But I think it was better back in the day. This time, I enjoyed more the way that I played it. The order of the quests made it much more interesting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												A player's experience in Fallout 3 is one that is different for every person. No two playthroughs will be the same. Unless... your just that type of person. I know your thinking "Why should I listen to this jackass, he only has 7 hours logged on this game." You are right to say that, but your also not. If you combine my time on the PC version, along side with my time on the xbox 360 and ps3 versions of the game, I've logged in around 400 hours. I am just now playing on the PC version because.. I just bought a PC! Fallout 3 takes you into the Capital Wasteland, a place that is mostly avoided despite it having such a lovely name. You are put in a chair and spun around untill your too disy to think, in a good way. You are literally born in the game, you then decide your gender, and your appearnce. You are then thrust in to the life eof an average child as you make your way from being in diapers, to your birthday party, and to taking you G.O.A.T which is a test that decides what position you will fill in the cault you live in when you grow up. This doesn't last long however when one day you wake up and chaos has struck. Vault 101 was your home, but it becomes a madhouse once your father escapes the vault. (No one's supposed to do that. Overseer's orders) This is now a madhouse that you try to escape in order to pursue after your father. Walking out of the vault and taking in the masssive view of the wasteland is breataking. You gaze among the surounding suburbs and the washington monument way in the distance. After you complete the breathtaking campaign, theres a total of 3 DLC's to extend you gametime. After you complete a DLC, you are free to return to the wastes with the treasures, and memories (both good and haunting) to use on your enimies you've made throughout your journey. If your wondering about the notice saying "It's not compatible for windows 7 or later." that's because it's not. The game won't literally work unless you fix it. And that's putting it lightly. The amount of steps you have to do really depends on what processor you have. If you have something such as an AMD (Which is what I have) You will have less steps than someone who has an intel processor. The lucky owner of an intel will have to do only a few more minutes worth of steps, but it's worth it in the long run. Saldy I can't find the video that helped me get my Fallout 3 working a week ago, so you'll have to find it yourselve's :/ Believe me, I looked for 20 munites jus now D: I would post all the steps, but sadly I don't remember them (There was that many)Fallout 3 is a must play, and deffidently belongs on all PC's gamers hardrive. This is truely on of the best games ever created.10 out of 10, would wasteland again.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Hiking simulator and open world game!  This game is full of crap, literally. Seriously, there's crap everywhere and that's supposed to be the driving force of the immersion in the game.  You're supposed to collect this crap, apparently.  Early game is mildly taxing compared to late game, at which point you become an unstoppable force of maxed out in everything as per every single Bethesda game ever.  The game is also pretty polarized in regards to said morality, as well.  There are no hard choices.  The game copies the *VISUAL* sense of desolation from Fallout 1 well, but lacks the black humor in the writing, factions, music, voiceovers, and the quality of interactions between the PC and environment.  Fallout 1 was short and sweet.  This game is drawn out and full of crap, and not the high quality crap that filled up Fallout 1, 2, and New Vegas.  I don't regret playing this game for 50+ hours, but I don't exactly celebrate its release as game of the year.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												This is without a doubt one of the best RPGs I have ever played, tailing just behind Skyrim. Thought if you have newer (or just relevant) versions of Windows you will have to install some user made content to make the game run, the 30 minutes doing that is absolutely worth it, as this amazing game offers countless hours of content and an amazing open world that you can freely roam and help your fellow survivors. The campaign is the best in the series and is compelling as you play as the Lone Wanderer who leaves his vault and goes out into the wasteland to find his father and finish the goal his parents had created years before. All-in-all this is an amazing game that everyone deserves the chance to try. [CAN'T WAIT FOR FALLOUT 4]

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												UPDATE: So after having not played this game for almost a year now, and having since upgraded to Windows 10 since the original posting of this review, I thought it would be a good idea to see if Fallout 3 is still broken. After downloading the game and its DLC, installing all of it, and then spending about 2 hours modding the heck out of it, I can safely say that Fallout 3 is running (at least for now) absoulutely flawlessly on my Windows 10 machine! I cannot overstate how awesome this is! This is by far and away one of my favorite games of all time, and I am SO happy that it is working on the newest hardware! What are you waiting for?! BUY THIS GAME ALREADY!Fallout 3 is one of the best video games of all time.  Fallout 3 is one of my favorite videogames of all time.  Fallout 3 is also extremely broken on anything above Windows XP.  It pains me to say this because I absolutely love this game!  (Ignore my hours played I have spent at least 200+ hours in this game on the Xbox 360 version as well as the PC version) I have had a myriad of issues with the PC version of Fallout 3 ever since I upgraded to Windows 8.  I have tried various things to attempt to fix the constant CTDs I receive when playing this game all to no avail.  If you happen to have a PC that is running Windows XP (I also hear that Windows 7 kinda works as well) then by all means you owe it to yourself to play this amazing game!  For anyone using Windows 8 or the newly released Windows 10, you have been warned.Despite not working on my Windows 8 PC, I feel like I can still recommend this game because of all the fun I've already had.  If Bethesda decides to patch this in the future then I will certainly be redownloading and replaying Fallout 3.TL;DRFallout 3 is prone to constant CTDs when being played on a Windows 8 PC.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												A player's experience in Fallout 3 is one that is different for every person. No two playthroughs will be the same. Unless... your just that type of person. I know your thinking "Why should I listen to this jackass, he only has 7 hours logged on this game." You are right to say that, but your also not. If you combine my time on the PC version, along side with my time on the xbox 360 and ps3 versions of the game, I've logged in around 400 hours. I am just now playing on the PC version because.. I just bought a PC! Fallout 3 takes you into the Capital Wasteland, a place that is mostly avoided despite it having such a lovely name. You are put in a chair and spun around untill your too disy to think, in a good way. You are literally born in the game, you then decide your gender, and your appearnce. You are then thrust in to the life eof an average child as you make your way from being in diapers, to your birthday party, and to taking you G.O.A.T which is a test that decides what position you will fill in the cault you live in when you grow up. This doesn't last long however when one day you wake up and chaos has struck. Vault 101 was your home, but it becomes a madhouse once your father escapes the vault. (No one's supposed to do that. Overseer's orders) This is now a madhouse that you try to escape in order to pursue after your father. Walking out of the vault and taking in the masssive view of the wasteland is breataking. You gaze among the surounding suburbs and the washington monument way in the distance. After you complete the breathtaking campaign, theres a total of 3 DLC's to extend you gametime. After you complete a DLC, you are free to return to the wastes with the treasures, and memories (both good and haunting) to use on your enimies you've made throughout your journey. If your wondering about the notice saying "It's not compatible for windows 7 or later." that's because it's not. The game won't literally work unless you fix it. And that's putting it lightly. The amount of steps you have to do really depends on what processor you have. If you have something such as an AMD (Which is what I have) You will have less steps than someone who has an intel processor. The lucky owner of an intel will have to do only a few more minutes worth of steps, but it's worth it in the long run. Saldy I can't find the video that helped me get my Fallout 3 working a week ago, so you'll have to find it yourselve's :/ Believe me, I looked for 20 munites jus now D: I would post all the steps, but sadly I don't remember them (There was that many)Fallout 3 is a must play, and deffidently belongs on all PC's gamers hardrive. This is truely on of the best games ever created.10 out of 10, would wasteland again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												This was my second playthrough. First time was in 2009. All told I think I have about 250+ hours into FO3. The first time through I was about 100 hours in before I finished the main story. This time I finished the main story in about 20 hours. I think it felt better this time to stay on track before going out and exploring the wastes. I mean, I needed to help my dad! Last time I was so distracted and I think I even forgot about helping him. This time I played on hard. It was a lot of fun, and way too easy after level 18 or so.. I still ended up always looting too much and being overloaded. Games with a lot of stuff to loot and keep track of really help me see my obsessive nature. This time I didn't use VATS so much, and I got to experience what a poor shooter the game is. The weapons suck and are always breaking. So early on I put all my skill points into repair skills. I loved having well-maintainted gear, and it made it easier to immediately make use of stuff that was loading me down.The Pitt was the most memorable for me.I felt so conflicted by the quest's ultimate decision. Am I wrong for choosing to side with the ex-brotherhood dude despite him enslaving people? I trusted his ultimate intentions, and his vision seemed more broad than the slave's. I supposed he could possibly have the means to carry out his intentions and that maybe the wastes would benefit. The slave seemed to be acting mostly out of anger, and he lacked information to tell me why I should help him. But.. He was a slave. I naturally wanted to help him.Mothership Zeta was maybe 10% interesting and the rest was just mundane and boring. And why where some of those alien dudes so so so tough? That was crazy.Operation Anchorage was nice because the simulator had blue sky.  The color was nice. The story was easy.Would I recommend a second playthrough?I don't know.. I had fun. But I think it was better back in the day. This time, I enjoyed more the way that I played it. The order of the quests made it much more interesting.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Running it on Windows 10 on ultra graphics very smooth solid 60fps I can achieve higher frames but I choice to use vsync because of screen tearing. And HDR looks sweet. step 1 modify FALLOUT.ini(documents->mygames->fallout3) file if you have more then a dual coreunder general change the following lines of codechange bUseThreadedAI=0 to bUseThreadedAI=1add line of code under generaliNumHWThreads=2step 2 download/install games for live on windows websitestep 3 download/install fallout live disabler from nexus modstep 4 change both launcher and exe compatibility mode to windows xp sp3 and run as adminstratorstep 5 Make sure Drivers are updated thanks to nvidia community that was easy I have a 980GTXm 4gb gpustep 6  play the best game ever made.On a lighter noteNuka Cola Recipe IRL1/3 coca cola1/3 mountain dew1/3 creme sodaenjoy the refreshing drink! because in total I played this on xbox 360 120 Hours and now I will be doing it again this time on my brand new MSI GT72 Maxed out Gaming Laptop until that is they work the bugs out in Fallout 4. I played and beat every bethesda game every sidequest every achievement I might as well work there.I plan in the future 3d printing my own pipboy 3000 its easy the 3d files are online and if you don't have a 3d printer just use 3d hubs it will set you back about 150 bucks.And to make your own nuka cola bottles are easy just print lables onto sticker paper, cut out and take a coca cola bottle(scrap labeling is optional) the mexican cola works good to and fill it full of mountain dew voltage goto radioshack get a resistor(use a led resistor calc online for what ever led you buy) Mine was red blue brown gold, battery holder for a watch battery cr2032, mini switch and uv led (solder it all together) to make your own nuka cola quantum. I can't sell any of this because you know copyrights. lol If you need a good cap to seal it use a twist off cap thats not damaged. theres even designs for the sticker for the lid if you want to protect the sticker use a polypropylene or clear epoxyThanks For ReadingBuy this game if you havent!The Fallout Anthology Package is the way to go. It comes with a mini nuke. There is an empty slot for Fallout 4.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I've finally got to play Fallout 3 and you know what? It is an amazing skydiving simulator! From an experienced skydiver and as someone who has played Fallout New Vegas I can say I don't miss the views of New Vegas as Fallout 3 has so many more places to view and skydive in, the level of detail that has went into this game is brilliant! Compared to the other games you can actually fail, not in the sense of not landing on target, but in the sense if you don't check your gear properly before hand it can fail! Really is a game I would recommend to people who are considering skydiving! I've startred using it for training at my work. For those of you who don't have the guts to jump from a plane, this will give you the experience without the danger! (Maybe put a fan on for wind and an oculus rift)Anyways, amazing game, I will give my review if I ever get to play Fallout 2, but I am worried this game has now spoiled me!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												The landscapes are ugly and grey, the wastes are desolate and depressing, the music is dated and the art style old. Everything is as it should be. Other games in the Fallout series, to me, seemed a bit too inhabited for what they should be. They seemed too colorful and too re-established. Fallout 3 does a good job of mixing the overrun downtown setting with the empty, fire-swept forests of the DC area. I thought this wasn't as good as New Vegas, but still deserves its own merit. I probably would have enjoyed it a lot more if I hadn't fired up Operation Anchorage and gotten the best armor and weapons right away. All in all, however, I found the story a bit short-lived and rather disappointing. Apparently being a good guy and sacrificing yourself at the end is the wrong choice. I gave it a hard time, but everyone else seems to absolutely love everything about it. Go see what they have to say.TL;DR- great game, cliche story. Don't play the Operation Anchorage DLC until later on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Fallout 3 is definitely a good game, but whether or not you think it's one of the all-time greats will probably depend on whether you play it or New Vegas first. If you played New Vegas first, Fallout 3 will initially be a little bit of a letdown. New Vegas is definitely the better designed game overall. Better game mechanics, more options, more nuanced, and better overall design. Fallout 3 can sometimes feel like a generic FPS, with all of the "closed space, tons of enemies, just keep attacking dozens of times and repeatedly using stimpaks" design that you encounter in about a third of the map. That flaw doesn't really exist very much in New Vegas, so it can initially be offputting when you repeatedly encounter it in Fallout 3.However, if you played Fallout 3 first, you'll probably think it's one of the greatest games ever made. It was the first Fallout game that really showed that "wow" factor and hinted at just how great the franchise could be. Plus, you'll be really impressed by the one thing that Fallout 3 does better than New Vegas: emotion. In New Vegas, you are basically a mythic character, with little back story. You don't have that much in common with the NPC's, who are basically mere mortals while you are pre-destined to be a god. I mean, the game starts off with you shrugging off a point-blank shot to the head. The courier might as well come from a different planet than all of the NPC's. In Fallout 3, however, you really get emotionally pulled into the game. You're just an ordinary person who takes it upon themself to do great things. Your whole backstory is very fleshed out, and pretty heartrending. Karma plays a much bigger role in this game than in New Vegas, and makes the playing experience that much more immersive. Family plays a huge role, as do genuinely good NPC's such as Three Dog. The emotional depth of Fallout 3 is some of the best you will ever encounter in a game. If you played New Vegas first, you won't even realize that emotional depth was missing. If you played Fallout 3 first, you will be disappointed by New Vegas' lack of emotional depth, despite the fact that New Vegas is superior in pretty much every other way.In the end, you'll learn to appreciate each game for what it does best. You'll probably wind up preferring whichever one you played first, but you'll still really enjoy both of them. If you already have New Vegas and not Fallout 3, I definitely reccomend purchasing this, just be aware that you'll have to adjust your expectations a bit and look for different positives in this game than you found in New Vegas.PS.- Be sure to adjust some of the game files after you install the game. Once you do, the game seldomly ever crashes. Until you do that, it crashes every few minutes. See this thread for details, and also look up a fix regarding Games for Windows Live, which drastically affects the performance of Fallout 3: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2814142

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												Fallout 3 is a wonderful open world game that only realizes it's full potential when heavily modded.  To get to to run properly on Windows 7 x64 without crashing at startup or upon loading a new game I had to:1. Add the following line to the Havok section of the fallout.ini:iNumThreads=22. Install and run FOSE (http://fose.silverlock.org/download/fose_v1_2_beta2.7z) instead of the Fallout exe, and install the New Vegas Anti Crash plugins( it works for Fallout 3 as well as New Vegas, and the Dl link is http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/53635/?)The GFWL Disabler (http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?) might also help, and enabling the 4GB flag on the game's executable should reduce crashes if using 2K HD retextures like NeilMB. ENBoost could help as well.For modding the game, a good base to start is: http://wiki.step-project.com/User:Kelmych/Fallout3Improved textures, more weapons, more enemies, better lighting, new houses and companions, more interiors, increased difficulty...It will take at least a day to download and set all of those mods up though.

I see why people like it, but after multiple tries, I still can't get into the game.Combat is very clunky, the pacing is very slow and drawn out, movement is slow, and it just bores me. I've tried to keep pushing to complete the game, but it is very boring to me. I see why people like it: It's a huge world, with lots of characters and quests, but I just don't feel like it is fun. However, I will still try to keep playing it to see if I can get into it.EDIT: I have sunk a long amount of time into this game, and let me tell you, the game gets a lot better. The pacing is still kind of odd in my opinion, and at some points the game feels very slow, but after playing for a while, I really do enjoy it, and I can't wait to play it again.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												the first fallout game i played, Fallout 3 incredible main story, awsome side quests, and massive nonlieniar atmosphiric open world make this one of the best games i've ever played. After playing both new vegas and fallout 4, i found that in terms of story, atmosphere ,and side quests, fallout 3 is the clear winner dispite in my opinion not being as overall good as fallout 4 (but still 500x better then new vegas, seriously i have no idea what obsidian was thinking when they implemented ceasars legion or thought that the game had an acceptable main quest.) The only true flaw i find in fallout 3 is the actual writing and dialoge that goes with its incredible story, at times its has that nice simple feel to it that might remind you of dialoge beween saturday morning action cartoons (childish, but at the same time awsome,) other times it just is downright childish and rather lazy (seriously, one of the many ways to kill the main villan is to convince him that he is insane, and he just kills himself, yeah its very hard to pass the speech check, but its still rather silly way to destroy a rather awsome villian.) Overall fallout 3 is a gameing masterpeice, combining rpg elements from the first 2 games with (at the time of its relese) modern fps mechanics to bring a new standard to the fallout franchise, a standard that set the foundation for fallout new vegas and Fallout 4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												It has been a while since I have actually sat down for a playthrough, however the times that I have were unforgettable moments. This game admittedly has a fairly short campaign once the player is aware of the certain courses that need to be taken; this does not limit replayablility, however. Although the campaign itself is fairly short and straightforward, the gameplay is a whole separate story. With Hub locations across the map, several factions to join, as well as a myriad of perks to choose from as the game progresses, different quest outcomes based on your responses, and a wealth of quests included in the main campaign, side campaigns, quests in add-on packs, as well as the occasional single side mission.  There was never really a dull moment for me in this game. Occasionally the game will minimize with no hope of re-opening, but I am also running on Windows 10, which is a fairly easy scapegoat at this point.  I only have 73 logged hours, but I have so many uncounted hours within my Xbox playthroughs (I happened to acquire that version for free) and I have fallen in love with the game and franchise.  This game will not disappoint.  I give this game 10 Bobbleheads out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I'm just getting my review out there now—I'm also one of those typical players who hasn't even made any progress since I [left the Vault and became a wanderererere going all over the place]I also decided I would review this game, as I've selected it for the 2016 Steam Awards; in the 'Game within a Game' category. Though, looking past what you might be thinking—the text-based game inside of Hubris Comics—this is obviously a game about harsh survival; in an even harsher, post-apocalyptic world with an amazing backstory to it [I can assume, as I've forementioned that I haven't made any progress with the game's story]It's a personal story for me, the idea of a 'Lone Wanderer'—a hero among the world that's left. It's amazing, and just so facinating to me. And the Karma aspect of the game really enhances the experience for us gamers, and there are way too many games out there nowadays that restrict you into playing a set character profile and stuff [looking at you, Fallout 4]. Sure, there aren't that many options in this game where you can customize your character, but, with the kind of game this is, you don't need to be a loud-mouth, drunk-off-your♥♥♥♥♥kind of guy/girl, or whatever. You can either be a hero or a villain; silent, at that.Anyway, the 'Game within a Game' comes from nowing how to survive out there. Yes, I know it's a game, and you can just reoad your last save if you screw up, but I'm one of te few who NEVER do that, because, as with real life, you can't just turn back time and forget about a bullet lodged in your shoulder, or a sledgehammer right to your skull. I love challenging myself like this: it makes the experience all the more real and authentic. In a war-torn land, you must do absolutely everything you can just to make it past a group of bandits. There are also too many recent games that rob the player of this particular experience—the true survival apect of a game. You might look at Fallout 3 and instantly compare it to something totally outlandish like Call of Duty 'Zombies' being the definition of hardcore, or Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode in Borderlands 2 [which actually is VERY challenging and rewarding], but for a game that has rightly earned a 'Game of the Year' tag, you need to try Fallout 3. It's one of the most authentic games from the last generation. ^w^

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												Looking back, I am honestly surprised as to how much time I spent in Fallout 3 considering the amount of cheating I did with the console for lols.Now, I did not play this game back when it came out, in fact I first played this after playing Fallout 4 on the PS4. I can see why people loved this game so much, and it will have a special place in my heart, however there was some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ttery to get through.I first got this game during a summer sale, when I was still using a laptop with integrated graphics. The amount of pain and suffering I had to do to make Fallout 3 work, while in retrospect not much, but I spent minimum 10 hours googling solutions. That aint right. Half the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t was with the game not launching if you do not have Games For Windows Live, the other half is the incompatibility with integrated graphics and windows 8.1 and 10. Once I managed to make it work on my laptop, I had a blast. When I made my PC and attempted to play this game, I had the old batch of problems, a whole NEW batch of problems because of windows 10 issues, and crashing whenever I exited the game or used the ingame steam overlay. I mean, I have played older games with no problems but Fallout 3 chooses to be one? Does not add up in my mind. Once I managed to get through all the problems however, it was a really enjoyable experience. Buyer Beware, THIS GAME WILL MAKE HEADACHES AT FIRST.Now on to the review:Pros-The Roleplaying And Development Of The Protagonist Was Fun-Wandering Around Killing♥♥♥♥♥♥Felt Awesome-The Atmosphere, While Gray And Drab, Was Spot On For A Post War World-The Little Stories Here And There Were Intriguing, And Made Me Think About Them For A Long Time-CharmCons-Initial ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t-Voice Acting Could Have Been More Varied-The Main Story Was.... Meh-The Shooting Mechanics Are Horrid-Ending Feels Off Without The DLC Broken SteelThere is a lot more to it, but I would give it a 7/10. Get it on sale, not full price

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Fallout 3. Immersive, intriguing, and badass. The story is one of the best stories in gaming. I find it to be just as good a story as BioShock. You may hear,"Oh it's just you tryna find your dad. It's really not that interesting." To HELL with that. You need to actually expirience this game in order to truly and fully appreciate Fallout 3's story. Three issues I have with the game. Number one, the game will not work properly on Windows 7 or above. Now this CAN BE FIXED. If you cannot figure it out, message me because I want you to enjoy this game. Number two, the visuals are not impressive. This was to be expected with a huge open world RPG such as this. Like most other games, you can modify this game.  Taking the visuals to a whole 'nother level. It rivals SKYRIM and BIOSHOCK INFINITE. That said, you need a beefy graphics card to handle the visual mods. With advanced shaders, blue skies and better looking textures, this game looks phenomenal. I don't enjoy the fact that you have to modify the game to make it prettier, but what has to be done must be done. Having siad that, the game isn't unbearable vanilla. I said the visuals are not impressive, not that they are bad. Number three, Fallout has a reputation for being one of the BUGGIEST PIECES OF LOVELY♥♥♥♥♥♥ It isn't as bad as DayZ but the fact that the two can even be compared is saddening to me. Fortunately, most common and random bugs disappear when playing on pc. They occasionally occur and most are easy fixes. Most. Crashing is eliminated with a 4gb patch and stuttering is solved with a simple mod. At long last you can enjoy your childhood once more at 60fps (good graphics card) and no crashing as it did on console. I rate 10/10 vanilla on PC, 9/10 on console and with mods 11/10. I would recommend this game a million times if I could.
